LEAD: Life-size earthenware storks, fish-patterned platters, leaf-embellished tureens - all in the brilliantly colored majolica glazes popularized in the Renaissance and revived in the Victorian period - have been pursued increasingly over the last decade by collectors, dealers and museum curators.

LEAD: Casper Leads Seniors: Billy Casper marveled at his own performance after shooting a five-under-par 65 to lead the British Seniors Open with a nine-under-par 201 after the third round at Turnberry, Scotland, yesterday. Casper was being pursued by Bob Charles of New Zealand, who also shot a 65 for 203.
LEAD: IS New York City succeeding in dealing with its problems, as Mayor Edward I. Koch contends, or is it in deep trouble, as his three Democratic challengers contend?
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about homes for unwed mothers misidentified the group that runs Heritage Home in San Jose, Calif. It is the Heritage Life Foundation.
LEAD: THE ACTING PRESIDENT By Bob Schieffer and Gary Paul Gates. 397 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $18.95.

LEAD: Since its creation in 1978, the United States Olympic Festival, despite occasional problems and internal conflicts, has remained true to its mission of being a springboard for the nation's best amateur athletes. In the 11 years since, practically all of the nation's Olympians have competed in a festival and many achieved their first fame before festival crowds.
LEAD: A private company has proposed a nationwide ''pay now, attend later'' plan guaranteeing parents current tuition rates years before their children go to college.

LEAD: The Manhattan dance studio that is the setting for the first act of the Otto Harbach-Karl Hoschna musical ''Madame Sherry'' is a place where twittery socialities play at being budding Isadora Duncans. In ''Aesthetic Dancing/Every Little Movement,'' the opening number of the Goodspeed Opera House's glowing revival of the 1910 show, half a dozen students waft about the stage, their chiffon-draped arms spread like giant butterfly wings in an interpretive dance that looks at once silly and sensuous.

LEAD: With baby boomers nesting, furniture sales - listless through the 1970's - are growing once again. Retail sales have climbed 24 percent since 1985, to $29.4 billion last year, according to the American Furniture Manufacturers Association, a trade group.

LEAD: BEFORE Albertina Bloom died in l980, the soft-spoken schoolteacher from White Plains found a way to have her lifelong effort to motivate students continue after her death. Miss Bloom designated her entire estate to provide scholarships for Westchester high school students ''who might otherwise be unable to avail themselves of the advantages of collegiate training,'' as she stated in her will.

LEAD: Tasmania, 1905. A young apple farmer with carrot-colored hair that forms a mushroom cloud around his head roams the orchards with his pet Tasmanian devil. But instead of worrying about harvest schedules or thunderstorms, he has on his mind nothing less than the state of the universe.

LEAD: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. BIRD - In a psychological character study of remarkable complexity, directed by Clint Eastwood, Forest Whitaker plays the saxophonist Charlie Parker as a kind of big brilliant baby. Drenched in great music, the film ''may be long, messy, and a bit drab-looking, but it is still one of the two or three most powerful jazz-oriented features ever produced.

LEAD: ''On my honor I will do my best/To take what they give me and steal the rest'' is the motto of Frank Dandridge, a soldier who, against all odds, persuades an aloof nightclub singer to marry him in ''Every Goodbye Ain't Gone. . . .'' by Bill Harris. But the wedding is hardly a victory. Rula Payton, the singer he marries, will give love only when she feels like it, and when she finally does, he finds he cannot take it.

LEAD: Thousands of patrons in a record opening-day crowd of 30,658 at Saratoga Race Track left early and angrily today after a ''gremlin'' in the track computers crippled on-track betting on the last five races.

LEAD: Responding to the public airing of casual conversations among crew members in a passenger jet just before a fatal crash in Texas last year, the airline pilots' union today called for legislation restricting the release of such recordings. LEAD: ROBERT A. M. Stern, who has been making custom furniture for for years, has just joined the growing ranks of architects designing pieces for mass production.

LEAD: The cost of running the nation's farms rose 7.5 percent, to $118.4 billion, in 1988, the Agriculture Department reported today. Despite the increase, the figure falls short of the record $131.8 billion that farmers spent in 1981, before the general financial crunch that stalled expansion in the agricultural sector.

LEAD: Wave Hill's imaginative summer Dancescape series got off to a promising start on Saturday night with a performance by Kei Takei's Moving Earth company. Each choreographer in the series has chosen an environment in this sprawling 28-acre estate in Riverdale. Ms. Takei selected a hill fringed by a thick forest for her ''Wild Grass River.

LEAD: Hassan Hakmoun, who brought his Gnawan Moroccan band, Magmouat Hakmoun, to the Village Gate on Tuesday night, is one of those musicians who can prod and inspire his musicians into a frenzy. A virtuoso of rhythm, he slammed out riffs on his sintir (a cello-like lute), changing the accent on the notes, making new riffs from the last note of an old one, leaving notes out to vary the rhythms, picking up and slowing down tempos.

LEAD: SCRIMSHAW, the ancient art of carving ivory, has been given a new life. Inspired to protect species like whales that have been traditional sources of ivory, David Lazarus, a Nantucket, Mass., artist, found he could get ivory-like results working on plastics like Corian or Formica.
LEAD: The United States Mission to the United Nations, in an effort to defray the high costs of New York housing, plans to raise the pay of its employees by 25 percent.

LEAD: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc. said today that it filed a bankruptcy court lawsuit charging its former chairman, Dino De Laurentiis, with fraud and seeking more than $50 million in damages from him and two of his production concerns.
LEAD: In a deft display of machine politics, Poland's Communist leadership snuffed out a parliamentary uprising today and pushed through the party's nominee for Prime Minister.
LEAD: The House has rejected an attempt to make the Census Bureau exclude illegal aliens from the population count that will be used to reapportion Congressional seats after the 1990 census.

The film is an updated version - by Mr. Vadim, Roger Vailland and Claude Brule - of the 18th-century novel of sexual adventure and deceit by Choderlos de Laclos. LEAD: Genevieve Fisch Fernandez, a public relations consultant, and Richard Gilbert Hewitt, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Lowell Hotel in New York by Judge J. LEAD: A central measure of a society is how well it treats its children. By that standard, New York City is in trouble. LEAD: The peculiar thing about Beijing, two months after troops and tanks crushed the democracy movement, is how normal life at first seems to be.

LEAD: The New Jersey Stars of the Domino's Pizza TeamTennis league announced yesterday that Tracy Austin, who was in an automobile accident Thursday in Short Hills, N.J., suffered a broken bone in her right leg in the crash and was being cared for at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. The Stars' coach, Asim Sengun, named Leigh Thompson, a 25-year-old former touring pro who is now the women's tennis coach at Maryland, to replace Austin.

LEAD: Last week the United Auto Workers union suffered a humiliating defeat in its bid to represent employees at a Nissan plant in Smyrna, Tenn. The Smyrna workers rejected the U.A.W. because Nissan already provided high wages and job security. With these benefits in hand, a U.A.W. presence posed more threat than promise.
LEAD: Racial segregation in 10 of the nation's largest cities is more deeply entrenched and takes more forms than social scientists previously thought, a study by the University of Chicago has found.

LEAD: The dollar rose sharply against major currencies yesterday after the employment report for July convinced many traders that the economy was not slowing down sharply and that there was therefore less reason to expect the Federal Reserve to move interest rates lower soon.

LEAD: William Larimer Mellon Jr., an heir to his family's banking and oil fortune who in midlife became a disciple of Albert Schweitzer and spent his remaining years as a medical missionary in Haiti, died of cancer and Parkinson's disease on Thursday at his home in Deschapelles, Haiti. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: Stock prices fell yesterday, depressed by losses in the bond market after a surprisingly strong July employment report allayed fears of recession and dampened hopes of further declines in interest rates.

LEAD: A Harlem hospital has received a $150 million mortgage that will allow it to construct a new building, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today. Joint Diseases North General Hospital, at 1919 Madison Avenue, will build a new hospital two blocks away with 240 beds, including 40 for people with AIDS.

LEAD: On the wane five years ago, the 35-year revival in collecting Louis Comfort Tiffany's stained-glass lamps has come alive with renewed vigor. The resurgence of interest is being seen in several museum exhibitions and in escalating prices at auctions.

LEAD: The object is a fan, round with a long stem handle, of the type supplied by undertakers for promotional purposes and handed out free in churches. LEAD: THERE are certain things I remember about our family's long summer trips from the land of Lincoln into the heart of Dixie. I remember the blinding sun reflecting off the windshields of approaching cars; the heat blowing through the windows upon my parents, my brother, my sister and me, and the black .38 pistol my father packed in the glove compartment.

LEAD: Although fish have been farmed in this country for more than 30 years, aquaculture has never been what you would call a booming business. Most of the entrepreneurs who dominate the business lack the resources and sophistication to bring their fish to the mass market.

LEAD: I found Joseph Epstein's article a little disappointing. LEAD: The Western imprint on fashion is now much like a cattle brand - not too striking, but obvious enough to catch the eye. For city dudes, that means accents: a fringed jacket with black leggings; a shearling coat with a pin-stripe suit; a pair of lizard boots with almost anything. When in doubt about the mix, stride up to the mirror.
LEAD: There was new danger but also new hope for hostages in Lebanon last week. The captors' complex motives make the outcome highly unpredictable. The Week in Review, section 4.

LEAD: THE tag sale was not to begin until 10 A.M. but some anxious customers were parked along the road the night before and had slept in their cars. LEAD: WILLIAM HOPKINS has been fighting drugs for more than 40 years, first as a Bronx narcotics officer and for the past 11 years as the supervisor of the street studies unit of the New York State Division of Substance Abuse Services. He is retiring this year, as soon as a replacement can be named and trained.

LEAD: Forty-six traders were indicted on charges that they repeatedly defrauded customers at Chicago's two commodity futures exchanges. The indictments stemmed from a two-year investigation that put undercover Federal agents, posing as traders, on the floors of the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

LEAD: Namibia is proceeding bumpily on the road to elections on Nov. 1 that will lead in turn to a constitutional conference. What's not so good is that South Africa is trying to tilt the vote to its political allies, using the roughhouse cops known as Koevoet.

LEAD: The current revival of the short- sleeved jacket makes so much sense one wonders what took it so long to come back. Sticky summer days take most of the fun out of dressing up; in fact, they make it a chore. Of course, there is always the option of dispensing with a jacket or blazer altogether, but that's not practical for women whose jobs, or personalities, require a touch of formality.

LEAD: The duffel coat is moving up the fashion ladder. This upwardly mobile style started as a rugged coat for country wear and bad weather, made in sturdy fabrics like loden cloth. Leather toggles anchored it securely, a hood that buttoned under the chin kept out the wind, and the fabric was frequently water resistant so it would keep out the rain.

LEAD: Sesame noodles are the chop suey of the 80's. Just about every takeout Chinese restaurant offers the dish. It is the rich taste of the sesame, freshened with ginger and sweetened slightly, that appeals to us. The taste is not unlike peanut butter. It is easy to have a version of the sauce on hand to use whenever the mood for that flavor strikes.

LEAD: With its most ambitious restoration project set to begin, at the Columbus Monument on Columbus Circle, and with two major Brooklyn monuments newly reclaimed, the two-year-old program in which private benefactors adopt New York City's deteriorating public statuary has had a busy summer.

LEAD: HERE is a report written by a school psychologist in California about a 9-year-old boy in the third grade whose teachers were concerned about his serious lack of academic progress. His name has been withheld.

LEAD: THE greatest disease of mankind is a lack of love, according to the surgeon and author Bernie S. Siegel, who advocates that the body can be healed through the mind. Dr. Siegel talks about caring, not curing; living, not merely postponing death through medical intervention, and above all loving oneself and others.

LEAD: Richard Welch, in decrying a recent Court of Appeals ruling that permits unrelated people to occupy single family homes (''Court V. Family: Homeowners Lose,'' Opinion, June 25), implies that we homeowners who would do so are not working, middle-class people, and that the ruling will devalue neighborhoods.

LEAD: Questions. What is Samuel's on-base average? Are leadoff batters supposed to strike out often? Was McDowell responsible for the ground balls that his past teammates could not convert into outs? Is Dykstra still a hot dog with incredible marketability? Could Tom Edens possibly be related to Barbara Eden?
LEAD: EMMA GOLDMAN IN EXILE From the Russian Revolution to the Spanish Civil War. By Alice Wexler. Illustrated. 301 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $24.95.
LEAD: Q. I have a wood end table that has a mark caused by a glass of water and a spot where paper is stuck to the finish. Can you advise me how to remove these blemishes?

LEAD: A chart last week accompanying an article about the Harvard Business Review provided an incorrect scale for measuring the publication's advertising pages. The figures showed the number of advertising pages, not a multiple of that number.

LEAD: Many Americans will forever think of African music as folk music. Every year this becomes more of a mistake. In urbanized Africa, untainted folk music has grown as quaint and artificially preserved as it is in the cities of the West. The singing griots of Mali and elsewhere keep an oral folklore tradition alive, but

LEAD: The National Women's Political Caucus, a group that has often been overshadowed by feminist organizations with sharper demands, pledged this weekend to work within the two-party system and to make abortion rights the focus of its work in the next year.

LEAD: The rookie Bob Milacki won for the first time in a month tonight, scattering seven hits in eight and one-third innings as the Baltimore Orioles won for only the third time in 17 games, beating Texas, 5-2, and continuing their domination of the Rangers' ace, Nolan Ryan.

LEAD: Some of the best, or at least most successful, opening variations look like desperation. They look like what occurs to you at 4 o'clock some morning when you have racked your brain to figure out what to play against a solid defense that has so far mocked all attempts to find something - anything - wrong with it.
LEAD: A FLYING SAUCER with three high school students and their history teacher inside drops out of the sky above a Jamestown settler bartering knives for beaver skins with an Indian.

LEAD: Tanya Yvette Thomas, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Alvin Thomas of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Reginald Samuel Pinder, the son of Valerie Pinder of the Bronx, at Scarborough Presbyterian Church in Scarborough Manor, N.Y. Bishop James I. Clark Jr. of Christ Temple Apostolic Church in New York, an uncle of the bride, officiated.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Of all the scandals now rattling the Washington bureaucracy, none touches more Americans than wrongdoing in the Internal Revenue Service. Federal tax collectors regularly intrude on more citizens than any other arm of government. Such huge power requires scrupulous honesty. But a House subcommittee has spotlighted distressing laxity in staff supervision.

LEAD: MANY PARENTS complain that their children spend too much time playing video games, thus neglecting homework and retarding healthy social development. It is a familiar complaint, having been leveled against television for years.

LEAD: A 450-UNIT condominium complex in the Bronx is expected to be the first project in New York City to be built under a new state law that broadens the use of city capital-budget funds in assisting housing development on private land. The legislation was signed into law late last month by Gov. Mario M.
LEAD: FATAL ERROR The Miscarriage of Justice That Sealed the Rosenbergs' Fate. By Joseph H. Sharlitt. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.
LEAD: The Denver Broncos' Tony Dorsett, the National Football League's No. 2 career rusher, underwent major reconstructive knee surgery in Colorado yesterday, leaving his football future in jeopardy.

LEAD: It was supposed to be a test of the relationship between two people. It became a test of will and survival. Janet Culver and the man she had been dating, Nicholas Abbott, set sail July 13 from Bermuda to Long Island in a 37-foot sloop. Ms. Culver, a 48-year-old executive secretary from Passaic, N.J., went along to see how she liked long-distance sailing and Mr.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Rome'' (Travel, June 18) provided a good summary of what visitors can see and do, but one very important bit of advice was missing. First-time visitors should be cautioned about the many pickpockets, including small groups of children. They seem to have an uncanny eye for spotting visitors from the United States.
LEAD: Renato Jamett hopes to be the governor of Michigan some day, and he is getting some early training for the job.

LEAD: IN three years of organizing trips for members of her museum, Mable M. MacDonald, the curator of costumes at the Richmondtown Restoration on Staten Island, has learned a great deal about bus tours. What she has learned, sometimes the hard way, can assist people who put together trips for church groups, clubs or cultural organizations or family reunions.

LEAD: SITE preparation has begun on a $120 million retail and entertainment complex that developers and officials hope will be the cornerstone of this city's efforts to become the Beverly Hills of the desert.
LEAD: Anyone who thinks that the classical music business rewards musicians on the basis of talent alone should contemplate the case of Eugene Fodor.
LEAD: CAPTAIN BENNETT'S FOLLY By Berry Fleming. 136 pp. Sag Harbor, L.I.: The Permanent Press.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Shelley Duvall stalks across the cobblestones of Universal Studios, arms folded against her chest. The midnight air is bone-chilling. The moon, two days shy of full face, rises in the cloudless sky. A horse neighs and a gush of wind topples a lamppost to the ground. The globe shatters. Actors and production crew members working on ''The Strange Case of Dr.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Revueltas, Ginastera, Villa-Lobos: String Quartets Cuarteto Latinoamericano. Elan CD 2218; CD only. Latin concert music of this century has tended toward the neo-Classical rather than the fiercely dissonant, with honorable attention paid to the varied folk traditions of the Latin countries.

LEAD: The line between art and life ran down 19th Street in the Astoria section of Queens. Two old men sipped Greek coffee at the Perama Taverna. Six little girls played dodge ball beneath lines of fluttering laundry. Four boys pedaled home from the local swimming pool, shirtless and damp. And Eugenia Spiridakis strolled toward the brick bungalow surrounded by cameras and cranes and lights to see how her son Tony's movie was going.

LEAD: ISRAEL'S kidnapping of a fundamentalist Shiite Muslim cleric nine days ago raised the curtain on a week of new horror and suspense over the fate of hostages in Lebanon. It started with a videotape of a hanged man that a terrorist group said was an American officer and with threats to kill more hostages.

LEAD: The Mexican debt agreement is good for both Mexico and the banks. Mexican negotiators asked for 55 percent reduction in either principal or interest, or an 80 percent refinancing of 6 years of interest payments. The banks met Mexico more than two-thirds of the way with a 35 percent reduction of debt or interest payments or a 60 percent refinancing of interest payments over four years.
LEAD: A Temporary C. of O.
LEAD: Errol Morris, the film maker whose movie ''The Thin Blue Line'' helped to free a death row inmate, has settled a lawsuit brought by the man he helped to free, lawyers for both sides say.

LEAD: Adeline Hofer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Arms Hofer of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Peter Max Polshek, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart Polshek of New York and Stone Ridge, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Chapel of at Colubia University by the Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, the Unitarian-Universalist chaplain at columbia

LEAD: FOR VETERANS OF THE compact-disk revolution - those who were buying anything, anything at all, that was issued when CD's first came on the market and were extremely scarce - the present state of affairs seems like a second CD revolution. In those early days, music lovers and audio buffs) who had to be the first on the block with new technology were happily (well, almosst happily) paying up to $22 for a single disk.

LEAD: An international campaign to have China condemned by the United Nations for human rights violations in connection with its suppression of the democracy movement is expected at a meeting opening on Monday in Geneva.

LEAD: The New York City Housing Authority, the world's largest municipally owned and operated housing agency, is looking for a new director of design and capital improvement, which is considered one of the city's most demanding positions. The authority owns 318 projects of 178,000 apartments housing 570,000 people.

LEAD: Two unscheduled performances of the play ''El Coronel No Tiene Quien Le Escriba'' (''No One Writes to the Colonel'') will be given at 3 and 8 P.M. today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place. The play is in Spanish, with English translation available by headphone. Tickets are $15.

LEAD: STEVE JOBS, SHIRT SLEEVES rolled up to his elbows, long hair over his collar, sits like a virtuoso at the keyboard of his new computer. Behind him, projected onto a huge screen, computer images -silvery letters and symbols - expand and shrink, leap and pop about as Jobs puts the machine through its paces.

LEAD: Students at Villanova University, like growing numbers of students at other campuses, are letting their fingers do the buying these days. Avoiding the crowds and costs of stores in their Main Line Philadelphia neighborhood, they are relying on catalogues instead.

LEAD: Lisa Burke, 15 years old, and Molly Tolkoff, 14, of Brookline, Mass., play a rough and tough, competitive brand of ice hockey for the Brookline High School freshman team. Rough play is not unusual for this sport. What is unusual is that their teammates are boys. In two years, however, the girls won't be on the varsity team.

LEAD: We disagree with the anonymous ''special-education advocates'' who say there are ''no approved facilities that can academically challenge the small number of students who are both learning disabled and academically gifted'' (''Debate on Aiding Gifted Disabled Pupils,'' June 25). At the Newgrange School, we are providing an academically challenging program for some of the intellectually gifted and above-average learning-disabled students in the central New Jersey area.
LEAD: Crack has turned emergency medicine at Highland General Hospital here into a nightmare, a scene of chaos and despair that is crushing the spirits of all who encounter it.
LEAD: Fold back to page 7 and you can read these next to the questions.

LEAD: The funny thing that is happening near Interstate 95, a road otherwise outstanding for tragically bottlenecked traffic on the New England trade route, is the musical that is opening the season for the American Festival Theater here.

LEAD: Late Monday afternoon, with one American hostage reported dead and another facing death, President Bush sat at a small wooden desk with a typewriter in the study tucked behind the Oval Office. He had rushed back from Chicago, canceling stops in Las Vegas and Oklahoma City and waving off suggestions from some advisers that the action might give the Lebanese extremists the impression that they could manipulate the United States Government.

LEAD: Protesting recent food price rises and dismal working conditions, thousands of Polish rail workers in the heavily industrialized southern region of Silesia staged a one-hour walkout today, warning that failure to quickly redress grievances would lead to further labor action, the state television reported.

LEAD: CLEARING THE BASES: Baseball Then and Now. By Bill Starr. (Michael Kesend, $18.95.) Ty Cobb was not as good as his .367 career batting average, say the baseball computer analysts; if he were playing today he would hit only .289. That only proves Cobb's greatness, say the critics of such analysis - .289 is impressive hitting for a 102-year-old.

LEAD: THIS summer, with the ever-increasing trend of families' shying away from long-distance travel in favor of vacations close to home, car repairs and simple tuneups are keeping many service stations in New Jersey busy.

LEAD: Even before the real-estate ads get around to mentioning the Panoramic Vu, the Wbfp, the Mble Bths, Wlkin Clst and Prewar Feeling, they announce - in large capital letters - that the living space for rent or sale has a TERR or ROOFTOP GDN.

LEAD: AS GUARDIANS of the portals of American education, college admissions officers are threatened with lawsuits, offered bribes by parents and nonplussed at the antics of applicants. With the college-admissions season only a few weeks away, admissions officers recall incidents past and gird themselves for the autumn onslaught.

LEAD: For years financial Cassandras have warned of the dangers of ''junk bonds.'' The rapidly expanding market for these low-rated, high-yield securities was hastily erected on a small, fragile and inadequate foundation, they said, and sooner or later many companies issuing the bonds would be unable to meet their debt payments, leaving bond holders without buyers when they wanted to sell.

LEAD: The Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes rose by 5.5 percent in June, the third consecutive monthly increase. The increase came after a sluggish first part of the year when sales fell to their lowest level since the 1981-82 recession. Seasonally adjusted, annual sales of new homes rose to 670,000 units, roughly the same as 1988.

Carleton of Kent, Wash. The ceremony was performed by the Rev.

LEAD: Sarah Martin Pracht, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Pracht Jr. of Mechanicsburg, Pa., was married there yesterday to Stephen J. Geisler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Geisler of Murraysville, Pa. The Rev. Joseph Pease officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Geisler is a senior at the University of Pittsburgh.
LEAD: A PLAN that would fundamentally alter the approach to special education in New Jersey has fallen under sharp criticism from one of the state's largest advocacy groups for handicapped children.

LEAD: The family of a mentally retarded Brooklyn man who suffocated last month during a struggle with the police said yesterday that the man was too mentally impaired to understand what the officers wanted of him.
LEAD: THE CONTROL OF NATURE By John McPhee. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.
LEAD: Louisiana's largest black college, Southern University, has gone to court in an effort to block a Federal court order aimed at desegregating the state's colleges.

LEAD: The only time the United States sent its bombers over Lebanon, as President Bush was reportedly prepared to do again this week, the mission ended in a fiasco, with two planes shot down and one damaged, one pilot killed and and one crewman captured, and little to show for the effort.

LEAD: When Virginia Douds attended Westminster College in the early 1960's, life at the small, church-related school had changed little since its founding in 1852. Students attended chapel services five days a week and men and women were banned from each other's dormitory rooms.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Howard Hurst, who heads a Canadian real estate development corporation, is not by nature an impulsive or emotional man. Indeed, sitting in an office backstage at Broadway's Virginia Theater, the impeccably tailored and soft-spoken chartered accountant appears to be the picture of cautious deliberation.
LEAD: NEVER will I forget the pathetic sight of a tiny, stiff-legged cocaine-addicted baby, trembling nervously and crying for help.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It is not entirely happen-stance that photographs are at the center of the stormy political dispute brought on by indirect Federal support of works by Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano. Much more than paintings, sculptures, plays, novels and poems, camera images seem to bring the world directly to our doorstep.

LEAD: RICHARD DRESSER doesn't dawdle when he sets up a play. In the Phoenix Theater Company's production of ''Alone at the Beach,'' five singles in their 30's have answered an ad for a summer share in the Hamptons - and each has been instantly accepted by George, the owner of the beach house.

LEAD: Erica Jong, the novelist and poet, and Kenneth David Burrows, a lawyer in New York, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Warren, Vt., by Nancy Colby, a justice of the peace in Warren.

LEAD: The California Angels are one of the surprise teams of the season, but perhaps the most surprising aspect of their unexpected success has been the rare combination they have put together. They lead the American League in home runs, earned run average and shutouts, and no team has done that in nearly 30 years.

LEAD: The breakaway effort by a black priest in Washington reflects a desire for assertion and recognition that has been prevalent among many black Roman Catholics in the last 20 years, black church members said. But many agreed that what was new was that it was a clergyman rather than a lay person leading the charge.

LEAD: St. Paul's Church, a relatively small 226-year-old congregation here, has withdrawn from the Episcopal Church of the United States to protest the ordination of women and the appointment of the Rev. Barbara Harris as the denomination's first female bishop.

LEAD: A power failure early yesterday in Seaside Heights, a New Jersey island resort town, left tens of thousands of people in the dark on the boardwalk and in bars and dozens of others stranded on amusement park rides, including a Ferris wheel, the police said.

LEAD: To The Editor: Anne Matthews's piece on Gotland and Visby (Travel, June 25) was an excellent account of the town and the island from the point of view of one who teaches English. For the economic historian and the businessman, however, more could be said.

LEAD: At least four workers who complained about safety and environmental problems at four military nuclear plants run for the Government by private contractors say they were ordered by their superiors to see psychiatrists or psychologists.
LEAD: In a piece distinguished for mean-spiritedness, Joseph Epstein has found a new way to blame the victim: for improper behavior.
LEAD: Sheila Jeanette Dailey and Henry Davis Rohrer 3d were married yesterday at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Noonan performed the ceremony.

LEAD: In an article July 16 about Los Angeles art, Luhring Augustine, a New York gallery, was misidentified. The article also misidentified Fran Seegull, the director of the gallery's New York office, who is moving to its California branch.
LEAD: DISAPPEARING ACTS By Terry McMillan. 384 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: Elsie Cryder Hamilton, a daughter of Mrs. Ferris F. Hamilton of Englewood, Colo., and the late Mr. Hamilton, was married yesterday at the home of her mmother to Thomas Edward Judkins Hazard, a son of Mary Suzanne Sheppard of Towson, Md., and Robert Culver Hazard Jr. of Potomac, Md. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev.

LEAD: In 1920, the third largest expenditure of South Carolina was payments to Confederate Army veterans and their widows. This year it was $2,600, the annual payment that went last month to Daisy Cave of Sumter, who is believed to be 97 years old. Mrs. Cave is the last living widow of a Confederate veteran, a status she has held since Kate Nelms died in Corinth, Miss., in 1987.
LEAD: Unlike most women, Ami Radunskya is partial to mathematics. But then hers was not a typical woman's upbringing.

LEAD: TO WIN NICOLE'S AFFECTION, I take her canoeing. It's the first time just the two of us, my girlfriend's 10-year-old daughter and I, have gone on an outing. I have high hopes for the day: that we'll have a lovely heart-to-heart talk, that we'll trust each other with some secrets, that we'll have a great time.
LEAD: REGARDLESS of what we choose to do for our summer vacation, the majority of us will be traveling in our piece of the American dream: our cars.

LEAD: The first national sailing team for juniors is expected to take shape in the next three weeks with a series of championship regattas. When the final cuts are made, as many as 23 youths will be named to the team.
LEAD: MONKEY BAY By Elaine Ford. 244 pp. New York: Viking.

LEAD: An Irish investment company has paid what may be a record price, on a square-footage basis, for a Manhattan commercial building purchased for investment, rather than redevelopment, purposes - $43 million, or more than $1,500 a square foot. The property is the old Gertrude Rhinelander Waldo mansion at 867 Madison Avenue, on the corner of 72d Street.

LEAD: The Samuel trade was a brilliant one. What better way to shake up a complacent team than to trade two solid, charismatic (and yes, streaky) former world champs for one mediocre strikeout king with no personality? DAN McGUIRE New York

LEAD: IT is definitely light-listening time in the county this week, with only the Valhalla Wagnerfest and the Caramoor Festival left to uphold the honor of the classics. And even Caramoor is starting its week with a jazz concert by the Duke Ellington Orchestra today at 5:30 P.M.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: EVERY time George Pina uses his Nikon 35-millimeter camera he thinks of his job at General Dynamics Corporation in New London. He does not take pictures for the company; he is an engineering chief in the Electric Boat Division. But five years ago, the company awarded him the camera as a result of his work, specifically detecting and later correcting a design deficiency he spotted during a submarine sea trial.

LEAD: A report on a war-crimes inquiry has recommended changes in British law to allow prosecutions for Nazi war crimes said to have been committed by immigrants who have since become British citizens. The report said there was already enough evidence to convict three such people living in Britain.

LEAD: He started his career with the San Francisco Giants, and now, after spending the better part of nine seasons battling the Giants and other National League teams as a pitcher for the Houston Astros, Bob Knepper is getting a chance to finish his career with the Giants.

LEAD: IN THE MIDDLE OF A VILLAGE OF brightly painted wooden huts a helicopter touches down and a small, elderly, blind man, smartly dressed in a gray suit and gray fedora, is carefully helped out and guided into a long, black Lincoln. The limousine, license plate 0-1, immediately speeds 100 yards to a roped-off area of freshly turned earth and neat new concrete houses.

LEAD: There really is a home on the range, and it looks just like you've always imagined. The cowboys sleep under the stars, they herd the cattle for branding and eat their meals around an open fire. The range cook, almost always a cowboy, gets up long before dawn to start the day's meals. It isn't an easy task: on the range, after all, there is no running water and no electricity - only a wood fire and 20 hungry cowboys.
LEAD: Reviving a damaged, stultified society is a Herculean task.
LEAD: Quincy Collins lives at 125th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem, where he is used to hearing police sirens wail throughout the night and seeing homeless people.

LEAD: The fashion photographs in MAN RAY: BAZAAR YEARS (Rizzoli, Cloth, $35; Paper, $19.95), shot for Harper's Bazaar between 1934 and 1942, meld commercialism with artistry of uncommon power. These pictures, most of which have not been reproduced since their original publication, do more than display pretty models filling out fabrics and styles by such celebrated designers as Chanel, Schiaparelli and Mainbocher.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding Joan Gould's article on the Great Mosque of Cordoba, which I visited many years ago: Each of the 850 pillars has a lead plate at the top. In case of earthquake, instead of stone rubbing against stone, the lead acts as a buffer.

LEAD: THE ACTOR JACK Nicholson said three years ago that he would ''like to play people that haven't existed yet, a future something, a >cusp character.'' So he wound up playing the Joker character in ''Batman,'' the movie based on the old comic book.

LEAD: DO most women with children look forward to summer vacation as I do, with a mixture of longing and dread? Who can withstand the charms of summer? The lengthening tender evenings, sharp scents of new-mown grass, the crisp bite of summer peaches, melons and corn? Then the inevitable whine, ''What do I do now?

LEAD: September wedding plans for Ann Forbes Doyle and George Stuart Kane, the son of Mrs. James K. Staley of Fair Oaks, Calif., and Franklin G. Kane of Edmonton, Alberta, have been made known by Miss Doyle's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Doyle of Hingham, Mass. Miss Doyle is a sales representative in Boston for Design Tex Fabrics Inc.

LEAD: When Tim and Christine Burke take their two children out in the double stroller, people peer at the youngsters and ask, ''Are they twins?''

In 1949, Arthur Drayton, a postal worker, was suspended from his job after 25 years of service. His offense: the refusal to disassociate himself from an organization deemed subversive by President Harry S.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Robbins of Kings Point, L.I., and New Milford, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Paige Robbins, and Eric Nerenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Nerenberg of Rockville, Md. Miss Robbins, 23 years old, and Mr. Nerenberg, also 23, graduated from the University of Maryland.

LEAD: MOLIERE WROTE, ''Anyone may be an honorable man, and yet write verse badly.'' This was in the 17th century, before personal computers and Michael Newman's Verse Perfect poetry processor. Using Mr. Newman's software for MS-DOS computers, anyone, honorable or not, can harness the algorithmic powers of the microprocessor to generate acceptable verse in forms ranging from iambic-pentameter sonnets to rap music lyrics.

LEAD: Experts are angling for an explanation of the results of the R. W. Oliver auction of antique and classic fishing tackle in Kennebunk, Me., last month. Although the 755 lots in the auction sold for $436,000, exceeding the presale low estimate of their value by $45,785, buyers showed little interest in some choice items, among them two extremely valuable fly fishing reels.

LEAD: The Last days of July profoundly altered the long-range outlook for audio. Obstacles that had hitherto barred the import of digital audio tape (DAT) decks were suddenly removed by an unexpected agreement between record companies and the manufacturers of DAT equipment. After three years of waiting and some bitter regulatory debates in Congress, American audio fans will at last have unhindered access to this superior method of home recording.

LEAD: Clothing inspired by Southern California's romanticized athletic style of life - surfing, water skiing, dirt bikes and skateboards - is appearing on main streets and in suburban malls, riding the wave of the beach mystique.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE owner of a home in Tarrytown's historic district began tearing down a major addition to the building last week after a judge sentenced him to 10 days in jail for disobeying a court order to remove the wing.

LEAD: REMEMBERING THE BONE HOUSE An Erotics of Place and Space. By Nancy Mairs. 273 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE statistics recited by Mozambique's President Joaquim Chissano have testified to the grim effects of more than a decade of vicious guerrilla war - 600,000 to 700,000 Mozambicans dead in a land of 15 million, an additional 1.6 million displaced as refugees, 2,599 primary schools and 822 rural health clinics destroyed or forced to close, 44 factories and more than 1,000 stores ruined.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE STEPS OF THE SUPREME COURT SHIMMERED IN THE heat as demonstrators on opposite sides of the abortion issue attempted to outshout, out-placard and outnumber each other on the Monday morning the Supreme Court announced its decision on Webster v. Reproductive Health Services. The states, the Court ruled, have the right to limit access to abortion.

LEAD: Labor unions, including many representing New York City workers, have mounted their most intense campaign in recent years for a mayoral candidate, Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

LEAD: It's possible, of course, that the people with really big money and really big-bucks possessions would feel differently about what they'd most hate to lose or have stolen from them. It's asking too much to believe that they would rather lose an important diamond ring than an unimportant ring with a four-generation background of nostalgia.
LEAD: ALL seemed wrong with the world, and that was as it should have been on Friday afternoon as I waited on the checkout line at the supermarket.

LEAD: LOOKING UP from a corned beef and pastrami on rye, a weary traveler on Interstate 95 sees the Manhattan skyline; Broadway show tunes are in the air. The skyline is painted on the window and the tunes come from stereo speakers - but it's not bad for St. Pauls, N.C.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IN Moodus, they call her the Earthquake Lady. Each time the ground moves, the windows of Cathy Wilson's house rattle and the stereo speakers that hang on the wall shake. At times, loud thumps send ripples through her water bed, waking her at all hours of the night. And sometimes, rumbling jackhammer-like noises from below send her 20 cats scattering in every direction.

LEAD: ORDERING from the menu at the Coyote Cafe & Saloon in South Norwalk is a little like treading gingerly through the Mojave Desert, trying to avoid mistakes and emerge with your taste buds intact.

LEAD: The look is easily identifiable: Navajo blankets and beautifully handcrafted clay pots, rough-hewn furniture and cactus plants. Indeed, Western artifacts are as much a part of the American design culture as Shaker or Colonial objects. But rather than creating a total down-home environment, those who embrace this Western esthetic today tend to happily transplant elements of it in relatively small doses, placing just a few objects in modern settings.

LEAD: THE clash over the nomination of William C. Lucas as the Justice Department's top civil rights enforcer was an intriguing display of racial politics in which the battle lines were anything but straight.

LEAD: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Myung Hee Kang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ho Ryun Kang of Lakewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Albert Huneke, the son of Mrs. Carl Strand and Albert Huneke, both of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Judith T. Baumer performed the ceremony.
LEAD: The countdown is on for the first flight of the space shuttle Columbia in three and a half years, to release a military reconnaissance satellite and a smaller scientific payload.

LEAD: At 12:06 this morning, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley announced to the chamber that it had given its final approval to President Bush's $166 billion rescue of the savings and loan industry, two hours after the Senate took similar action.

LEAD: IT should be the centerpiece of a 19th-century New England mill town, a long, low, brick mill building surrounded by tenements. But Joseph Loth's silk factory, completed in 1886, is not in Massachusetts or New Hampshire. It is on the west side of Amsterdam Avenue between 150th and 151st Streets.

LEAD: Nearly a month after an incident in which an Afghan guerrilla group is said to have killed 30 members of a rival faction in an Afghan mountain gorge, the Muslim fundamentalist leader accused of ultimate responsibility for the killings denied today that he played any role.

LEAD: THERE was a time, not too long ago, that I could see everything. I could thread any needle, dial the telephone without squinting, read the Playbill in a darkened theater and study the minuscule list of ingredients in all the things I shouldn't have been eating in the first place.

LEAD: The struggling Baltimore Orioles suffered a setback yesterday when their slugging catcher, Mickey Tettleton, was placed on the 15-day disabled list. Tettleton, who had 22 home runs this season, will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow to repair torn cartilage in his left knee and will be out at least three weeks, the club announced.

LEAD: THIS is the way I remember the pledge to the flag as we used to give it in school. We fifth graders would stand up and face the flag. Right hand over heart we'd begin: ''I pledge allegiance to the flag...'' At that point we'd fling out the right arm, palm up, and continue, ''...of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

LEAD: The Samuel trade is emblematic of the front office's inability to properly assess and address team needs. Dykstra and McDowell should have fetched more than the flawed Samuel, who is shaky on defense and not suited to his role as a leadoff hitter. RICHARD J. BRENNER Syosset, L.I.

LEAD: QUIDDITIES: An Intermittently Philosophical Dictionary, by W. V. Quine. (Belknap/Harvard University, $9.95.) Beginning with ''Alphabet'' and ending with ''Zero,'' one of the century's great logicians writes miniature essays on ''Atoms,'' ''Etymology,'' ''Fermat's Last Theorem,'' ''Redundancy,'' ''Rhetoric'' and other favorite themes.

LEAD: Food companies like Geo. A. Hormel & Company and ConAgra Inc. have been processing farm-raised fish for years. But few have been eager to farm fish because it is riskier and more capital intensive than processing. Over the years, Coca-Cola, Dow Chemical, Kraft, United Fruit and Weyerhaeuser have all jumped in and out of fish farming.

LEAD: THE Energy Department last week held the first in a series of public hearings aimed at creating a national energy ''strategy'' by December 1990. In many respects, the quest for a strategy was seen a tacit acknowledgement by the Administration that the Energy Department is to have a much bigger role in setting priorities and policies for energy development in the 1990's than it did in the 1980's.

LEAD: EVERY day, the United States adds 60,000 barrels to the Government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a sea of stored crude intended to cushion the effects of a disruption in the flow of imported oil. But even as the reserve grows larger - 22.3 million barrels were added in the last year - the protection it offers shrinks.
LEAD: The article ''2 Towns Warn of Power Demands'' (July 16) is very misleading.

LEAD: THE weak market for homes in New York City's suburbs, where demand and prices have soured, is creating headaches for everyone trying to sell their houses - and migraines for sellers at the middle and high ends of the spectrum - according to economists and real estate brokers.

LEAD: The ball rose toward the afternoon sky today and then dropped quickly into Mel Hall's glove. There was, at that precise moment, a sense that the Yankees were going to crumble again, that their long, hot summer had reached another low.

LEAD: When Frank Viola joined the Mets in their locker room in Busch Stadium, St. Louis, last Tuesday afternoon, he and Ron Darling shook hands and smiled and exchanged pleasantries. But they didn't talk about ''the game.'' They didn't have to; it's been there, in the records and in their memories ever since they pitched in it against each other and made college baseball history.

LEAD: Insofar as erosion on Long Island's South Shore, I say, ''Don't mess with Mother Nature!'' If one looks back, say to the day the Fire Island Lighthouse was built, the water was literally a stone's throw away. There would be no Robert Moses State Park there today if it weren't for erosion. What the sea took away in other places, it gave back on Fire Island.

LEAD: THE Sao Paulo Bienal, the Venice Biennale, the Whitney Biennial and now, at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, ''The Connecticut Biennial.''

LEAD: It was the middle of the night when the screenwriter Jeffrey Boam was summoned from his San Fernando Valley home to a downtown police precinct. It wasn't for parking tickets.
LEAD: Last Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average soared past 2,661, its highest level since the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, 1987.
LEAD: The reclusive octogenarian Victor Paz Estenssoro is to give up the presidency on Sunday after having turned Bolivia back from part of the revolutionary process he started in his middle years.

LEAD: More than 60,000 telephone technicians, installers, operators and repair workers went on strike against the Nynex Corporation last night after contract negotiations broke down over whether emmployees will pay a share of health care costs.

LEAD: Mookie Wilson's departure from the New York Mets last week got scant attention - overshadowed, perhaps, by headlines celebrating the arrival from Minnesota of Frank Viola, a pitcher who's supposed to lift the team from its present doldrums.

LEAD: Mr. Epstein writes that he knows lots of people who have been ''kicked very hard in the stomach by fate. Without denying or attempting to disguise the effects of this devastating kick, they neither whine about it nor protest it.'' Are we to believe that Mr. Epstein has a list of victims who suffer stoically?

LEAD: Toshiki Kaifu, a former minister of education with little background in foreign or economic affairs, was virtually assured today of election as the next Prime Minister of Japan when four of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's five faction leaders endorsed him.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having just returned from a visit to Seville, Cordoba and Granada, I was surprised that you did not mention one of the best ways to visit the cities of Moorish Spain. We took the Andalusian Express, a restored 1920's train, which takes passengers on two-day, overnight trips beginning in Seville and ending in Malaga.
LEAD: ''SHE started the sexual revolution,'' the actress Eileen Heckart declared. The director Melvin Bernhardt added, ''And she has come back because she's needed.''

LEAD: After months of intensive negotiations, the Brady Plan has finally produced the Mexican debt reduction agreement. The accord, however, suffers from serious defects. The package covers the Government's $54 billion in medium- and long-term loans out of the country's $70 billion in total bank debt.

LEAD: Despite a pledge during his Senate confirmation hearings to ''sever'' his ties to his former New York law firm, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. regularly did personal favors for his former colleagues and interceded with subordinates in the Department of Housing and Urban Development on their behalf, documents from his office files show.

LEAD: Ground has been broken for the main office building in the Newport Center project in Jersey City, a $10 billion development that eventually will cover more than 300 acres along the Hudson River waterfront opposite lower Manhattan. The new building, a 37-story stone and granite structure, will contain a million square feet of rentable space.

LEAD: THE number of public one-room schools, schools with one teacher for the first eight grades, has decreased because of population growth and the increased busing of students to central sites. There were nearly 150,000 public one-room schools in 1930; in 1971 there were less than 2,000, and in 1987 about 700.

LEAD: Empire Games Heptathlon Athlete Wins Again: Caryl Senn of Massapequa, L.I., won the Empire State Games open women's heptathlon championship yesterday for the fifth time in eight years and her second successive year. But she failed in her bid for the event's heptathlon record for points, finishing with 4,552.

The Dona Maria Hotel, while desirably situated, has dingy, dark, rather seedy rooms.

As a result the bureaucrats have ordered the rims raised by six inches. This could be a prime example of a well-intentioned reform with devastating side-effects.

LEAD: Casual dress is the mode on stage at Stratford this summer. Hamlet lounges around the castle at Elsinore in his pajamas, as if he had brought the wrong clothes home from Wittenberg. Still wearing pajamas, he sleepwalks through ''To be or not to be,'' redirects the Players and enters Gertrude's bedchamber looking as if it were time for him to retire.

LEAD: Too much of summer remains to sense the kind of urgency Ron Darling faced on that crisp October night in St. Louis nearly four years ago. The season had less than a week to go. The opponent was John Tudor. Darling's contribution was nine memorable scoreless innings that made an important victory possible.

LEAD: FAVIGNANA, Levanzo and Marettimo, as the three small islands that make up the Egadi archipelago are called, lie just off the western coast of Sicily, opposite the port of Trapani. Each island has steep and stony coastlines, a few scattered farms and one small town whose inhabitants have lived - for thousands of years - by quarrying the rock beneath them and harvesting the waters around them.

LEAD: CARL DUDASH spends months researching, designing and building each harpsichord he makes in his Norfolk studio. But it is when he sits down at the keyboard to play that his face lights up, especially if the listener has never heard a fine harpsichord.

LEAD: Buoyed by agreements with its domestic political opponents, the Government of Nicaragua comes to a Central American meeting this weekend to press for the immediate demobilization of anti-Government rebels in Honduras.
LEAD: The equation, art plus government equals controversy is just as true today as it was in 1907 when Augustus Saint-Gaudens sought to redesign the $20 gold piece.

LEAD: Opening a novel rift in the Warsaw Pact, Hungary has said it will consider granting political asylum to some East Germans, effectively assisting them in their flight from another Communist nation.

LEAD: EVERY NOW AND THEN I come across articles in magazines or letters to the editor describing the problems that older people have with their spare time at retirement. LEAD: Iran and a pro-Iranian group in Lebanon today rebuffed overtures from the United States and Israel aimed at arranging the release of hostages, but Administration officials said the setback did not foreclose further diplomatic efforts.

This condition makes me a victim as well, or, to use terminology fashionable in therapy chat, co-dependently addicted to guilt, and a survivor, eligible for a blame-support group.

LEAD: LAST year I turned 50, and it didn't bother me a bit. I was in great shape. I weighed 20 pounds less than when I got married 23 years before. I had no gray hair, and from the front only a dignified receding at the temples was visible, suggesting, if anything, accumulating wisdom. It was fun assuring friends that indeed I was 50, and hearing ''You sure don't look it,'' and ''I never would have guessed.

LEAD: When you hear the words ''Leica camera,'' what adjectives spring to mind? My list runs as follows: indestructible, mechanical, professional, expensive. Photojournalists who have to take pictures on the run might add ''indispensable.'' Of course, we would all be thinking of M series Leicas, rangefinder cameras with interchangeable lenses and the durability of wrought iron.

The wedding took place at the home of the bride's parents in Old Black Point. Joseph G. Lynch, a justice of the peace and a retired judge of the Probate Court in Portland,
LEAD: Workers at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg, Pa., have found two marks that could be cracks in the bottom of the reactor vessel.

LEAD: A front-page chart on July 30 about Americans who have no health insurance contained several errors. A corrected version appears today on Page 26.

LEAD: ONE OF THE MOST worrisome reports a pediatrician can hear from a parent is that a child has lost all interest in favorite toys. A child who can no longer take pleasure in playing may be signaling a psychiatric emergency. Though the pediatrician may not be formally trained in child psychology, such emergencies must always be as much a concern as medical problems.

LEAD: IT is always sad to lose a friend, one that you have known and admired for many decades. My dear departed friend was the Underhill Oak, a red oak, the largest and oldest in Yonkers. This arboreal giant stood 115 feet tall and had dominated the landscape near the foot of Underhill Street for at least 350 years.
LEAD: A RENTAL complex in this incorporated ''city within a city'' in Denver is trying to attract single parents and small families by offering child-care and self-help money-saving services.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Usually, a top draft pick by a National Basketball Association team can start counting the money. Last week, Danny Ferry, the Duke basketball star who was the second player picked in the league's June draft, began counting his money, in lire. The 6-foot-11-inch forward passed up a chance to play for the Los Angeles Clippers and signed a reported one-year, $1 million contract to play for the Messaggero Roma team in the Italian professional league.
LEAD: ''I don't want that. What's that? It's a complete game.

LEAD: WHAT do Americans worry about most? According to a recent Gallup Poll, many of us replied fat was the most troubling issue in our lives. Fat, we said, caused us more anxiety than Muammar el Qaddafi, racism, pesticides, nuclear warheads, sexually transmitted diseases, drugs and even the prime rate.
LEAD: History was made this afternoon at the Hambletonian, the most prestigious event in harness racing, when the raceoff, the deciding race to determine a winner, was declared a dead heat.
LEAD: It is implied in your article that the only problem that the V.A. at Northport has is one of lack of funds. This is not so!

LEAD: FACT: The General Electric Foundation has committed $20 million over the next decade to help inner-city schools. Its goal: Double the number of college-bound youngsters from every school it goes into.

LEAD: THE sculpture festival at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island is a lot more than the sum of its contents, which at last count was 42 works (excluding drawings) by 23 artists. Roughly half of the sculptures are deployed over a substantial portion of the estate's 80 acres; the remainder are in the complex's Main Hall, known as the Newhouse Center for Contemporary

LEAD: Natalie duPont Edmonds and Peter Andrew Fair were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Raymond Webster officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Edmonds Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and Osterville. Mr. Fair is a son of Mrs. Frederick Maul Fair of New York and Mountain Top, Pa., and the late Mr.

LEAD: A 2-year-old boy was shot once in the head late yesterday morning as he was walking down the street with his mother in Douglaston, Queens, the police said. He was in critical condition at Long Island Jewish Hospital last night. The mother and son were walking down Horace Harding Boulevard and Marathon Parkway around 11 A.M.

LEAD: THE fastest-growing intercollegiate sports for women are soccer and cross-country. Soccer, offered for women in 3 percent of schools in 1977, has grown to 38 percent in 1988. Cross-country was available in less than a third of the schools and is presently represented in more than 80 percent.
LEAD: Your article on the veteran's hospital (''Veterans Hospital Faces Change,'' July 16) left a lot of unanswered questions.

LEAD: The perjury indictment Friday of a former mayoral aide who ran the Talent Bank for Mayor Edward I. Koch has made patronage - the doling out of city jobs to political allies and people they recommend - the latest hot issue in the campaign for mayor of New York.

LEAD: Here in the Maine woods just west of Lewiston is a little summer youth camp on the shore of Worthley Pond where the campers say they like the food and spend their mornings discussing global politics.

LEAD: Cheryl Lynne Range, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Range of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., and David Robert Scheidemantle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Scheidemantle of Nanuet, N.Y. were married yesterday at the Neighborhood Church in Palos Verdes Estates. The Rev. Karl A. Johnson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: ABOUT half the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-A has been been penalized for breaking N.C.A.A. rules at least once since 1980. Division 1-A is the N.C.A.A.'s most visible competitive level, comprising 106 colleges and universities with big-time football programs. Most violations have occurred in basketball and football programs.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about the playwright Rupert Holmes included an erroneous quotation. Mr. Holmes said his aim in ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'' had been to ''make fun'' what had been a ''dark and somber book.'' He did not say he intended to make fun of the Dickens work.

LEAD: Ted has been in New York on business and his colleagues in Texas want to know how things are going. They can call or write or send a facsimile or electronic mail to him. But what they really need to be able to do is hold a conference with him, because the spontaneous exchange of information among executives is often the spark that leads to important decisions.

LEAD: In the ninth inning Friday night, as the crowd inside the Skydome rose slowly to acknowledge Dave Stieb's big moment, one Yankee pitcher turned toward a teammate and asked if he had ever witnessed a no-hitter.

LEAD: Paolo Baffi, the former governor of Italy's central bank, died on Friday night after a long illness, the bank announced today. He was 77 years old. The bank did not disclose the illness. Mr. Baffi, one of the major economic figures in postwar Italy, worked for 40 years with the Bank of Italy, the country's central bank.

LEAD: A REVOLUTION of rising expectations among parents and students has come to America's college and university campuses. With the cost of a year at the most expensive and selective schools now having cracked the $20,000 barrier, parents are raising their sights about what to expect in return.

LEAD: Where and when do differences between men and women begin - the ones that result in aptitude-test disparities and battles over relative ability in the sciences and verbal fields? Some researchers speculate that there are actual neurological distinctions between the sexes at birth, ranging from the anatomical to the biochemical.

LEAD: WHILE Joseph D. Monticciolo was administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development's New York regional office from 1981 to 1988, he frequently supported charity fund-raisers given in his honor. On the surface it sounds worthy.

LEAD: WHEN Marian Anderson received the $10,000 Philadelphia Award in the 1950's, she used the money to set up scholardhips for young singers. ''If some of these people have gone out and brought pleasure and satisfaction to publics of their own and if the scholarship helped them climb another rung on the way to their goal, I feel that the people who have listened to me ofer the years deserve the credit,'' she wrote in her autobiography.

LEAD: A REAL-ESTATE concern acting on behalf of the Penobscot Indian Nation has applied for a permit to subdivide 2,100 acres of rolling hills and lakeshore in this barely developed town a couple of miles south of Springfield in northeastern Maine.

LEAD: A judge has upheld a law that allows West Virginia to revoke the driver's licenses of school dropouds, Judge Paul Zakaib of Kanawha County Circuit Court said Friday that the law, a model for proposed Federal legislation, is based on an interest in keeping teen-agers in school, ''is not unreasonable and withstands any constitutional challenge.

LEAD: For a guy who's supposedly retired, Carl Yastrzemski has been having lot of trouble getting in any fishing this summer. First there was his induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y., two weeks ago. Now it's his old team, the Boston Red Sox, which has called Yastrzemski back from a fishing vacation in

LEAD: This is a corrected version of a chart that appeared July 30 with an article about people in the United States who lack health insurance. This chart shows people under age 65 without health insurance, by family income. Population figures are in millions Source: Employee Benefit Research Institute.

LEAD: GOING from part-time shipping clerk to president takes a little more than luck, yet Ralph Frickel, the 34-year-old president of Benfield Electric International here, said he believes that simply being in the right place at the right time played an important part in his career.

LEAD: The recent article ''Schools and Asbestos: Law Posing Problems'' correctly delineates several challenges facing those confronting asbestos problems in schools, or other buildings in which they live, work, shop or learn. In fact, the requirements under the Asbestos Hazard Emergency Response Act may soon be expanded in New

LEAD: SOMEHOW cabbage soup tastes more savory from a bowl in the shape of a giant cabbage leaf, and honey sweeter from a honeybee pot. And the table will look more festive if the braised duck and rice is served in a duck tureen.

LEAD: THE United States House of Representatives has approved a measure that will temporarily block construction of a Postal Service General Facility on land adjacent to the Westchester County Airport.

LEAD: The Government reported today that about 20 people were killed and more than 1,200 injured in accidents involving radioactive materials in China between 1980 and 1985. The disclosure, in the official China Daily, gave no details and did not indicate whether there had been further injuries or fatalities in the last few years.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TALENT. By Howard and Susan Kaminsky. (Bantam, $18.95.) The authors of this irritating novel are publishing veterans - he's the president of the Hearst Trade Book Group, she's a former editor - so presumably they know something about the world of talent agencies, which forms the backdrop for their breathless account of the glitzy activities of New York and Hollywood deal makers.

LEAD: The Giants and the Jets drew a crowd of 8,500, at $6 a head, to watch the National Football League teams scrimmage at Lehigh University's year-old Murray H. Goodman Stadium today. Actually, it was a glorified practice. It started with 96 plays of 7-on-7 passing drills at one end of the field and 1-on-1 pass-blocking drills at the other.

Gottlieb of New York and Rye, N.Y., and the late Robert P. Gottlieb. Rabbi Mark L.

LEAD: TO the ancients, they were the islands of wind and fire. The Greek god Aeolus kept his winds imprisoned in a cave in the archipelago that takes his name, and flames leaping from the chain's volcanoes both terrified and guided Mycenaean, Greek and Roman mariners sailing the southeastern Tyrrhenian at night.

LEAD: Easy Goer's enormous talent took on an added dimension today when the 3-year-old colt overcame real trouble for the first time in his career and went on to score a stirring 4 1/2-length victory over older horses in the $287,500 Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.

LEAD: A singular family double was in the cards today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Pam Wittes of Los Alamitos, Calif., won one of the two major knockout team titles here Friday, and her husband, Jon, is in the final of another today.

LEAD: Additional titles of interest: ALL GOD'S CRITTERS GOT A PLACE IN THE CHOIR. Words and music by Bill Staines. Illustrated by Margot Zemach. E.P. Dutton. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 7) A witty and distinctive illustrator has set the words of a popular folk song in a rural, prairie Eden. Children and animals gather round a plain farmhouse in a choir where ''some sing low, some sing higher.

LEAD: While Dykstra and Roger McDowell have truly flourished with Philadelphia, the most Samuel has done is to adopt the now familiar phlegmatic attitude and performing ability of the Mets. Not exactly the spark we were all promised, huh? RITU B. SHARMA Massapequa, L.I.

LEAD: A United States Air Force captain who is under investigation on espionage allegations had access to codes used for Air Force communications at a vital intelligence post in West Berlin, military officials said today.

LEAD: IN ITS HEYDAY, THE ENGLE clock traveled the Eastern Seaboard, drawing the curious like a sideshow. Built over 20 years by a Pennsylvanian named Stephen Engle, the clock - 11 feet tall, with 48 moving figures, two organ movements that play at regular intervals and a tellurian, which maps the moon and stars -was completed in 1877.
LEAD: AN INVISIBLE SPECTATOR A Biography of Paul Bowles. By Christopher Sawyer-Laucanno. Illustrated. 501 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $24.95.

LEAD: Until 10 years ago, the fatalities in post-World War II sailboat races could be counted on four or five hands. Occasionally, a sailor might fall overboard and drown, and a boat would disappear with all hands. Never was it said that sailing was as predictably risky as mountain climbing or powerboat racing.

LEAD: For This Week: Divide overgrown clumps of bearded iris and replant firm rhizomes in groups of three; discard rhizomes that are old or rotted. Mail orders for bulbs that will be planted in fall. Cut to the ground stalks of perennials that bloomed. Prune hedges, especially privet, hemlock, yew. Last call to sow biennial seed outdoors in nursery beds.

LEAD: FOR the 15 years that I lived abroad as a foreign correspondent, I don't think I missed too much of American culture, at least not much highbrow or middlebrow stuff. Books and magazines were sent to me, and I saw many of the movies and plays I wanted to see during visits home or to London. During the last few years I had access to videos.

LEAD: In the current brief respite from hostage-killing, President Bush may have an opportunity to arrange a swap of all hostages, and perhaps even to reach an understanding of sorts with states sponsoring terrorism.

LEAD: The article by Senator Donald DiFrancesco and Assemblywoman Maureen Ogden, ''Needed: Workers' Leave'' (Opinion page, July 2), is splendid. It makes secure the position of the competent worker who relies on his or her job to take care of family units when it becomes necessary.

LEAD: Three recent books, handsomely produced and well illustrated, are each a good browse. The first is ''The Guinness Book of Stamps,'' part of the Guinness Superlatives series. Herein are found the biggest stamp and the smallest, the fastest delivery and the slowest, and a wealth of information on how and why stamps are produced.

LEAD: Some residents of West 62d Street are annoyed by the floating address of a new apartment house in their neighborhood and are suing to try to anchor the number before it causes more confusion among people doing business in or visiting the area.

LEAD: I can inform Joseph Epstein that there is nothing wrong with the conscience-and-guilt appeal in battling racism. The civil-rights movement grasped in its early years - in the budding days of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People - that conscience and guilt are two sides of the same moral coin, and that any society claiming to be civilized must wrestle with both conscience and guilt when rectifying the wounds it creates.

LEAD: To the Editor: Speaking of airport parking (Travel Advisory, June 25), some city agency should look into the parking fees at the city's airports. Short-term parking costs $1 an hour; fair enough. However, the minimum charge is $4. How often have you spent four hours at the airport meeting a friend or seeing someone off?

LEAD: The hottest political topic in Yugoslavia is Slobodan Milosevic - what he has done and, even more, what he might do next.

LEAD: This is the time of year when no news is the expected news from the Metropolitan Opera. It's the summer doldrums, with the theater turned over to ballet rentals, the solo artists off traipsing the festival circuit, and everyone else enjoying a bit of blessed vacation relief.

LEAD: A 176-acre student-run farm at Penn State University on which students had previously earned money has been shifted to university control, and some students as well as agriculture-college faculty and staff members are upset about it.

LEAD: Scarlett O'Hara, weeping at the bottom of her grand, gauche staircase, vows, ''I'll find a way to get him back. After all, tomorrow is another day!'' Margaret Mitchell's brilliant open ending has kept audiences arguing about Scarlett's resourcefulness for more than 50 years. But if ''Gone With the Wind'' had first appeared in the sequel-mad summer of 1989, Scarlett's famous final line would hold the sure promise of ''Gone With the Wind II.

LEAD: Each time an airplane is about to leave the airspace of one European country for that of another, an air traffic controller must usually make a time-consuming phone call to a foreign colleague who notes the information with pencil and paper. LEAD: Meeting the health costs of AIDS will not be easy. But health insurance companies are making a cruel situation worse by insisting on the right to test applicants for health insurance and, in some cases, by restricting coverage for the disease. The cost of AIDS is large and growing, but is still a very small part of the national health bill.

LEAD: FOR American banks, whose stock prices have long suffered because of their heavy lending to Latin American countries, the Mexican debt accord of late July was a reminder that the troubled loans can be worked out without cataclysm, but not without sacrifice.

LEAD: Five Central American Presidents ended their meeting in Honduras yesterday with a workable plan for demobilizing the contras and ending civil war in Nicaragua. They called for disbanding rebel camps in southern Honduras by Dec. 8. This would be 90 days after the stationing of international monitors in the jungles to oversee compliance and deter cross-border raiding.
LEAD: A hot-air balloon that crashed and killed its pilot was leaking before takeoff in a national competition, a Federal investigator said today.

LEAD: Theodate H. Soule, director of social services at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center from 1938 to 1962, died on July 24 at Pennswood Village in Newtown, Pa., where she lived. She was 93 years old.

LEAD: MANAGEMENT proposals to shift some health-care expenses to employees have emerged as important sticking points in the stalled contract negotiations that prompted strikes at three regional telephone companies last weekend.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The immensely expensive legislation that President Bush is expected to sign this week to rescue the savings industry will ultimately affect the pocketbooks and convenience of millions of American consumers. LEAD: THE ECONOMY A fundamental remaking of the savings industry was quickly set in motion as President Bush signed legislation intended to end years of staggering losses. Mr. Bush expressed pride in the bill passed by Congress early Saturday, saying it would ''put in place permanent reforms.'' LEAD: Mencken! Thou should'st be living at this hour. (With apologies to W. Wordsworth.) Through the 1920's and 30's H. L. Mencken savaged the follies of American life. His special targets were the narrow minds, the intolerant certainties of what he called ''the booboisie.'' He reveled scornfully in the trial of John Scopes for teaching evolution, describing the onlookers - who believed that God literally created the world in six days - as ''gaping primates.

LEAD: Mary Sue Davis wants to have a baby. But since 1979, when she married Junior Lewis Davis, she has suffered several ectopic pregnancies, a ruptured fallopian tube and the tying off of the second. She and Mr. Davis have participated in an in vitro fertilization program too, but the implantation of two out of nine fertilized eggs was unsuccessful.
