LEAD: Charging that South Africa is interfering in the preparations for Namibian independence, the South-West Africa People's Organization, the territory's leading nationalist movement, warned today that it might not accept the results of Namibia's first free elections.

LEAD: A man wanted in the death of a television writer was arrested in New York City Wednesday night on an unrelated drug charge, the police said today. The man, John Doherty, 27 years old, of Jersey City, is charged with felony murder and first-degree robbery in the death of the writer, Robert Stevens, 68 years old, of New York City, who was robbed and beaten early Monday in a Westport home he had rented, the police said.

LEAD: The National Labor Relations Council yesterday rejected a request by many of New York City's private hospitals seeking to block the state's largest hospital workers union from mounting a three-day strike starting Monday.

LEAD: The interpreter for a Chinese acrobatic troupe who left the group a day after four of the troupe's performers disappeared, emerged yesterday to say that she wanted to return home and had not sought political asylum in the United States.

LEAD: Three former South Carolina assistant football coaches were sentenced today for their convictions stemming from the use and distribution of steroids within the athletic department. Their sentences ranged from three months to six months in a halfway house.

Baltimore won the second game, 4-1, behind a three-hitter by Pete Harnisch, his first complete game ever.

Foley, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Foley of Durham, N.C. Judge Brooke A. Peterson of the Municipal Court in Aspen performed the ceremony at the couple's home.

LEAD: Ponce de Leon was looking in the wrong place. The Fountain of Youth is at Kemper Lakes Golf Course, just northwest of Chicago, where the 71st P.G.A. Championship is in progress.

LEAD: The United States has slightly fewer farms this year than in 1988, but they are slightly larger than they were last year. The decline continues a slide that began in 1982, when there were 2.4 million farms.

He will serve on the search committee for a successor, he said, and will remain in his post until a ''qualified successor can be engaged.

LEAD: From a rebel bunker on Samarkhel Mountain, the ancient city of Jalalabad is visible eight miles away, a sprawl of mud-walled homes shimmering beneath a canopy of flame trees that stretch to the horizon. But a line of the Government's Soviet-built tanks sits in the plateau between the city and the rebels, their barrels trained on the enemy's redoubts.

LEAD: In his 49 years at Grambling University, Eddie Robinson has served as coach in basketball, baseball and football and as athletic director. Now he will take on another assignment at the school in Louisiana, vice president for athletic relations. Joseph Johnson, the university president, said Robinson had requested the move.

LEAD: The Xoma Corporation, a biotechnology company in Berkeley, Calif., agreed to acquire International Genetic Engineering Inc., more commonly known as Ingene. Each of Ingene's 7.9 million shares would be exchanged for 0.278 shares of Xoma stock, giving the transaction a value of about $40 million. Xoma specializes in monoclonal antibody technology and has applied for permission to market two drugs: one for treatment of septic shock received from hospital infections and the other for graft-versus-host disease, which strikes recipients of bone marrow transplants.
LEAD: A Federal judge today allowed the police to continue using painful methods in the arrest of anti-abortion protesters.

LEAD: Now is the season for fresh local sweet corn. Yellow, white and a mix of yellow and white are available. Buy corn that has been picked the same day because the longer an ear of corn is off the stalk, the less sweet it will be; the sugar starts turning to starch as soon as it is picked. Very fresh corn will have a dewy moistness about the husk and silk, and the stem will not be brown.

LEAD: Mack Lobell, the harness horse of the year in 1987 and 1988, is the overwhelming favorite in a field of eight in the $350,000 International Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

LEAD: There is not much time for sadness at Gaylord Hospital. Each of the 121 men and women being treated at this medical rehabilitation center has survived a traumatic event: a stroke, a car accident, a fall, a shooting or, in the case of one patient, the Central Park jogger, rape and a beating. Now they must somehow rebuild their lives.

LEAD: Having completed a weekend of Beethoven lectures and performances to close the final Summerfare Festival in Purchase, N.Y., Roger Norrington brought his London Classical Players to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening for an all-Beethoven concert that was part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.

LEAD: Jack W. Schuler, the president and chief operating officer of Abbott Laboratories, resigned yesterday over ''differences in philosophy'' with Robert A. Schoellhorn, Abbott's chairman and chief executive, a spokesman for the $5 billion diversified health-care concern said.

LEAD: Gord Stellick, who at 32 became the youngest general manager in National Hockey League history when he was appointed in April 1988, announced his resignation from the Toronto Maple Leafs yesterday. At a news conference in Toronto, Stellick cited interference from Harold Ballard, the 86-year-old owner.
LEAD: A new kind of life insurance, which pays part of the death benefits while the policy holder is still alive, is attracting attention these days.

LEAD: Michael Cohen, scientific director of Applied Medical Research Ltd., a start-up company in Washington, patented a proposed oral contraceptive this week that the company believes could replace current birth control pills.

LEAD: Two days after taking office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu became momentarily entangled today in a report that he had fathered a child outside marriage. But he later appeared to free himself of the rumors and avoid a sex scandal like the one that dogged his predecessor.

LEAD: Airlines are starting to fly a new generation of highly automated jets, raising concerns among safety researchers that pilots will rely too much on the technology and will lose or never learn the sharp skills and reflexes needed in emergencies.

LEAD: Videocassette recorders started smoking, light bulbs exploded and ceiling fans raced as if they were going into orbit when a power company mistakenly doubled the normal amount of electricity in 30 houses.

LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday told the Federal judge overseeing its bankruptcy that it was nearing an agreement that would allow it to satisfy the demands of its creditors and equity holders.

The first test flight, on July 17, was a success, but the House voted the next week to order a reduction of the 132-plane program. The Senate approved most of the request for the bomber but also passed a resolution saying it was not committed to the fleet now planned.

LEAD: Its name is Camp Pioneer, but it might be more aptly called Nature 101.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: HORTENSE IS ABDUCTED. By Jacques Roubaud. Translated by Dominic Di Bernardi. (Dalkey Archive, $19.95.) A dark Parisian night, an eerie mansion, midnight bells. A shot rings out and a life ends. A conventional detective story? No, no, a significant 37 times no. Although ''Hortense Is Abducted'' is a mystery with a plot literally as intricate as a sestina, its real fascination lies in Jacques Roubaud's conversational asides, inside jokes and self-referential word play.

LEAD: Ten years after gleaming silver trains started rolling on the South's first rapid-transit system, a quarter of a million passengers a day travel on a 1,582-mile network of 150 bus routes and two rail lines with 29 stations.

LEAD: IT was a peaceful Sunday morning in the Alsatian town of Barr. A fine rain was falling on the vineyards covering the long slope down to the Rhine. Trains, cars, river boats and planes, incessant traffic, passed in the misty distance.

LEAD: JOAN POUNDS of Wilton, the former owner and director of the Hamilton School, used to snap pictures of her nursery school and kindergarten students and give them to parents at Christmas time. In the six years since she sold the school, Mrs. Pounds has turned what had been a public relations gesture into a full-time career as an award-winning children's portrait photographer.

LEAD: A LITTLE-KNOWN New Jersey opera company is playing an active role in an international debate to lower the reference pitch by which orchestras tune their instruments. The issue is that the reference pitch, the tone A, has gradually risen over the last 200 years and the consequences may be severe for performers and instruments.

LEAD: Last month I had a chance to test my action-stopping prowess at a day-long gathering of mountain bikers. The activities involved such odd diversions as pulling a sled loaded with cement blocks and attempting to pedal through a bog without dismounting. But my personal favorite, in photographic terms, was a time-trial circuit that featured a mud-puddle finale.

LEAD: Stock prices surged but the best-known indicator, the Dow Jones industrial average, could not quite make a daily close above its all-time high. Other indexes, like the Standard & Poor's 500, reached record levels in late July. At times last week, the Dow did trade above the peak of 2,722.42 it set on Aug.

LEAD: Q. My house is 3 years old with a walk-out basement, which is unheated. There is a worsening problem of efflorescence on the outside of the concrete basement walls. Can you suggest a solution to this problem?

LEAD: The judge's request was not what you would expect to hear at a beauty pageant. ''Let me see your teeth,'' he said to the seven lovely contestants seated before him. They dutifully offered their smiles. He checked their incisors. When you are six years old and a reigning beauty queen, you cannot wait for Christmas for those two front teeth.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Something weird was happening to the Suspension Bridge that connects Cincinnati to Covington, Ky., and is close by Riverfront Stadium. I was told this last January by a Cincinnati cabdriver on the way to the Bengals' conference championship game against the Buffalo Bills.

LEAD: Breeding populations of ducks in prime nesting areas of this country and Canada were at near-record lows this spring, and the Fish and Wildlife Service's proposed regulations for the forthcoming 1989-90 waterfowl seasons are much the same as last year's regulations, which included fewer days in which to hunt and lower bag limits.

LEAD: Kids can be kids this season without looking like their parents or oversized dolls. As the designer interest in children's wear grows, so do the options for stylish young customers. They can play it straight with modern classics, romantic with retro looks, cavalier with casual separates. Cute's out.

LEAD: In response to the Opinion page articles entitled ''Ending Required Gym: 2 Views'' (July 9): I believe that both views presented missed the point. Has economics become the yardstick by which we measure whether we cancel gym class? If so, our children and our future may be in serious trouble.

LEAD: Anne Maura O'Connor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. O'Connor of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter McCargo Standish Jr., a son of Mr. Standish of Sewickley, Pa., and the late Carolyn R. Standish. The Rev. James Halligan officiated at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: PALLADIO himself could not have designed a better view of the subtle symmetry of his 16th-century Villa La Rotonda than from a four-seater plane high in the sky above the province of Vicenza in northeastern Italy. La Rotonda, the architect's most celebrated building, appears as a giant crab grasping its Berici hillock at its highest and most logical point.

LEAD: When a name becomes music, the results can be intriguing. Marcel Landowski's name can be found in all reference works devoted to 20th-century French music, but seldom in programs outside France.
LEAD: Attempts by Iranian researchers to buy poison-producing strains of fungus from Canada and the Netherlands have been disclosed for the first time by Western intelligence officials.

GORBACHEV'S STRUGGLE FOR ECONOMIC REFORM The Soviet Reform Process, 1985-88. By Anders Aslund. 219 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press.
LEAD: No one could say we were not forewarned. There were highway signs aplenty warning, ''The Timber Wolf is out to get you.'' It did.
LEAD: A weeks-long hunger strike by hundreds of inmates, and the death of two of them last week, have rekindled longstanding complaints about human-rights abuses in Turkish prisons.

LEAD: The death of Bob Marley in 1981 was a great equalizing event in reggae. His music, a mixture of bass-heavy rhythms, lovely and lilting melodies and often overt political messages presented a monolithic vision of Jamaican culture to the world.

LEAD: Thirty-two American composers have received commissions this year from the Meet the Composer/Reader's Digest Commissioning Program, which has given $429,500 to 19 consortia comprising 52 symphony and chamber orchestras, opera and theater companies, choruses, soloists, public radio stations and other musical ensembles.

LEAD: Three years ago, as he was working on the novel ''The General in His Labyrinth,'' Gabriel Garcia Marquez found himself with extra time on his hands. Every morning he would sit down at his word processor to write, and at night he pored through letters, books and documents about Simon Bolivar, the Great Liberator of Latin America who is the central figure of the book.

LEAD: One day last week, James R. DeVita was at it again. In the fifth week of Leona M. Helmsley's trial, the chief prosecutor was arguing a legal point with his usual stubbornness. He seemed immune to broad hints that Judge John M. Walker Jr. was growing short on patience.

LEAD: Tension is running high at the Chicago futures exchanges. So far, 46 traders have been charged with trading practices that the Federal Government says systematically robbed the trading public on a major scale. More indictments are expected. But in the midst of the turmoil, it is important not to lose sight of another crucial and more important challenge facing the Chicago exchanges - competing with foreign markets There is a major battle looming over who will control the international 24-hour market for futures and options contracts.

LEAD: I SPENT most of my first year in New Haven being pregnant. It was a full-time job, with doctor and midwife visits, queasiness and food labels that need to be scrutinized for potentially harmful ingredients. During eight and a quarter months I looked forward to my second year in New Haven.

LEAD: IN EXTREMIS: And Other Alaskan Stories. By Jean Anderson. (Plover/Talman, $16.95.) The Alaska of Jean Anderson's first collection of short stories is a magical place whose remoteness and harshness make its inhabitants' emotions and relationships stand out in great relief. Many of the characters in ''In Extremis'' discover this truth only after having fled other, seemingly more complicated lives in states such as Texas or California, Ohio or Michigan.
LEAD: The Jets opened their exhibition season with a 28-27 loss to the Green Bay Packers today, but the outcome was not as important as how Tim Cofield played the game.
LEAD: WITH style, energy and instruments that include the gankogui and the atsimevu, a group called Talking Drums is bringing authentic West African music and dance to auditoriums and classrooms.

LEAD: I GAINED notoriety overnight after contracting Lyme disease. Suddenly thrust into the limelight, I was a star. I was famous the moment I walked out of the examining room. ''Oh, so you have the dreaded disease,'' a secretary at the doctor's office said when she read the diagnosis.

LEAD: The country's most influential Shiite Muslim cleric said today that the hostage issue would ''move in the direction of a rational solution.'' But he warned that it could take a long time and that any American military move would backfire.

LEAD: IN A SPANKING NEW GYM IN VAN NUYS, Calif., Michael Nunn, the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion, is working the heavy bag. A left-handed fighter, Nunn sets, plants and throws the big hook, then skips back nimbly to repeat it from a different angle. With each punch, his eyes light up, the brows arching, much in the manner of Muhammad Ali, to whose legendary ring style his own is often compared.

LEAD: Scores of people have been killed in a wave of ethnic fighting sweeping parts of the northeastern state of Assam, and the fighting has sent thousands of people fleeing into refugee camps and into a neighboring state, The Press Trust of India news agency reported tonight.

LEAD: When officials at Universal Studios heard that the Walt Disney Company had ordered three day care centers here to destroy unauthorized murals of Mickey Mouse and his pals, they were ecstatic.

LEAD: As a collectible, the fish decoy has surfaced. Then, on July 9 at the Oliver auction house in Kennebunk, Me., a rare New York piece by an anonymous carver set a world auction record for a fish decoy of $6,600.

It is Mozart's music in juxtaposition with Mozart's age that makes us gasp.

LEAD: Toni Silver loves to travel. Two years ago she went to Asia, visiting Korea, Singapore, Thailand, Nepal and Bali. She loved the Balinese people, their culture, their food. She stayed two months and she now believes she may have found her life work.

LEAD: THE FRONTIER OF LOYALTY: Political Exiles in the Age of the Nation-State. By Yossi Shain. (Wesleyan University, $25.95.) Political exiles are, arguably, the most passionately committed of all political dissidents. Unlike members of a ''loyal opposition'' seeking political reform from within a nation's borders, or refugees who attempt to create a new life in a new country, political exiles are suspended in a kind of ideological limbo.

The other explosions damaged buildings but caused no casualties. The police said they had not determined who had carried out the attacks.

LEAD: With Roman Catholic-Jewish relations already strained by the continued presence of a Carmelite convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp, a Jewish organization has complained that recent comments by Pope John Paul II suggested that God's covenant with the Jewish people had been superseded.

LEAD: Late this month the first of 30 low-income families will move into a renovated apartment house at 1427 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. The building is a joint project of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the nonprofit Flatbush Development Corporation and the private Affordable Dwelling Units Inc.

LEAD: THE struggle over the last remnants of the ancient virgin forests of the Northwest is the latest battle in a fierce centurylong contest for control of the nation's publicly owned woodlands.

LEAD: New productions of ''Die Meistersinger'' remain scarce even in a time when radically rethought stagings of Wagner's most formidable music drama, the ''Ring,'' no longer qualify as rarities. A comedy on a distinctly Wagnerian scale, it deals at marathon length in heavyweight, Breughel-like humor. The work consumes more than five hours of an audience's time and can strain the resources of any opera company.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. James F. Dougherty of Sea Girt, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., have announced that their daughter Kathleen Elizabeth Dougherty is to be married next month to Dr. James Aloysius Boozan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Boozan of Elizabeth, N.J., and Sea Girt.

LEAD: IF the mark of a good play is how well it withstands the indignities of a mediocre production, then Richard Harris's ''The Business of Murder'' ranks low in the ratings.

''It's like the kind of big, exciting movie we loved best then, in which someone pretty much like us takes incredible risks for unimpeachable motives and wins just what we wanted.

LEAD: New York State has agreed to return 12 wampum belts, some of which have been in the State Museum since 1898, to the Onondaga Nation of Indians.

LEAD: Recent tax and demographic trends are changing the role of life insurance. Traditionally, the insurance has provided family protection: in case of an untimely death, the proceeds help pay the rent, buy groceries, take care of college bills. The need for such insurance was reduced or eliminated once the insured's children were grown.

LEAD: The Soviet artist is so beholden to state subsidy, from quality of shelter to critical imprimatur, that the government's interference in the arts is a given. The real issue for many artists is how to minimize personal cravenness in accepting state help.
LEAD: An article last week about the closing of landfills quoted Mardythe DiPirro, Supervisor of the Town of Southampton, incorrectly. She advocates recycling garbage and opposes incineration.

Can workers and management develop the cooperative strategies necessary to compete with the Japanese on American soil?

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHENEVER I find myself in a city for the first time, I find that the best way to start learning about its history is to visit its churches. In most countries of Europe, historic ecclesiastical masterpieces allow a visitor, for a few moments, to see the world the way the age of faith saw it nearly a thousand years ago.

LEAD: The pitching staff is no better than last year's. They traded away a good prospect in Don Schulze for the so far disappointing Walt Terrell and did not pursue the recently released Bob Knepper, who they could've claimed for nothing.

LEAD: A lawsuit has been filed against a cemetery in suburban Pomona, accusing it of mingling the remains of several people who were cremated, returning the wrong ashes to some relatives and dumping excess ashes in a vacant lot.

LEAD: AUGUST HEAT. By Beth Lordan. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Beth Lordan paints the small-town atmosphere of her first novel in sumptuous prose; she refers, for example, to the ''wide generosity of the day's breeze,'' the ''cicada-laden silence.'' Out of this setting a potentially compelling story struggles to rise.

LEAD: For This Week: Plant crops for fall harvest: seedlings of broccoli, cabbage and kale plus seed for rows of spinach, mache, peas, beets and leaf lettuce. Transplant azaleas, rhododendrons, abelias, hollies and conifers. Pinch back overgrown petunias for rebloom in early fall. Remove faded flowers of geraniums to prevent disease.

LEAD: To insure the voting rights of the homeless, Maine has adopted a policy allowing people to register to vote even if they have no residence other than a park bench. ''To the best of our knowledge, Maine is the only state to handle it in this manner'' without pressure from the courts, said Richard Pinner of the New York-based National Coalition for the Homeless.

LEAD: Back in the 1970's, America's railroads were in sad shape. Plagued by rising costs and burdensome regulations, nine of the major freight carriers - controlling about a fifth of the nation's tracks - were bankrupt. Many of the remaining 56 railroads were barely profitable.

LEAD: William Grimes offers a number of explanations for the higher-than-market rates of return earned on investment in the archeological market; however, he overlooks the fact that nonprofit and state-owned museums have acted as black holes of archeological artifacts.

LEAD: It is difficult to determine to what extent the Yankees' losing record and poor pitching can be attributed to Dallas Green. But it is incomprehensible to have Roberto Kelly, with the team's highest batting averge as well as its highest on-base percentage, bat ninth. Surely, a .330 hitter batting further up in the lineup will have more at bats and, therefore, increase his team's run production.

LEAD: For the third day in succession, Beirut and other areas of Lebanon came under savage artillery and rocket barrages today, keeping residents pinned down in bomb shelters.

LEAD: These days college yearbooks can't just sit there; editors believe the productions have to move to attract attention. This has given rise to video yearbooks - enough to occasion a national competition by the Associated Collegiate Press to find the best ones.
LEAD: A Lobell captured the 31st International Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway, but it was not Mack Lobell, the premier trotter in the world the last two years.

LEAD: The Giants opened their preseason tonight with a 20-17 victory over the New England Patriots. More important for the Giants, they showed signs of becoming a good pro football team.

LEAD: A BITTER dispute has erupted over a memorial to honor Westchester's 47 fallen firefighters. To resolve the matter, it may be necessary to build two monuments, separately honoring the county's professional and volunteer firemen who have died while fighting fires.

LEAD: A NEW state law designed to restrict construction on 60,000 acres of sand dunes on Michigan's lakefront shores is expected to result in court challenges to the power of state regulators over private landowners' development rights.
LEAD: THE PILGRIM'S RULES OF ETIQUETTE By Taghi Modarressi. 279 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

LEAD: WHEN George Bush was running for for President, he held a gathering in Farmington to which the faithful from around Connecticut were invited - provided they donated $1,000 to the cause. They got to meet the Bushes before sitting down to a haphazardly prepared lunch at which Mr. Bush gave a ringing speech exhorting the faithful to turn out the vote.

LEAD: Patricia Shiland calls them ''miniature life-style portraits,'' and although the name may not immediately evoke an image, that's exactly what they are. The finished product is framed, protected by glass and hung on a wall, but instead of a painting or drawing it's a three-dimensional portrayal of an individual in miniatures that reflect the person's style of living.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was thrilled to see ''What's Doing in Glasgow'' (Travel, June 25). As a Glaswegian, I and my birthplace have been the butt of some cruel jokes, especially from citizens of that other famous Scottish city.

LEAD: Dr. William F. Mitty Jr., professor of surgery at New York University School of Medicine, died of a heart attack Wednesday while vacationing in Puerto Rico. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: THE season of fresh fruits is also the time of fine hot weather and of outdoor entertaining. Put them all together - they spell picnic. The other weekend I made a fruit salad to take to a potluck picnic. Watermelon, cantaloupe, honeydew, peaches, plums, grapes, cherries, nectarines, apricots and blueberries were piled in displays at the supermarket.

LEAD: Sorry, but I don't buy Bruce H. Dobkin's program of physical reconditioning and antidepressant therapy (Body and Mind: ''Ill, or Just the Blahs?'' July 16). Chronic Fatigue Syndrome sufferers aren't merely tired, they're sick, with an attendant bag of insidiously persistent flu-like symptoms. Dr. Dobkin's comparing his own faltering steps after a self-limiting viral illness (Hong Kong flu) with the protracted debilitation of Chronic Fatigue

LEAD: NOW that Shoreham is closed, we must get on with the job of providing Long Island with all the energy it needs for a healthy economy. Five steps can be taken in the months ahead to guarantee new sources of energy for the growth of Long Island into the 21st century.

LEAD: ''The people that got burned are the banks and the smaller guys, who were a little more desperate and shipped clothes with their fingers crossed.'' Howard Bloom, president of Chetta B, a dress maker, on the bankruptcy filings by Bonwit and B. Altman.

LEAD: THE State Department issued on July 25 a list of 29 countries requiring, or planning to require, evidence of tests for HIV, the AIDS virus, from some or all visitors. The list is based on inquiries sent to United States embassies around the world. Michael M. Mahoney, the director of the State Department's Citizens Emergency Center, said that the list was prepared because many travelers had asked the department for information about countries' requirements; it will be brought up to date on a regular basis, he said.

LEAD: EVEN though cities across the nation are burdened with too much vacant office space, developers are continuing to put up new buildings. And they have a good shot at success because many existing buildings are easy prey for new competition.

LEAD: ''When they hit the seat - that's when they chicken out.'' Jack T. Falfas, director of operations at Cedar Point, was describing how dozens of people wait nearly two hours on weekends to ride the theme park's newest roller coaster, the Magnum XL-200, only to bail out at the last minute. What sends them scurrying down the exit ramp is the sight of the Magnum's first hill - a stomach-churning, 20-story incline followed by a sheer, 60-degree drop that hurtles riders through the coaster's dips and curves at 70 miles an hour.
LEAD: Face it, most people don't drive Ferraris. Oh, really? you say.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S foster-care system is on the verge of running short of foster parents, say foster-care advocates and the head of the agency that oversees foster care in the state.
LEAD: Mike Shannon remembers the day he suddenly found himself lumped into that species known as journalisticus electronicus jockus.

LEAD: To the Editor: A reader requested information about places in England relevant to the life of Sir Winston Churchill (Q & A, May 21). Your interesting response covered sites from his early and career years. May I make Churchill's volume complete by adding a final chapter?

LEAD: Many in the arts say that government philistinism is unraveling a vibrant tapestry of artistic treasures and creativity.

LEAD: Ina Sue Kaplan and James Samuel Felman were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Morris W. Barzilai. Mrs. Felman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Kaplan of New York, is a senior accountant at Arthur Andersen & Company, accountants in New York. She is a graduate of Cornell University.

LEAD: Q. My house is 3 years old with a walk-out basement, which is unheated. There is a worsening problem of efflorescence on the outside of the concrete basement walls. Can you suggest a solution to this problem?

LEAD: Because of a production error, the mutual funds table last Sunday carried incomplete figures. The table failed to take account of trading on Friday, Aug. 4. That day's figures were, however, published in Business Day on Aug. 5. Readers wishing copies of the Saturday table may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y.

LEAD: MOST New Yorkers probably would be surprised to learn there are ''no hunting'' and ''no trapping'' signs within their city. But most New Yorkers have not visited Lighthouse Hill, a pleasant, wooded neighborhood in the center of Staten Island that would be invisible to the rest of the world if it were not for the working lighthouse that crowns the hill, 230 feet above sea level.

LEAD: Pounding home on his fourth Thoroughbred mount, THE KING OF THE NIGHTCAP (Bantam, $16.95), William Murray bumps Dick Francis at the three-quarter pole and prances into the winner's circle to the ecstatic cheers of his fans.

LEAD: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces. But if you neglected the task this year or have not examined these items within the last 12 months, you should do so before fall to make sure they are in safe working condition before the next heating season begins.

LEAD: Houston is filled with people who pass Astroworld every day and don't go in. It's just too familiar, sitting there in the middle of residential Houston. Like New Yorkers and the Statue of Liberty, they think of Astroworld as something for someday or something for tourists.
LEAD: In 1977, an event called Food Day was celebrated at the White House with a vegetarian meal. It gave some Americans the idea that a meatless meal was not just for vegetarians.
LEAD: Astronauts on the shuttle Columbia ended experiments and checked flight controls today as they prepared to land in California Sunday.

LEAD: The usual fare at Texas Stadium includes hot dogs and soft drinks, but no alcohol. Now the new Dallas Cowboys owner, Jerry Jones, and the stadium's management are seeking to skirt the alcohol ban by persuading the city of Irving that the stadium could qualify as a ''fine restaurant.''

LEAD: Judy Ann Van Dyck, a daughter of Eva R. Van Dyck of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Herbert Van Dyck, was married yesterday to Michael Scharfman, the son of Sylvia Flamm of New Rochelle, N.Y., at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi David B. Kudan officiated at the ceremony. Mrs. Scharfman is the purchasing manager at Eastern Supply Company, Inc., a heating and air-conditioning equipment company in Elmsford, N.Y.

LEAD: Hundreds of mourners and residents of the drug-torn Bushwick section of Brooklyn came out yesterday to bury a slain woman who had fought against drugs in her community. They marched and chanted in a two-mile funeral procession from the church to the cemetery.

LEAD: In Israel, where politics seems to be part of every issue, arts administrators and government officials say public support of the arts is free of political coloration. That doesn't mean Israeli politicians are reluctant to criticize plays or exhibits that fail to suit their ideology. And Israel does occasionally censor the arts, for what the government calls ''security reasons'' (though theater censorship has been abolished for a two-year trial period).

LEAD: Letitia Humphreys Barroll and James Bradley Frederick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Frederick of New Britain, Conn., plan to marry in September, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. W. Barroll of Baltimore, have announced.

LEAD: David Horowitz and Peter Collier are opportunists of the very worst type, and the attempt to legitimize them as ''born again'' is ludicrous. Particularly revolting is the mental image of Mr. Horowitz ''squeezing back tears'' at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. He, and others of his ilk, shouldn't even be allowed near the place.

LEAD: With all the rain that New York has seen this year, it was going to take something close to a flash flood to startle the city. It happened yesterday, when the afternoon sky turned dark and the rains moved in with a fury, stopping buses, delaying planes and turning back subway trains in their tracks.

LEAD: To The Editor: ''What's Doing in Glasgow'' mentions Saturday mornings ''on Byres Road, a bustling byway near the 15th-century towers of Glasgow University.'' While Byres Road is filled with activity, often that of university students, the towers of Glasgow University are not 15th century.

LEAD: Patrick Smith is to be the timpani soloist with the Bronx Arts Ensemble in the Timpani Concerto in D by the Italian Baroque composer Giuseppe Jacchini, today at 2 P.M. at Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and Mosholu Avenue in the Bronx. The program is to be repeated at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall at the Bronx Rose Hill campus of Fordham University.

LEAD: To find a particular scene or segment on a video cassette, many viewers just run the tape back and and forth until they find the spot. This method is slow, frustrating, rough on the tape and hard on the hardware. With all the search and indexing devices available on modern VCR's, such haphazard hunting isn't necessary.

LEAD: While heading the other day toward the Racer, a monstrous wooden roller coaster at Kings Island amusement park near Cincinnati, Donald Helbig's pace quickened and his expression brightened noticeably. ''It's like a second home for me,'' Mr. Helbig said.

LEAD: ''It's like a foreign country now,'' says the British film maker Terence Davies. ''We must be the most uncivilized, dirtiest, most aggressive, foulmouthed nation in Europe. We are pigs, and we live in a pigsty. Because I love my country, I loathe what it has become.''

LEAD: Legislators and strategists who are playing leading roles on each side of the abortion issue are trying very hard to cast themselves as moderates, hoping the public will conclude that their foes are extremists.

LEAD: Midsummer has settled over the audio scene, and all is seasonally indolent. The customers are away, and what is heard in the shops is mostly the sound of the air-conditioner. A similar lull pervades the manufacturing precincts of the trade as the workers head for the hills or the beaches.

LEAD: A former vice president of the student body at the University of Utah who took part in the burning of an American flag has accused a Vietnam veteran of assault. The veteran, Dale H. Osborne, was found to be carrying a loaded .38-caliber revolver.

LEAD: So many Eastern European athletes have been signing contracts with American teams lately that it's easy to forget that in the Communist world, there is no such thing as a free agent, even, it now appears, when an athlete has been bought and paid for.

LEAD: As a former 1960's activist myself (I was a member of Students for a Democratic Society at Columbia University during the student strike of 1968), I find the whole business of born-again anti-Communism to be an elaborate hoax designed to gain attention for a small group of unrepresentative, burnt-out cases (''Radical Transformations,'' by Sharon Churcher, July 16).

LEAD: FOR Ada Erik and her extended family, there are certain expectations: a roof over one's head, food on the table and, of course, death and taxes. But in this rural Passaic County community, she says, there are some things she refuses to accept without a fight.

LEAD: IT'S one of a vanishing species, an element of the ethnic Upper East Side that used to be the stronghold of Central and Eastern European nationalities. The New York Sokol's 1896 building at 420 East 71st Street is one of the survivors, a two-story intermission amid a growing forest of high-rises.

LEAD: A Toronto radio station reported that Gord Stellick, who resigned as general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs on Friday, would join the Rangers as assistant general manager, but Stellick denied yesterday that an agreement has been reached.
LEAD: Introduced in the 1930's, the diesel locomotive revolutionized the rail industry by enabling railroads to run faster trains with smaller crews.

LEAD: Larry Bird, who missed most of last season after foot surgery, will become the first athlete in any team sport to earn more than $6 million in a year, sources told The Associated Press yesterday.

LEAD: After months of delays, the Lotus Development Corporation has finally released not one, not two, but three new versions of its Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet, the financial modeling program that may be the most widely used computer application program in the business world. Customers who have been waiting for a new 1-2-3 may be confused by the sudden plethora of choices.

LEAD: A former mental patient apparently threw her three children 100 feet off a bridge to their deaths and then jumped into the Tombigbee River herself, the police said today.

LEAD: Sharon Churcher writes that once a young Communist, I am ''now a historian intent on exposing leftist bias in the college curriculum.'' As a lifelong opponent of McCarthyism of both the right and the left, I believe firmly in academic freedom, faculty autonomy and the right of scholars of differing persuasions to have complete freedom in determining course curriculum.

LEAD: Dallas Green appears to be totally unable to provide any off-the-field inspiration while his on-the-field managerial tactics are appalling. He has consistently failed to relieve starting pitchers until games have gotten well out of hand. MICHAEL HOWARD Woodbury, L.I.

LEAD: Charles S. Lyon, professor emeritus of New York University Law School and a former United States assistant attorney general, died Friday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan, where he lived. He had suffered complications from a series of strokes. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: Dr. Bob Lanier, a Republican, and Pete Geren, a Democrat, were the two top vote getters today in a Fort Worth-area election to fill the seat vacated by Jim Wright, the former House speaker toppled by ethics charges.

LEAD: As if the medium of opera were not bizarre enough, many composers further confused matters by introducing the element of sexual ambiguity. Their reasons were not always immediately clear. Why, for instance, should Mozart decide to put trousers on a mezzo-soprano and have her sashay about as the love-crazy adolescent Cherubino?

LEAD: When the rainy season comes each May to these rich farmlands, they explode in the brilliant green of Nicaragua's basic food crops - rice, beans, and tall cornstalks that loom over the field workers that tend them.

LEAD: Is it grey or gray (On Language: ''Shades of Gray/ Grey,'' July 16)? William Safire could have spared himself the extended exercise if he had simply followed the dictum of Andrew Jackson: ''It is a damned poor mind indeed which can't think of at least two ways of spelling any word.'' SID ESTEROWITZ

LEAD: FOR 43 years, Louise Bernstein, a social worker, has focused her energies on the elderly, working to create and improve services for older people in Fairfield County. Now, as a senior citizen herself, the 66-year-old Ms. Bernstein has created a program in which able-bodied elderly people help those who are not.

LEAD: Skiing Bittner Captures Slalom: Armin Bittner of West Germany clocked the fastest time in the first run and held on for the victory yesterday in a World Cup slalom race at the Australian resort of Thredbo. Bittner, 24 years old, the defending World Cup slalom champion, clocked 1 minute 2.52 seconds in the first run over a 74-gate course with a 205-foot vertical drop, and 59.41 seconds in the second, with 72 gates.

LEAD: WILLIAM PLUMMER makes a wonderful guest at a dinner party. He can speak informatively about the breakup of Sean Penn and Madonna. He has walked the Inca Trail. Interested in the psyche of a Vietnam veteran who hunts panthers in the Everglades? Ask Mr. Plummer.

LEAD: WITH the Sept. 12 New York City primary fast approaching, the candidates must distinguish themselves in unusual municipal circumstances. Though for Saratoga's clubhouse area and its tree-shaded paddocks, there is a dress code - dresses for women, jackets and ties preferred for men - no one seems to get too excited if it is occasionally ignored, as it was for the woman in the elegant white pants suit, center right.

LEAD: I do not consider myself a member of a Second Thoughts ''group.'' And if I have ''distanced'' myself from the activities of Peter Collier and David Horowitz, it was not because I preferred them ''to organize the grass roots'' rather than to remain ''an intellectual current.'' I simply found that I did not belong to that current as their actions and statements seemed to define it.
LEAD: IN virtually every community hospital in Westchester, elderly people no longer in need of hospitalization are living in a setting intended for acutely ill patients.

LEAD: Four American helicopters joined the search today for Representative Mickey Leland and 15 others missing since their flight vanished in western Ethiopia on Monday. But the day ended with no sighting of the plane or its passengers.

LEAD: The New York most visitors never get to is the playing field for the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, an agile bilingual troupe that is spending August performing in mostly working-class neighborhoods of all the boroughs as well as Westchester and New Jersey.

LEAD: As a writer and member of the gay community, and as a person diagnosed with AIDS, I am deeply ashamed of David Leavitt and his belated apology for not becoming involved in the fight against AIDS until now, until 1989, when ACT-UP became famous and it suddenly became fashionable to join the club (''The Way I Live Now,'' July 9).

And, according to reports from New York Times correspondents and bureaus around the world, these relationships are changing - in some places, such as the Soviet

LEAD: The owners of Douglas Elliman - a leader in the business of selling Manhattan co-ops and managing expensive apartment buildings - have decided to settle their differences by selling the 78-year-old company. The sole shareholders, Lawrence P. McGauley and Edwin J. Gould, fell into battle after Mr. McGauley, the hands-on chief for more than a decade, sparked upheaval and defections by dismissing a top executive a year ago.

LEAD: RICHARD W. BANGERTER of Orem, Utah, has been here for three weeks learning management strategy. He is a student at the Center for Montessori School Management, which is based this summer, along with the Center for Montessori Teacher Education, at the College of New Rochelle. When Mr. Bangerter returns home he will begin a new career.

LEAD: The focal point of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, which ended a week ago in Chicago, was the Spingold Knockout Team Championship. It provided upsets in the middle rounds, with all the top four seeds going down to defeat, and minor annoyances and major dramas in its concluding stages.
LEAD: The cardigan sweater is enjoying a resurgence of popularity among young women who are adapting its simple, classic look in new contexts.

LEAD: TWO days to go. I had started counting in the middle of final exams. When I made that announcement at the breakfast table, my son looked up in surprise and said, ''I can't believe you're actually counting.''
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: TASTES in salad dressings have shifted in this country. Several decades ago they were primarily sweet and thick. Recently, however, vinaigrette dressings have become extremely popular.

LEAD: The commander of United States forces in South Korea, Gen. Louis C. Menetrey, says there would be no military need to keep American forces there after the mid-1990's if present trends continue.

LEAD: Kings Park $190,000 83 Orchid Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, fireplace, basement, attic, 2-car garage; taxes $4,500. Massapequa $206,000 115 Massapequa Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old split level; new kitchen, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700.

Clark of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Richard W. Burton performed the ceremony at St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Last year Martin had one starter and no bullpen and had the team 15 games above .500. Yes, he had Clark, Henderson and Winfield but don't forget Balboni and Hall have 70 r.b.i. Barfield is doing just great, Kelly is getting on base, Sax counts for a lot, and the team is better off without Henderson.

LEAD: Before me stood the Great American Scream Machine, a long loopy roller coaster that rises like a serpentine monster above the entrance to the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson, N.J. Already, I was hoarse. See, speed is fine. Heights, too. But turning completely upside down? Seven times?
LEAD: People like to be scared on amusement rides: no one expects real danger. But accidents do occur.

LEAD: Kathleen Ann Kennedy, a senior claims examiner for Crum & Forster Commercial Insurance Company in Basking Ridge, N.J., and David Norton Grubb, a special deputy insurance commissioner for the State of New Jersey, were married yesterday at the Hermitage in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. Bernard Kettler, the Mayor of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., officiated.

LEAD: When faced with the most serious crisis so far as Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Frank E. Young found solace in the Bible. Turning to the Book of Romans, Dr. Young produced a quote that summed up his thoughts: ''All have sinned and fallen short of the glory of God.''

LEAD: CONFLICTING messages from pediatricians and health authorities on the immediate need for a second dose of measles immunization have generated growing confusion and concerns among many parents in recent weeks.
LEAD: THE Bush Administration reacted with suspicion when Fidel Castro offered last month to join the United States in the fight against narcotics traffickers.

LEAD: Censorship, in the form of a government official telling artists what they may or may not do, is not an issue in Italy. But it hardly means that politics and the arts are not intertwined. This is a country where party connections determine who becomes the doorkeeper at a government ministry, and the same principle applies to public funds for the arts.

Dr. Ned Wolfe Edwards, a cousin of the bride and a Presbyterian minister, and the bridegroom's father, also a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Keene Valley (N.Y.) Congregational Church.

LEAD: ''Radical Transformations'' was a good reminder of how the 1960's generation divided into the unlucky and the lucky.

LEAD: It was a merger that billed itself as a model of compatibility: Time-Warner, the company forged by combining Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. Synergy - that buzzword of mergers and acquisitions - would create a global media giant for the 21st century. A merger with any other suitor, Paramount Communications Inc., for example, was deemed unthinkable.

LEAD: SO you're not feeling well? Feverish? Dizzy? Nauseous? Poor thing. Want to make an appointment with your doctor? Of course. Ask yourself first if you're ready to do battle with your doctor's office receptionist for a decent appointment.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ALTHOUGH electronic brains these days control televisions and telephones, offices and automobiles, the average house is still a mindless creature, bumbling along without any effort to make itself more safe or economical, comfortable or convenient.

LEAD: MORE rain had been predicted for the rest of the day and the sky outside my bedroom window was indeed gray. But I awoke contented and ready to tackle whatever came my way. Then, glancing out a daughter's window, I discovered that the robin's nest and its three newly hatched nestlings was gone.
LEAD: Don McPherson threw two fourth-quarter touchdown passes, giving the Philadelphia Eagles a 23-17 preseason victory over the Atlanta Falcons tonight.

LEAD: It is being billed as the race that never happened, and when it happens today at the 100th Amateur Athletic Association championships at Alexander Stadium in Birmingham, England, there will be more than nostalgia at stake.

LEAD: On a street corner in a poor neighborhood of New York, a 12-year-old boy sits on a milk crate and sells crack. His mother stands by, patting his head. Other boys, as young as 7, 8 and 9, hang out nearby. They have most of the crack to be sold, so the 12-year-old will not be caught with it in his possession.
LEAD: Short on income and worried that aid from the Soviet Union may be cut, President Fidel Castro is dreaming these days of making Cuba a playground for foreign tourists once again.

LEAD: KAFFIR BOY IN AMERICA An Encounter With Apartheid. By Mark Mathabane. Illustrated. 303 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons.

LEAD: Early next April, teams in eight cities, some that have never had major league baseball, will begin a five-month schedule of 154 games. In the sixth month, next September, they will engage in three rounds of playoffs that will produce the first champion of the first major league outside the baseball establishment in 75 years.

LEAD: When Cordelia Knott served her first chicken dinner to paying guests at Knott's Berry Farm in 1934, she and her husband, Walter, could not have realized that 55 years later guests would follow the dinner by being zipped from 0 to 55 miles an hour in Montezooma's Revenge or by piloting their own cockpit in the new XK-1 airplane ride.
LEAD: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: A Dec. 9 wedding is planned by Marion Shepley Briggs and Harold James Berry 3d, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Briggs Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Manset, Me., have announced. Mr. Berry is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Thomas Berry of Darien, Conn.
LEAD: DESPITE what might have possessed the Darien Dinner Theater's producer, Jane Bergere, to put on a summer-stock season of three musicals, so far it is not working.

LEAD: STEVIE SMITH: A Biography. By Frances Spalding. (Norton, $19.95.) ''Stevie Smith is an unusually difficult subject for biography.'' So begins this book by Frances Spalding, the British biographer of Roger Fry and Vanessa Bell. The problem is that there is not much to go on: days spent as a secretary in London, evenings eked out in a household of spinsters in a suburb so outer it was virtually outre.
LEAD: The engagement of Geraldine Emily Baum to Michael Oreskes has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Louise Baum of Fairfield, Conn. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: Last week President Bush named as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff a man whose combat experience has included stints at the White House and the Pentagon.

LEAD: WITH the Sept. 12 New York City primary fast approaching, the candidates must distinguish themselves in unusual municipal circumstances. The 1989 race is the first with campaign spending limits, and is made more significant because the next mayor will have to deal with a redesign of city government and a new schools chancellor.

The program, ''CNN Newsroom,'' will be made available free to all high schools in the United States.

LEAD: Mike Reid did not major in physics or even math at Brigham Young University. But he knows better than any other golfer in the world that theorem of plane geometry: The shortest distance between two points is a straight line. In his case, right down the middle of the fairway.

LEAD: The new ''Are You O.K.? Program'' recently introduced in Ossining [ ''Computerized Calls to Check on Elderly,'' July 23 ] is a wonderful idea and has obviously proved itself in Iowa and elsewhere. If the total price to monitor 1,500 elderly residents is less than $7,000, it is a wonderful bargain as well.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having just returned from a week around the Shenandoah Valley, we were glad to see ''Roaming the Shenandoah Valley'' (Travel, June 25).

LEAD: Uphill or down, wherever you wander in Dorney Park, you're never far from The Sound: that primordial squeal, accompanied by a percussive clatter and ratchety basso profundo, that is the aria of passengers caught in the killer drop of a classic wooden roller coaster.

LEAD: CHINESE restaurants have traditionally offered good value for families dining out. Even today, when restaurant prices are steadily rising, this continues to be true, as Uncle Dai's, a new Chinese restaurant in downtown Stamford, demonstrates. Uncle Dai's does not put a lot of emphasis on decor. A few pictures, a lacquered screen masking flowers do their bit to dress up a long, drag storefront with red plastic chairs and booths and matching carpet.

LEAD: A growing demand for housing in New York City's Chinatown is pushing the neighborhood north and west. The Mandarin Plaza condominium apartment project is the latest example of this trend fostered by the increase in the number of Asians. Developers of the 25-story building at 378 Broadway, which also faces White Street and Cortland Alley, said they have already sold half of the 164 units, mainly to Asians who have either moved to the United States or plan to do so soon.
LEAD: Like many local governments, Summit County has more people it wants to jail than it has cells. Like many local governments, Summit County is building a larger jail.

LEAD: Q. My house is 3 years old with a walk-out basement, which is unheated. There is a worsening problem of efflorescence on the outside of the concrete basement walls. Can you suggest a solution to this problem?
LEAD: If Robert D. Kennedy were the type of man to brood, he'd probably be pretty miserable right now.
LEAD: The most ordinary things often set off the most extraordinary research efforts. Witness machine cancels.

LEAD: Manolo Blahnik sees a return to really feminine shoes with a hint of whimsy. Maud Frizon has always favored such styles, but for fall she has added some down-to-earth walking shoes. Walter Steiger's low, thick heels now have rounded edges and a thin coating of gold. Diego Della Valle sticks to the classics, and Giorgio Armani puts softening touches on tailored styles.
LEAD: All roads in the South don't really lead to Six Flags Over Georgia - 12 miles west of downtown Atlanta - but it sometimes feels that way.

LEAD: LOBSTER is a Maine cliche. The jaunty dancing crustacean on the state's license plate leaves scant doubt in the matter. Rare is the visitor who leaves without having savored the lobster's delicate flesh. Still, there is snobbery, mainly in the contention that until you've had lobster at a bona fide lobster shack, you haven't really had Maine lobster at all.

LEAD: Despite the efforts of Vincent Tese, New York State's Director of Economic Development, Stewart International Airport will remain without the services of American Airlines for the foreseeable future.

LEAD: Isabelle French is preparing to go out. She dabs her lips with lip gloss and checks her well-lacquered fingernails. She loads her purse with perfume, blusher and lipstick, and skips out the door. Isabelle French is 6 years old.

LEAD: Davey Johnson has enough trouble trying to figure out how to cut the Chicago Cubs' 4 1/2-game lead; he doesn't need another problem. But he has one: what to do with David Cone.

In photography this exercise has a special significance, since in the last 10 years the medium has played a broad and invigorating role in the art world.

LEAD: A few miles down the road from Colonial Williamsburg's blacksmiths and craftsmen is a celebration of a 20th-century technological triumph: the plastic water slide. Water Country U.S.A., a 40-acre park, elevates chutes and inner tubes to Disney proportions. Assuming you don't mind parading for hours before strangers in a soggy bathing suit with your stomach bloated from cotton candy and snow cones, you'll enjoy a wondrous variety of ways to be slippery when wet.
LEAD: A million-dollar baby in a 5-and-10-cent store once merited a hit song, and now a $200 million-a-year shopping center is trying to get one for itself, too.

LEAD: The Karsten Manufacturing Corporation, maker of the Ping Eye-2 golf clubs, is suing the United States Golf Association and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrew's in Scotland to prevent them from banning the use of the company's square-grooved irons in their competitions next year.

LEAD: This city has always been a curious mix of gentility and toughness, of refinement and bluntness. And that is exactly the way to describe the new skyscraper just finished at 75 State Street in the center of downtown, for this unusual tower, designed by Graham Gund Associates with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, reflects the city's complex character.

LEAD: As a public librarian I was greatly interested in the July 9 article ''Developing Children Into Avid Readers.'' I believe that public libraries play a vital role in turning children into avid readers.

LEAD: A Palestinian guerrilla who was trying to cross into northern Israel was shot and captured today in a clash with Israeli troops and allied militiamen about a mile and a half north of the border, the Israeli Army said. No group has claimed responsibility for the raid.

Though made on a comparatively modest budget, this is a beautifully produced movie, seen entirely from Patty Hearst's limited point of view - stylized at times, utterly direct and both shocking and grimly funny.

LEAD: A new state law designed to restrict construction on 60,000 acres of sand dunes on Michigan's lakefront shores is expected to result in court challenges to the power of state regulators over private landowners' development rights.

LEAD: IT'S the summer of ''Titus Andronicus.'' No longer relegated to obscurity, Shakespeare's earliest and bloodiest tragedy is currently slaying them, as the saying goes, at the New Jersey, New York and Stratford (Ontario) Shakespeare Festivals after a recent production by the Royal Shakespeare Company.

LEAD: The nation's elected representatives left Washington last weekend in dire need of a vacation, which, by their own admission, they had done little to earn. The first seven months of the 101st Congress were filled with distraction and turmoil, yielding little of substance. Yet a demanding agenda looms ahead, and for that, a brief period of rest and reflection is surely in order.

The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church in Sag Harbor by the Rev. Eliot G. Frederic.

LEAD: A few years ago, a friend and I were ambling down the main street of an English town in Oxfordshire called Woodstock. A microbus with Belgian plates pulled up, and the driver poked his head out the window to ask, ''Excuse me, do you know where ze festival was?'' I told him he was on the wrong side of the Atlantic; luckily for him, he drove off before I could add that I'd been at the festival.

LEAD: There is no significant support for a return to the thoroughgoing cartelization and incompetent government management of the airline industry that was practiced before 1978. But one active question remains: Has the reconcentration of the industry at the national level exposed travelers to monopolistic exploitation requiring governmental reintervention?

LEAD: In ''Best Friends,'' John Voulgaris toys with scores of questions about the nature of friendship, the rewards and perils of fame, the futility of intelligence, the emptiness of self-satisfaction and many other ordinary concerns that fill the dialogue of soap operas and romantic fiction - but he provides no answers and doesn't even make the questions very interesting.

LEAD: Allene Robinson Smith and Peter Alexander Cooley, who are planning to attend the Stanford Graduate School of Business next month, were married yesterday at St. James's Episcopal Church in Wilmington, N.C., by the Rev. Robert D. Cook.

LEAD: In December 1987, William D. Hanna arrived here with Yogi Bear and Magilla Gorilla. Accompanied by employees dressed as the cartoon characters, Mr. Hanna came to Warsaw to inaugurate a joint venture that his company, Hanna-Barbera Productions Inc., the American cartoon giant, set up with American and Polish partners.

LEAD: EIGHT Northeastern states said last week that they would join California in a plan to clean up the nation's dirtiest air. The strategy is not only aimed at tightening emission standards for cars rolling off the assembly lines. In an attempt to put the squeeze on the country's two largest pollution sources -the Los Angeles basin and the Northeastern megalopolis - officials on both coasts are turning their attention to a problem that had gone largely unregulated: old cars.

LEAD: Furious parents and teachers have filed suit seeking to overturn a Boston School Committee decision to close five schools and consolidate four others. They say the move will leave 4,000 students and 500 teachers unassigned just as the academic year approaches.

LEAD: One of the most spectacular of recent museum acquisitions, and in its field beyond a doubt the most envied, is the portrait by Vincent van Gogh of the postman Joseph Roulin that has just been bought from a Swiss private collection by the Museum of Modern Art.

LEAD: Each year, millions of visitors brave the Beast at Kings Island in Ohio. And brave they need to be. The result: You never know until the last minute what surprises await you.

LEAD: This has been an unusual year for lawns. Spring started out dry and there were dire predictions of drought. Then the rains came, and more rains, and cool growing weather. This turn of events was followed by an unusual summer, which so far, has had more than an adequate amount of rainfall. In ordinary seasons, lawns go dormant and turn brown at this time of year, but the grass has remained green.

LEAD: TENNIS Quick Victory for Graf: Top-seeded Steffi Graf needed only 32 minutes to ruin the pro debut of Kim Kessaris and post a 6-0, 6-0 victory last night in the opening round of the United Jersey Bank Classic at Mahwah, N.J. Kessaris, 16, was not scheduled to play in the tournament at Ramapo College but received a late invitation when Hu Na withdrew in the afternoon because of an ankle injury.(AP) Chang Wins: Michael Chang needed only 57 minutes to dispatch Neil Broad of South Africa, 6-1, 6-1, in the second round of the A.T.P.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, the ''Your Money'' column in Business Day on Aug. 5 misstated the extent to which some ''golden parachute'' payments would be affected by proposed Treasury regulations. For executives whose companies are taken over, the proposals clarify which compensation counts as part of a ''golden parachute.

LEAD: THE power of emotions to override even the most rational decisions may be explained by a new discovery about the brain, researchers say. The data suggest that the brain is arranged so key aspects of emotional life, like primitive fears, can operate largely independent of thought.

LEAD: Esa-Pekka Salonen, a 31-year-old Finnish conductor, has been appointed music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic as of September 1992. He replaces Andre Previn, who abruptly resigned from the post in April.

LEAD: Chicago has not been a ballet city historically. It has had its teachers, and has been hospitable enough to touring ballet troupes. But home-grown companies have not flourished there. Ballet Chicago is the newest entry into the ranks. Founded last year and directed by Daniel Duell, a former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, the company performed this week at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in its East

LEAD: 2d Lawmaker Is Killed Larkin Smith, a freshman Congressman, died in a plane crash in Mississippi as another air crash victim, Representative Mickey Leland, was mourned in Washington. Page A16. Judge Rejects DNA Tests In what may be the first challenge to DNA ''fingerprinting,'' a judge said that tests linking a murder suspect to a victim were not reliable.

LEAD: Gov. Thomas H. Kean today sent back to the Legislature a bill requiring reflectorized license plates, calling the proposed design ''ugly'' and saying the fee to cover costs of production was too small. In his conditional veto of the license-plate bill, the Governor said the proposed 25 cents in added registration fees would be too little to pay for the new plates which are considered safer because they would be more visible.

LEAD: This week in New York, Oleg Tabakov will complete a circle begun in Moscow in 1958 when, as a young actor, he had two parts in ''My Big Land,'' a play about a Jewish father and son, written by the poet Aleksandr Galich.

LEAD: The stock price of North-West Telecommunications Inc. surged $4.25 today, to $30.75, after the Wisconsin telecommunications company announced on Monday that it had turned down a friendly merger offer from an unidentified bidder. The 16 percent gain was the fifth largest among over-the-counter issues.

LEAD: Experts on energy thought for years that oil production in the United States would shrink to insignificant levels by the middle of the next century, making imports the nation's only meaningful supply. Now they are finding that steady advances in the technology for finding oil from large but hard-to-reach reserves discovered years ago seem likely to stretch the nation's era of oil production, possibly well beyond the year 2100.
LEAD: Art Monk, after avoiding the news media for much of the past six seasons, has shed his reclusive image at the Washington Redskins' training camp.
LEAD: Robert B. Anderson, the Texas-born lawyer who was Secretary of the Treasury from 1957 to 1961, died Monday at New York Hospital, a hospital spokesman said yesterday.

LEAD: New York City's Department of Juvenile Justice has prepared a sensible plan to replace the inaccessible, inadequate Spofford juvenile detention center with two smaller, better designed facilities. The plan deserves the Board of Estimate's backing. There is broad agreement on the merits. Juvenile Justice managers find Spofford poorly designed - long walks between dormitories and dining hall, for example, require a heavy investment in supervision, and program space is limited.

LEAD: The Mets won a gamble, a foot race and a ball game last night in Shea Stadium when they rallied for two runs in the ninth inning to edge the San Diego Padres, 3-2, and moved into second place, three and a half games behind the Chicago Cubs.
LEAD: The United Nations Security Council called for an immediate cease-fire in Lebanon late Tuesday and urged the Arab League to resume mediation efforts it discontinued last month.

LEAD: Robert J. Wussler announced today that he would resign from Turner Broadcasting System Inc., after 10 years in which the senior executive vice president helped guide the international expansion of the cable television concern.
LEAD: Oliver L. North's appeal of his convictions in the Iran-Contra case will be heard on Feb. 6 before a three-member panel of judges.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines expanded its daily schedule yesterday to 390 flights, from 350, and announced that it would offer 602 daily flights beginning Sept. 7. The airline also said it would sell tickets for at least half its seats at large discounts to fill the additional flights.

LEAD: Tom Watson and Lanny Wadkins, a pair of 39-year-old pros with considerable Ryder Cup experience, were named to the United States Ryder Cup team today by their long-time friend and fellow touring pro, Raymond Floyd, who is the nonplaying captain of this year's squad.

LEAD: The rehearsal pianist launches into the opening bars of ''Shall We Dance.'' Suddenly the actress who plays Anna, the English governess who is hired to tutor the crown prince of Siam in ''The King and I,'' coaxes the new actor playing the King into trying the polka. The lip-biting monarch with two left feet takes a few tentative steps, then the two of them sweep off, circling the battered studio floor at a ferocious pace to the laughter, cheers and whistles of the other cast members.
LEAD: President Bush said something today that neither of his two immediate predecessors would have dared to say quite so bluntly.

LEAD: Louis M. Thayer, who was a member of the National Transportation Safety Board for nine years after retiring as a rear admiral in the Coast Guard, died of a heart attack Aug. 9 at his home in St. Augustine, Fla. He was 82 years old and had lived in the Washington area for 25 years before moving to Florida last year.
LEAD: Citing reduced revenues and increased losses, the Ashton-Tate Corporation announced today that it would lay off at least 15 percent of its 1,700 employees and take other cost-cutting measures.

LEAD: The tenor Frank Lopardo will replace Vinson Cole in the Mostly Mozart performance of ''Davidde Penitente'' next Tuesday and Wednesday. Patricia Schuman, a soprano, is the other soloist. Also on the all-Mozart program are Divertimento in D (K. 2251), and the Violin Concerto No. 4 in D with Midori as soloist.

LEAD: ON television, in magazines and on the sides of city buses, the advertisements trumpet ''dry'' beer. LEAD: OF the thousands of adolescents who will be going off to college in the next month, a disturbing number will not graduate. For many of those students, the freshman year will be a watershed. LEAD: There is a delightfully anomalous, pre-suburban quality to northeastern Westchester County. Just beyond the bedroom communities of the early-and mid-20th century, and barely 50 miles from Manhattan, a surprising sense of rural gentility still reigns in such communities as Katonah and Bedford. Along the heavily wooded country roads that string together a patchwork of still-quiet hamlets are such noteworthy house museums as Caramoor and the John Jay Homestead, not to mention the Katonah Gallery, that suggest a world far away in spirit from metropolitan New York, 1989.

The Rev. Helenmarie Sunkenberg, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Grace Memorial Union Chapel in Sabbathday Point, N.Y.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Whittemore Millard of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Jayne Nesbitt Millard and Milton Lee Clark Jr., the son of Mr. Clark of San Antonio and Benja Leta Clark of Houston.
LEAD: Some weeks ago I was in a Mexican restaurant in Los Angeles. It was the kind of eatery that could be part of a chain - Formica tables, plastic chairs, foam-rubber plants and fiberglass bricks.

LEAD: IN an unruffled voice, Zhang Xiaobin explains that not much has changed at his venture capital firm since the dramatic crackdown in Beijing two months ago. His employees come to work, his profit targets are within grasp, he still travels.

LEAD: THEY missed something and it is a rather big something. When the Pennsylvania Railroad demolished Penn Station in 1964, it was described by The New York Times ''a monumental act of vandalism.'' Many New Yorkers and architectural historians still regret the loss of the station, and aficionados search the lower depths of the present station for remnants of the old one - handrails, elevator doors, lighting fixtures and the like.
LEAD: IT was a dark and stormy night when the bizarre sex crime that forms the basis for ''Murder By Appointment'' was committed. It was also a dark and stormy night when the killer was caught.

LEAD: When it comes to negotiating a major league contract, a rookie's best friend could be a competing offer from a phantom rival league. LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IN May, more than 200 executives from New Jersey's leading companies convened in Princeton to form a coalition called ''Invest in Children.'' Their mission: to decide how best to use their financial and political clout to improve the health and education of the state's youth.
LEAD: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in Azerbaijan today to demand that the Communist authorities free jailed members of an independent group and accept its political demands.

LEAD: AFTER a three-year construction surge in many of Manhattan's most expensive neighborhoods, the pace of residential development in New York City has slowed. Its focus, moreover, is shifting to lower-cost housing, most of it in the other boroughs and much of it dependent on government support.

LEAD: TO Phyllis Newman, time is a riff. Now that she is about to begin her ''101st year'' as a performer, Ms. Newman says that she is ''still doing the things I've always tried to do - to really entertain and, also, somewhere, I hope there's a point of view that comes across.''
LEAD: In recent years, advances in medical science have significantly improved the health care delivery system in the United States.

LEAD: The sanctioned Woodstock commemorative concert, the one with the permits, the Port-o-Sans and the liability insurance, fizzled. But a spontaneous gathering at the hayfield that was the site of the Woodstock Arts and Music Fair 20 years ago here attracted thousands of people, who came with tepees, tents, blankets and sleeping bags.
LEAD: Colleges are supposed to prepare people for a lifetime career or job. How long does a football career last? How many are left with lifetime vexation of injuries?

LEAD: WITH competition tightening for high-quality American Indian crafts, Tedd Schwartz has developed stratagems for getting some of the best objects. He visits his favorite Hopi potters in Arizona during the early morning hours, just as they unload their kilns.

LEAD: A rookie, Billy Joe Tolliver, threw two touchdown passes, and another rookie, Elliot Smith, returned an intercepted pass 49 yards for a touchdown tonight as the San Diego Chargers beat the Chicago Bears, 24-7.
LEAD: ''It is an incredible success for our struggle. But now let us see it in practice. This is just the beginning.'' - Lech Walesa. [ 12:1. ]

LEAD: Program notes described ''The Angle of Ascent,'' presented on Wednesday afternoon at the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival, as ''a metaphoric collage addressing the variedness of life, its transformations, its mysteries, its impermanence, and its eternal continuance.''

LEAD: September wedding plans for Ellen Beth Speer and Gary Davis have been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Speer of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Mr. Davis is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Davis of Montreal.
LEAD: Gary David Goldberg doesn't know what to do with $60 million, but it's not one of the things he worries about.

LEAD: Jessica Meltsner and Brian Michael Britt, graduates of Oberlin College, were married yesterday at the Rockport, Mass., home of the bride's grandfather, Dr. John Spiegel. Fred Fritsen, a Rockport justice of the peace, officiated.

LEAD: There are many Southern dishes that I hold dear. But, in the article on Robert Fulghum, y'all mentioned a dish I've never head of. What, in the name of Southern cuisine, is chicken hyphen fried steak? Where I come from in Mississippi (pronounced Missippi), no one uses a hyphen between chicken and fried.
