LEAD: Two years ago, Emily Lloyd might have been dismissed as one of those minor storm systems that rattle the showbiz barometers, stir the moviegoing public and evaporate as suddenly and inexplicably as they arrived. After all, she was only 16 and had appeared in a single low-budget film. She'd played the brazen adolescent who scandalizes a sedate British seaside town with her sexual bravado in ''Wish You Were Here,'' and she'd done nothing else whatsoever.
LEAD: Ending a costly rivalry, Fraser has surrendered the title ''Icebox of the Nation'' to International Falls, Minn.

LEAD: ''The Cocktail Hour,'' a semi-autobiographical comedy by A. R. Gurney, will close today after the matinee at the Promenade Theater, Broadway at 76th Street. Directed by Jack O'Brien and starring Nancy Marchand, Burt Edwards, Holland Taylor and Richard Backus, the play will have run for 15 previews and 351 regular performances.

LEAD: I VIVIDLY RECALL THE first time I held a gun. My father was a New York City cop. One day when I was 10, he returned from his annual trip to the firing range and let me and my brother watch him clean his .38 caliber Smith & Wesson revolver. Dad sat on the kitchen table as the biting odor of gunpowder and gun oil filled the room.
LEAD: No, Donald, we said buy the Yankees.
LEAD: Did the American people somehow let down, even betray, the contra rebels in Nicaragua?
LEAD: A woman who was hit in the arm by a stray bullet while dining in a 31st-floor apartment says she is uneasy that the police have no clue to where the shot came from.

LEAD: The insider-trading case against Robert A. Freeman has ended with his conviction, but it was hardly a shining hour for Federal prosecutors. Mr. Freeman, a partner in the firm of Goldman, Sachs, was arrested along with two other brokers in 1987 and, amid much ado, charged with a broad insider trading conspiracy.

LEAD: The new order in Poland, and sharp changes in neighboring countries, suggest the start of a new order for all of Eastern Europe - the first real break with Moscow's orthodoxy in 40 years. The Week in Review, section 4.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Prospects column last week, about the impact of the savings and loan bailout plan on interest rates, misstated Ralph Nader's assessment of the plan. Speaking about one effect of the bailout, he said: ''Nonprofit groups will get the first crack at taking over the residential property of the Resolution Trust Corporation.

LEAD: EVERY summer, with sheep firmly grasped by the throat, in groups of 10 or so, classed by age or category (such as yearling ewe or grand champion ram), anxious youths line up before the judge in the middle of the large red show barn at the Medina County Fair in Medina, Ohio. Hours before, back in the stables, the animals were carefully cleaned, clipped and groomed.

LEAD: Swimming Another Record for Barrowman: An American, Mike Barrowman, broke the world record for the 200-meter breaststroke during today's qualifying heats at the Pan Pacific championships in Tokyo. Barrowman, 20 years old, was clocked in 2 minutes 12.89 seconds in his heat at the Yoyogi National Swimming Pool on the final day of the championships.
LEAD: BEGINNING OF THE END

LEAD: In June, less than an hour before adjourning for the summer, the South Carolina Legislature adopted ''Target 2000: School Reform for the Next Decade.'' The measure is an extension of the Education Improvement Act of 1984, which identified 61 ways to improve school performance and has already helped lift S.A.T.

LEAD: President Bush said today that he would work with President Barco to coordinate the extradition of narcotics traffickers to the United States so that they can be brought to justice as swiftly as possible.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: I was enchanted with Paul Lewis's account of Talloires and neighboring town (''Beside the Alpine Lake of Annecy,'' Travel, June 11). My two children, ages 7 and 10, my husband and I rented a chalet in Talloires for the month of July last year and it was an unforgettable holiday.

LEAD: IN the early 1970's, Logan Lewis, a young man from the Bronx, had just started rehabilitating drug addicts on the Island, but he often encountered a problem: Communities told him that, although his work was worthwhile, they did not want addicts as neighbors.

LEAD: Things Italian have become wildly popular in the last few years, and we should all be grateful. The food can be enormously satisfying without being stupefyingly rich. It can be hearty and still seem appropriate in warm weather.

LEAD: I read the article on blueberries with interest (''Picky About Blueberries,'' Opinion page, July 16) and would wish to be in the author's shoes. I'm about to plant blueberries extensively, but am wary of the new, disease-resistant, large and copious berries that are bland in taste. I hope someone can guide me to domestically grown blueberries that still preserve the old, wild flavor.

LEAD: In Richard Eyre's production of ''Hamlet'' at the National Theater (starring Daniel Day-Lewis in the title role), Polonius (Michael Bryant) was giving instructions to his aide Reynaldo. Suddenly Mr. Bryant stopped speaking, then said, as if in a daze, ''I was about to say something,'' and searched his mind for his place in the play.
LEAD: JOSEPH SCUTELLARO, who teaches a seminar in business management, will admit that he sometimes has trouble maintaining a certain level of interest and attention in his classroom.
LEAD: To the Editor: Recently I had an enjoyable vacation in Sri Lanka. Despite all the unrest, I was not affected.
LEAD: CHRISTOPHER UNBORN By Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Alfred Mac Adam and the author. 531 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

LEAD: In the far northern reaches of Manhattan lies a territory where the steep hills and deep valleys have not been flattened by bulldozers, where streams of immigrants have mixed without melding and where everyone is a Westsider because a river runs just east of Amsterdam Avenue.

LEAD: Dr. Lainie Sue Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Friedman of Jericho, L.I., was married there last evening to John Louis Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ross of Jericho. Cantor Mark Horowitz and Cantor Barbara Horowitz, who are husband and wife, performed the ceremony at the Fountainebleau.

LEAD: Ellis Burks's two-run single with the bases loaded and one out in the 14th inning today gave the Boston Red Sox a 3-1 victory over Milwaukee, ending the Brewers' winning streak at eight games. The Red Sox stopped a losing streak at six games.

LEAD: A report on Aug. 6 about the wedding of Judith Lynn Steinhardt included an incorrect reference to the bridegroom. He is Daniel Albert Carasso, a graduate of the University of Southern California and a recipient of an M.B.A. degree from Georgetown University.

LEAD: Ten months after doctors removed a tumor from his throwing arm and told him he would never pitch again, Dave Dravecky returned triumphantly to baseball. Last week, five days after Mr. Dravecky's first comeback victory for the San Francisco Giants and six innings into his second, the arm gave out, breaking with a loud crack as Mr.

LEAD: There recently arrived in my mailbox a billet-doux from my little brother. More specifically, this was a five-page letter to him, from me, with his Post-it self-stick memo stuck to page 1. The letter was dated ''13/xi/63'' - a la European mode - and postmarked Cambridge, England, mailed to an 11th grader.

LEAD: BEFORE the Great Revolution, the Cultural Revolution and the Beijing Spring of 1989, Shanghai was China's most Westernized city, supplying foreigners and Chinese alike with the finest in handmade clothing. Somber-hued pajamas and gray serge Mao jackets were not enough to keep Shanghai's custom tailors in business during the succeeding decades, and a number emigrated to Hong Kong, where many of the best tailors are Shanghainese.
LEAD: As negotiations with the Jets' No. 1 one draft pick, Jeff Lageman, bog down, an interesting pattern has emerged between the men who represent opposite sides in the talks.

LEAD: When the University of South Carolina administration decided last spring to designate two freshmen dormitories where rooms would be off limits to the opposite sex, it didn't know how students would react.

LEAD: The engagement of Claire Trumbull Townsend to Edward Victor Bacher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Bacher of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., has been made known by her parents, Mrs. Harold P. Salembier of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Charles C. Townsend of Germantown, N.Y. An Octorber wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Treacy Jr. of Scarsdale, N.U., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Marie Treacy to Kevin Francis Driscoll, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Driscoll of Westlake, Ohio. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Because of a concert sponsor's change, a listing today in the Week in Connecticut column of the Connecticut Weekly misstates the site of a Hartford appearance by the Tannahill Weavers. The concert, at 7:30 P.M. today, will be at the Summit Hotel, not at Lloyd's Restaurant.
LEAD: As a black who grew up under Southern segregation, now living and working in New York, I am tired of sanctimonious Yankee hypocrites trooping down South to pontificate about racism.

LEAD: TO the old guard, nostalgic for their genial hometown, Stamford has become an austere, intimidating business center, the largest between New York and Boston. But new residents of Connecticut who choose it over Darien, New Canaan or Greenwich do so ''because you get more value for your money,'' said Janice Green, manager of the William Pitt Real Estate office.

LEAD: The Yankees proved tonight that they don't play favorites. They showed that they can lose games for Bucky Dent just as easily and just as excruciatingly as they did for the deposed Dallas Green.
LEAD: SINCE David Mamet is a master provoker and a distinctive stylist, his depiction of women is one of the contemporary theater's more interestingly debatable issues.
LEAD: TO a child, a summer is longer than a year. For David, my 2-year-old son, this is his first boyhood summer. Innocence and wonder surround everything he does.

LEAD: Q. We are planning to install a new kitchen floor of vinyl tiles. The existing floor is vinyl tile that still is well secured and has a smooth surface. LEAD: AS chaotic as Lebanon may have seemed to outsiders in the past 14 years, the civil war there actually followed certain unwritten rules. What is new about the violence today is that those long-established rules are being shredded. The political and military boundaries that no one had dared breach - call them ''red lines'' - have now been crossed, and the combatants are entering a new game whose rules are as undefined as its outcome.

LEAD: PERHAPS the worst thing about computer networking is the actual physical wiring. Whether the computers are connected with coaxial cables, twisted pair cables, fiber-optic cables or jumper cables, the cabling itself is usually a logistical, physical and financial nightmare. Adding a computer to the network, or even just moving someone's desk, is a major ordeal.

LEAD: ZUCCHINI can be a very boring vegetable. As a child in England I remember how each year local gardeners would compete to grow the biggest, pointing with pride at specimens the size of a man's riding boot. The marrows, as they were called, were cooked with the typical English solicitude toward vegetables: Boiled, stuffed and then baked until they were reduced to a watery pulp.

LEAD: Iran today hanged 79 ''notorious and professional'' drug smugglers, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the convicts were hanged in Teheran and in 21 cities after being found guilty by the Islamic Revolutionary Court, which runs the nation's anti-narcotics campaign.

LEAD: TWO weeks into the telephone workers' strike, a familiar pattern is evident: while American unions battle hard, and often successfully, to maintain health insurance and other benefits, they are quietly giving ground on wages.

LEAD: PRACTICE, PRACTICE, PRAC-tice. Tchaikovsky conducted on opening night, and the stature of America's grandest music venue was thenceforth entrenched.

LEAD: EVERY parent who has ever been detoured by a whining child into a Story Book Village, a Frontier Land or a Dinosaur World, can blame it on one man: Julian Reiss, creator of Santa's Workshop. LEAD: ARRIVING in St.-Tropez in the late afternoon - my Pan Am flight was six hours late - I had to do something to fill up the time until the clubs opened. So I dropped into the bar of the Byblos Hotel and spent several hours trying to decide whether to jump off the balcony. Diving off this balcony into the Byblos pool is one of St.-Tropez's sacred rituals.

LEAD: The late Alexis Lichine spent much of his professional life arguing for a revision of the 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux. He didn't succeed. When he died, earlier this year, the 1855 classification remained much as it had always been - and probably will be for a long time to come.

LEAD: FOR almost as long as there has been cable television, the question of how to provide the service to isolated rural residents has nagged at franchise owners, regulatory agencies and scores of would-be subscribers throughout the nation. LEAD: STRANGER AT THE GATE. By Malcolm Bosse. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Indonesia in 1965 was a country in turmoil. On one side was the P.K.I., the third-largest Communist Party in the world; on the other, the country's Muslim majority and its army. Caught in the middle was the increasingly ill President Sukarno, who, in an attempt to maintain power and a semblance of order, was performing a delicate balancing act between opposing factions.

LEAD: Academicians and researchers afford colleges a name and prestige commensurate with their scholarly doings. LEAD: THE sabbatical, once the exclusive perquisite of the academic community, has spread to the business world. But with one significant difference: Unlike teachers, only a few business people who take an extended leave are lucky enough to be kept on their companies' payrolls or are guaranteed the same or comparable jobs when they return.

The handsome prince sweeps the maiden off to the castle and cares for her the rest of her life.

LEAD: A picture caption on July 30 with an article about a camp for the blind misidentified a counselor. She is Tanya Chin.

LEAD: Roger Zelazny is not comfortable with rigid categories. He writes about science as if it were magic and magic as if it were science. His characters are conversant with Chaucer and Nietzsche and thermodynamics and Hart Crane and molecular biology. His eclectic enthusiasms add sparkle to his new collection of stories, FROST AND FIRE (Morrow, $16.95).
LEAD: SINCE David Mamet is a master provoker and a distinctive stylist, his depiction of women is one of the contemporary theater's more interestingly debatable issues.

LEAD: ''DOESN'T anybody stay in one place anymore?'' asked Carole King in a song some years ago. Katharine Barrett Kelly has stayed in one place. She has lived all of her 81 years in Bedford - more specifically, in Katonah, a hamlet in the town.

LEAD: Easy Goer's victory in the $1,088,500 Travers Stakes at Saratoga on Saturday was a lot easier than the decisions his handlers face as they plot his fall campaign.

LEAD: A third person died yesterday from injuries caused by an underground steam-pipe explosion that rocked the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan on Saturday night, causing millions of dollars in property damage.
LEAD: The police and military authorities rounded up nearly 10,000 people in a nationwide search for drug traffickers suspected in the slaying of a presidential candidate, officials said today.

LEAD: Drug testing of transportation workers is an increasingly popular idea, but programs to begin the testing are moving at a crawl.
LEAD: Linda Lyon Van Voorhis, a poet, died yesterday at her home in Irondequoit in suburban Rochester. She was 87 years old.

LEAD: IN a dark and smoky chamber two floors above 10th Avenue and 56th Street, Tony Schwartz roosts behind a music stand, a solo performer in New York's oddest cabaret act. A master of political advertising, Mr. Schwartz ignores the grand piano to his right, playing instead a small tape recorder as he sings the body electronic.

LEAD: In the most striking example yet of Japan's growing financial interest in the American motion picture business, a leading Japanese consumer electronics company has agreed to provide a Hollywood producer with more than $100 million to make films.

LEAD: Shelley Taylor Smith hears the same question every time she mentions her favorite pastime: ''Why?'' When she explains how much she enjoys circling Manhattan armed only with goggles and a tetanus shot, she is confronted by the same stares, the same head-shaking disbelief.

LEAD: William Herbert Hunt, a former billionaire, has filed a reorganization plan in bankruptcy court that would pay less than half of the $300 million in back taxes the Government says he owes.

LEAD: The Mets were marching magnificently through August yesterday with a 3-1 lead over the Los Angeles Dodgers in the ninth inning. Two were out and nobody was on base. Then it happened: on the longest of long shots, the Dodgers snatched the game on a pinch-hit single, a bunt single and a three-run home run by Willie Randolph, who hadn't hit one since the Yankees exiled him after 13 years in New York.

LEAD: THIS is the time of year when I am persuaded to pursue easily gathered aquatic quarry: steamer clams, mussels or quahogs rather than striped bass or bluefish; tautog, sand eels or blue claw crabs rather than trout.

LEAD: Unionized pilots of Eastern Airlines were set back twice late Friday night, as the executive board of the Air Line Pilots Association refused to call for a national work stoppage in support of their walkout and declined to allow the pilots to keep their seniority if they move to other carriers.

LEAD: ''We sang today at the church, 'Poland lives, Poland is growing.' LEAD: Governments and companies across Europe are teaming up on a large and fast-growing number of projects aimed at making Europe a more formidable competitor for the United States and Japan.

LEAD: The first sight to greet the audience at the Central Park ''Titus Andronicus'' is a small, flaming barbecue grill propped up on a slender tripod at center stage. ''Titus Andronicus'' is a revenge-begets-revenge tragedy of rape, dismemberment and decapitations whose body count runs so high even scholars don't always jibe on the final tally.

LEAD: The Jets' quarterback situation worsened tonight when Pat Ryan, the back-up, suffered a sprained knee in an exhibiton game against the Philadelphia Eagles that will keep him out for from six to eight weeks. The loss of Ryan marred the Jets' 19-10 victory.
LEAD: NBC and Group W announced Friday that their stations were jointly developing a weekday, hourlong entertainment and news program.

LEAD: An article yesterday misstated the position of the American Anthropological Association on returning bones and other relics from museums to Indian tribes. The Association, most of whose members are cultural anthropologists who do not work with physical materials, has designated a commission to recommend a policy position for adoption at its annual meeting in November, 1990.

LEAD: Steel imports in June rose for the third consecutive month, up 5.2 percent, to 1.55 million tons, but the total for the first half of the year is sharply below the 1988 period, the American Iron and Steel Institute said last week. Steel exports in June continued substantially ahead of recent years, totaling 403,000 tons, compared with 355,000 tons in May and 126,000 tons in June 1988.

LEAD: Over the last 20 years, the women's movement has transformed the American workplace. In increasing numbers, women are on the job in the offices of corporate law firms and the shuttles in outer space. Not just working; they are giving orders on factory floors and on the drill fields of West Point.

LEAD: Two teen-agers have been arrested in the death of a homeless man who was electrocuted earlier this month after four youths accosted him in an Upper West Side subway station, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: A second Con Edison employee died of injuries suffered Saturday night when a steam pipe exploded in Gramercy Park, bringing the death toll in the accident to three. Con Edison workers made repairs at the site yesterday. Page B3. (The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee)
LEAD: Credit market analysts say the Federal Reserve Board is not at all likely to push interest rates lower in the near future, despite exhortations from the Administration to do so.

LEAD: After Japan's political leadership won passage of a 3 percent sales tax last year, it seemed that Parliament had written the final chapter in a battle raging for more than a decade. Little did anyone here expect a tax revolt.

LEAD: A 68-year-old New Jersey man was stabbed to death Saturday evening in the entrance of his daughter's apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, apparently a victim of an attempted robbery, the police said.

LEAD: A table in Business Day on Thursday about health care and the strike at the Nynex Corporation referred incorrectly to a contract offer by the company, which is proposing payroll deductions to help cover premium costs. In the first year of a new contract, the proposed deduction would be $10.27 weekly, not monthly.

LEAD: A longtime leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who was convicted on Federal extortion charges in 1988 won re-election Saturday to head the Alabama chapter of the civil rights group.

LEAD: TO most boxing insiders and to a growing number of just plain fight fans, there is only one man these days who represents a credible challenge to Mike Tyson, and he is the former undisputed cruiserweight champion, Evander Holyfield.

LEAD: At the Westbury (L.I.) Manor, Helene Schlackman, a daughter of Mrs. Milton Schlackman of Lynbrook, L.I. and the late Mr. Schlackman, was married yesterday to Jonathan Robert Rod, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester S. Rod of Penn Valley, Pa. Rabbi Arnold Shevlin officiated.

LEAD: PGA Earnings Q. Each week, the PGA Tour lists its leading money winners based on what each golfer has earned for the year, without regard to how many tournaments he entered. Among the top earners this season, who would be the leader on the basis of earnings per tournament? A. Through 33 tournaments this season, not counting this weekend's event in Colorado, the per-tournament leader in winnings is Tom Kite, who is second on the overall earnings list.
LEAD: Striking telephone workers in California and Nevada tentatively agreed today to return to work, and a union spokeswoman said they could be back on the job by the end of the week.

LEAD: Pamela Linde Lippmann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lippmann of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Adam Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Roth of Peekskill, N.Y. Rabbi William P. Kloner officiated at Maison Lafitte in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Mrs. Roth is an English teacher at the Dwight-Englewood School in Englewood, N.J.
LEAD: As an 11-ton scientific satellite slips back toward earth faster than expected, the space agency is racing to retrieve it before it crashes.

LEAD: Like modern-day knights of the Round Table, a band of adults came here on a recent weekend in search of the Holy Grail. But instead of riding mighty steeds, carrying lances and wearing armor, they arrived in station wagons and Jeeps, donned jeans and carried knapsacks and notebooks.

LEAD: Artistry, weather and the environment all came together to make a spellbinding event at Wave Hill in the Riverdale section of the Bronx early Saturday evening, when Forti and Troupe presented the world premiere of Simone Forti's ''Touch.''
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about dry beer misidentified the business school at Washington University in St. Louis. It is the John M. Olin School of Business.

LEAD: When famine strikes abroad, American purses fly open at ''Live Aid'' concerts. Now many of the same citizens are asking why U.S. foreign aid can't do more to end global poverty as well as serve U.S. national interests. This has spurred useful reform proposals for what is likely to be Congress's first formal foreign aid bill since 1985.
LEAD: Five people have been indicted after what the Commerce Department described as an attempt to ship high-technology equipment of military value to the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Last year it took Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential candidate, months before he would admit to being a ''liberal,'' proving just how dirty the ''L-word'' had become in national politics.
LEAD: The Orioles, who have been in first place since May 26, maintained a half-game lead over the Brewers in the American League East by defeating the Toronto Blue Jays, 7-2, today.

LEAD: The Kremlin's pregnant silence these days, as Poland prepares to install its first non-Communist government since the early postwar years, is widely taken for tacit acceptance of the new Polish reality.

LEAD: In a novel East-West arrangement, the Jewish Museum is to move across Central Park into one floor of the New-York Historical Society on the Upper West Side for two years while its own Upper East Side home is closed for renovations and expansion.

LEAD: The guerrilla forces led by Jonas Savimbi have mounted a major offensive here, according to a high Angolan Government official. The offensive, the official indicated, has jeopardized a cease-fire agreement between Angola and the rebels.
LEAD: Ivan Lendl used masterful shot-making today to score a lopsided 6-1, 6-3 victory over John McEnroe and win the Player's International Canadian Open tournament.

LEAD: I didn't get your letter of June 9 until about 20 days after. I thought of answering your letter sooner, but I didn't feel like picking up my pen because I have been in low spirits.

LEAD: Conservationists were hopeful and developers fearful in July 1988 when the Government enacted a law intended to reverse the chaotic urbanization that has scarred much of Spain's coastline in the last 25 years.

LEAD: After a year of modest concessions by the Japanese Government and a difficult operating environment in Tokyo that has made profits scarce, the Wall Street firms and members of Congress who had vigorously fought to pry open Japan's financial markets have backed away from their demands.

LEAD: As an independent film maker scrambling for contributions, Karen Goodman felt a certain kinship, she says, with the street performers in her documentary ''No Applause, Just Throw Money.''

LEAD: The armed services and defense contractors have developed an elaborate game for selling expensive military hardware to Congress. LEAD: Charles A. Schoeneck Jr., a stalwart in New York State Republican politics, died Saturday at Crouse Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Syracuse.

LEAD: There has been much talk in political circles in recent years about the rapid shift in voter opinion that often takes place days before an election. These sudden shifts, usually in response to some news event or a last-minute attack, trouble many politicians who see the democratic process reduced to something as whimsical as a coin toss.

LEAD: A film producer was killed tonight when a water tower he was planning to topple while shooting a movie fell prematurely, the police said.

LEAD: There are two main differences between ''CNN Newsroom,'' Turner Broadcasting's daily 15-minute current affairs program for junior high and high schools, which made its debut last week, and ''Channel One,'' the offering from Whittle Communications, which had a tryout in six schools last spring. One is that ''CNN Newsroom'' carries no commercials, while every edition of ''Channel One'' contains two minutes of advertising.

LEAD: For more than 100 young people enjoying a summer night's boat party on the Thames, the dancing and chatting turned to a desperate struggle for survival early today when their pleasure vessel was sunk by a barge while cruising off central London.
LEAD: Palestinians armed with knives and axes hacked a Gaza man to death when he refused to hand over his Israeli-issued identity card, Arab reports said today.
LEAD: Ernest Riles hit a grand slam with two out in the ninth inning today, rallying the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch and city housing officials said yesterday that they would ask the Board of Estimate to approve a real-estate tax exemption for the Kings Bay 1 apartment complex, a Mitchell-Lama development in Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay section.

LEAD: Frank Assumma and J. Edmund Keating have been appointed executive vice presidents of Backer Spielvogel Bates.

LEAD: Not that any aspect of being the Yankees' manager is easy, but playing the Tigers was supposed to be the easy part of Bucky Dent's initiation.

An article about the report was carried by the Emirates News Agency on Thursday. The report said Tunisia, Morocco, Algeria and the United Arab Emirates followed as markets for such investments, estimated at a total of $232 million.

LEAD: Among the host of companies looking to cash in on the renewed emphasis on environmental issues, the SPX Corporation is in a fairly unusual situation.

LEAD: Even though more than 50,000 new books are published each year, they are not enough to feed the insatiable appetites of the large book clubs. So, more than ever, the clubs are now originating their own book titles.

Rabbi Allen Press and Canon Jonathan Young, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

LEAD: * Tristar Automotive Group, New Rochelle, N.Y., to North Castle Partners, Stamford, Conn., to advertise its 10 automobile dealerships, with a budget if $3 million to $4 million.

LEAD: Recent thefts from at least 13 university libraries of microfilm containing United States patent information have baffled librarians and prompted an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LEAD: Jane Elizabeth Veron, who is to start studies at Harvard University next month for a joint M.B.A. and law degree, and Andrew Todd Feldstein, a second-year law student at Harvard, were married yesterday. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated at Stouffer's Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

LEAD: Depending on the point of view, a new commercial initiative can be seen either as a magnanimous gesture aimed at curbing a cruel tradition and preventing rampant brain damage among American youngsters, or as a sinister plot designed to sabotage their proper development, rob them of their birthright and turn them into a bunch of spineless softies too timid to handle a hot one.

LEAD: Growing up in Boston as an avid Red Sox fan, Rick Ferroli dreamed of playing in Fenway Park and taking aim at the famed Green Monster. Though he pitched in high school and college and as a semipro, Ferroli never made it to Fenway as a player.

LEAD: As police sirens led air-conditioned buses and dark-windowed limousines through the streets of Tangier on Saturday night, few people here seemed to care whether the big bash at the palace on the hill was a real birthday party or simply a huge marketing extravaganza.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: It was an unfamiliar sight: a Southern Governor commuting the death sentence of a man he believed to be guilty.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that the Justice Department was investigating about 1,000 cases of possible wrongdoing at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Ronald Reagan's Administration.

LEAD: The Solidarity leader designated to be Poland's Prime Minister said today that he would consider giving the Communist Party more high-level Government posts than envisioned earlier, as the two sides appeared headed toward a period of hard bargaining on the new Cabinet.

LEAD: Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that unless Congress puts into effect the bipartisan agreement reached in April, the Government faces cuts in military and domestic spending of $16.2 billion for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

LEAD: A gunman was shot and killed by an undercover narcotics officer yesterday after the man fired four shots in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, the police said. LEAD: Chris Evert says she will retire from serious competition after this year's United States Open. ''No more 'maybes,' no more 'probablys,' '' Evert said in an article she wrote for the Aug. 28 issue of Sports Illustrated. ''The 1989 U.S. Open will be my final tournament.'' Evert, 34 years old, will still represent the United States in the Federation Cup in Tokyo in October.

LEAD: PEACHES fall into two categories, white and yellow, with many varieties of each color. A ripe white peach will be creamy gold, while a ripe yellow peach will be a deep, rich yellow. Both may be blushed with red, but neither will be tinged with green when truly ripe. The flesh of a ripe peach will yield to slight pressure and be tantalizingly aromatic.

LEAD: Floyd Youmans, who has been on the disabled list for much of his first season with the Philadelphia Phillies, had arthroscopic surgery on his pitching shoulder yesterday in Los Angeles and will not play again this season, the team physician, Dr. Phillip Marone, said. LEAD: The Giants released eight players today, reducing the squad to 67, but deciding little of the team's makeup for the opening game Sept. 11 in Washington.

LEAD: The Justice Department, the Iran-contra special prosecutor and a lawyer for a former high C.I.A. official face an important hearing today before the Federal Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va. LEAD: One tournament in two sites is an idea that makes sense, cutting down driving time for many who would like to participate. One disadvantage, affecting the experts, is that it is impossible to have a knockout team championship with a single winning team.

LEAD: A flyblown, ramshackle building, no more than a large lean-to, is home to the 10 men who defend a provincial air base of Colombia's anti-narcotics police. LEAD: A huge elevator on the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy ruptured a hydraulic line during an open house today, spraying oily fluid on visitors and causing a panic that resulted in dozens of injuries.

LEAD: The oil business, faced with government proposals to clean the air by replacing gasoline with methanol, compressed natural gas or electricity, is suddenly espousing a previously overlooked substitute: cleaner gasoline. The reformulated fuel announced by ARCO last week for older cars that run on leaded gas is only the beginning, the industry says.

''There was no fire, just smoke,'' said Joe Hopkins, an airline spokesman. Earlier reports from officials at the airport tower had said there was a fire.

LEAD: In an Administration where senior officials boast of being team players, efforts to articulate a new policy on Central America are being hampered by a conflict between rival experts on the region.

LEAD: NORTH American folk-art collectors and museums have discovered the arpillera, a South American wall hanging that depicts particular events as well as the hardships and joys of daily life. Arpillera is the Spanish word for burlap or sackcloth, the material used as the foundation for the needlework, which is executed in embroidery and appliques of gaily colored scraps of cloth.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today assailed his former House colleagues for cutting the military budget, saying they acted on the mistaken assumption that the Soviet military threat is diminishing.
LEAD: Sir James Goldsmith said today that he would sell the American insurance subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries to a French insurer for $4.5 billion if his bid for B.A.T. succeeded.

LEAD: Three weeks after reporting a sharp drop in second-quarter profits, the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 4,500 jobs this year, or about 3 percent of its work force, and sell some businesses.
LEAD: The Harken Energy Corporation, an energy development company, today offered to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation of San Antonio for $11.75 a share, or about $190 million, in cash.

LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation acknowledged yesterday that it had asked a number of its departments to plan for a 25 percent reduction in staff and a 10 percent cut in spending, but a company spokeswoman insisted the company was not planning layoffs.

LEAD: FOOTBALL 49ers 17, Chargers 14: Terrence Flagler scored on a 90-yard kickoff return as San Francisco beat San Diego yesterday in a preseason game at Candlestick Park in San Francisco. Jim McMahon was unimpressive in his first start for the Chargers, who acquired him from the Chicago Bears last Friday.
LEAD: To achieve Vic Damone in a dog-eat-dog match, Mr. Smooth must avoid Wedge City, control the yips and chips and steer the ball to the dance floor.

LEAD: Hungarian guards used dogs to tighten border control, but 250 East Germans still reached Austria overnight in the tide of escape from their Communist homeland, witnesses said today. Flight from East Germany through Hungary started in May, after the liberal Communist regime in Budapest began removing barbed wire and other obstacles from its border with Austria.

LEAD: For more than a generation, the dream of many poor Moroccans was to reach France and Belgium, where they understood the language and could easily disappear among the huge communities of North Africans long resident there.

LEAD: * Centel Cable Television Co., Chicago, said its shareholders had approved the company's merger with a new subsidiary that will allow Centel Cable to complete the sale of its operations.

LEAD: The Bundesbank's policy makers returned from a monthlong recess today to a familiar refrain in the foreign exchange market: speculation that the West German central bank will raise interest rates to bolster the value of the mark and rein in inflationary pressures.

LEAD: The United Airlines maintenance center here is the largest aircraft repair shop in the world, so big that it has been able to work on planes owned by more than 60 airline and military customers.

LEAD: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company was awarded a $149,000 bonus and a $25,000 raise the day after the utility's shareholders approved Lilco's plan to sell its Shoreham nuclear power plant.

LEAD: There is no telling how Colombia's current arrests of drug traffickers will affect cocaine exports - removing top executives of a business need not damage it if lieutenants are waiting to take over.

LEAD: The Government today replaced the president of Beijing University, China's most prestigious academic institution and the vanguard of the democracy movement last spring. The president, Ding Shisun, was regarded as a protector of his students, and his dismissal was widely forecast by students and faculty.

LEAD: More than 200 residents of a Gramercy Park apartment building that was heavily damaged in a steam-pipe explosion over the weekend were ordered from their homes last night after tests showed what a Consolidated Edison official called ''extremely high'' levels of asbestos fibers throughout the building.
LEAD: After a journey of 12 years and 4.4 billion miles, Voyager 2 streaked with astonishing accuracy tonight toward its planned rendezvous late Thursday with Neptune.

LEAD: Summer Sunday afternoons are not generally a prime theater time in New York City. And it was clear that the program charmed just about everyone in an audience whose age span ranged over some 60 years.
LEAD: Trying to insure that he will have two lines on the November ballot, Rudolph W. Giuliani has filed nominating petitions for a newly created party - the Independent Fusion Party.
LEAD: Sales of domestic cars rose 5.4 percent in mid-August, bolstered by incentive campaigns to clear inventories before the introduction of the 1990 models.

LEAD: Removing Wallpaper Q.I am in the process of removing three layers of wallpaper from a ceiling. The last layer of paper was painted over, and I cannot use a steamer because I want to preserve the finish on the walls. I bought a can of a liquid wallpaper remover, but I find that it does not penetrate the painted wallpaper very well and thus does not soften it enough for easy scraping.

LEAD: As part of its crackdown on the generic drug industry, the Food and Drug Administation announced today that it would inspect the plants of 20 additional large manufacturers of generic drugs.

LEAD: A 34-year-old man says the family of Representative Stewart B. McKinney, the Connecticut Congressman who died of AIDS two years ago, has reneged on a promise to let him keep property willed to him if he kept quiet about his gay relationship with Mr. McKinney.

LEAD: The disappearance, torture and killings of citizens by security forces and guerrillas in Peru have steadily risen the last 18 months, Amnesty International said today.

LEAD: The people of City Island have long been delighted to note that despite its name and despite where it is, hardly anything about the island is city-like.

LEAD: After weeks of negotiations, the directors of Time Warner Inc. yesterday announced the financing for the purchase of the remaining shares of Warner.

LEAD: Bronislaw Geremek is a Polish historian, a medievalist, who sees the contemporary politics of his country with uncanny clarity. Sixteen months ago he analyzed the Polish situation in terms that are now, to our astonishment, coming to life day by day.

LEAD: A Federal prosecutor in the tax-fraud trial of Leona Helmsley called yesterday for her conviction, declaring that the self-styled hotel queen had brazenly cheated the Government out of over a million dollars in taxes by putting herself above ''those little people'' who paid their taxes.

LEAD: As the economy slows across the New York metropolitan region and much of the Northeast, economists say Long Island is on the leading edge of the downturn. After a decade of explosive growth, the Island's bubble has burst.

LEAD: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, who turned 85 years old on Tuesday, is ill and is receiving special medical care in a beachside resort, Chinese officials and an East European diplomat say.

LEAD: The most extensive survey to date of the incidence of autism shows that the risk for a family with one autistic child of having another is far higher than had been thought.

Giuliani has yet to show his stuff on the tube. One may not learn much about the issues in 30 or 60 seconds - except that all parties agree on the need to be tough - but the way the candidates are using television exposes their weaknesses even while celebrating their strengths.

LEAD: For the first time since the early 1980's, Congress is considering sweeping legislation to force the Federal Reserve to shed some of its secrecy and be more accountable to Americans for its decisions that for better or worse steer the economy.

LEAD: TRW Inc. said today that it had reorganized its Space and Defense sector into four operating groups.

LEAD: A group of foreign and Mexican investors, led by Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, has bought a share of Mexico's largest airline and has an option to gain majority ownership.

''This is madness,'' Mr. Hynes mused, as he kept his smile in place.

It is expected that few will make the effort.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rallied yesterday as credit market participants responded favorably to the sale of $7.75 billion worth of new five-year Treasury notes.

LEAD: The chairman of the University of Maryland's Board of Regents has resigned over his role in causing the resignation of the new president of the system's Baltimore campus.

LEAD: Leaders of two Vietnam veterans organizations today criticized Brian De Palma's new film, ''Casualties of War,'' as a false portrayal of the soldiers who fought in that war.
LEAD: The Milwaukee Brewers acquired the veteran Ed Romero from the Atlanta Braves yesterday.

LEAD: The San Francisco Giants are doing the things that keep a team in first place. They are getting excellent pitching. They are hitting with power. And when their opponents make mental or physical errors, as the Mets did yesterday afternoon, the Giants are quick to capitalize.

LEAD: Calling Mayor Edward I. Koch, ''the best in a class field'' of Democratic mayoral candidates, The New York Post yesterday endorsed Mr. Koch in the Sept. 12 Democratic primary. It was the first of the four major daily newspapers in New York City to make an endorsement in the mayoral primary.

LEAD: An extraordinary plan to transfer development rights from Grand Central Terminal along a subsurface route to a site four blocks away, where they would have been used to construct one of the biggest buildings in New York City, was rejected unanimously yesterday by the New York City Planning Commission.

LEAD: Broadbeach Associates Inc., a private Los Angeles investment company, said it would be willing to raise its $89.8 million offer for the McGill Manufacturing Company if McGill were ''able to demonstrate to us that such additional value exists.'' McGill, based in Valparaiso, Ind., makes anti-friction bearings and electrical specialty items.

LEAD: Two months after its takeover by the WPP Group, Ogilvy & Mather has dismissed its entire mail-room staff and hired an outside service to do the job. Robert Bou, a former mail-room supervisor, said the staff of 18 were summoned to a meeting on Monday and told their services were no longer needed. '
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: TO everything horticultural there is a season. A garden that registers neither winter nor summer contradicts the order of nature - no wilting of blooms, no browning of leaves, no changing from the bright bulbs of spring to the mauve-tinted hydrangeas of fall.

LEAD: A House panel investigating favoritism and mismanagement in Federal housing programs said today it had asked the chairman of Paine Webber Inc. to testify about the firm's consulting arrangements with the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
LEAD: To The Home Section:
LEAD: * Analysis and Technology Inc., North Stonington, Conn., named Jay W. Ryerson senior vice president and John P. Cretella vice president.
LEAD: As a French naval task force assembled off Lebanon today, a military command of Muslim and leftist militias threatened to treat the French vessels as a ''military target.''
LEAD: The Public Broadcasting System and the Cable News Network plan to carry live pictures of Neptune taken by Voyager 2 as the spacecraft passes the planet early tomorrow morning.

LEAD: The Congressional Budget Office has further increased estimates of the cost of the program to insure the elderly against the catastrophic expenses of serious illnesses under Medicare, a Congressional aide said tonight.
LEAD: Elevated levels of chromium have been found in the urine of 35 of 97 children tested after their elementary school was ordered closed in May because of the presence of the toxic metal.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Barneys New York, the big clothier based in Manhattan, confirmed today that it planned to open a large store in Chicago as part of an ambitious expansion.

LEAD: The ''green card,'' which has not actually been green for years, is taking on a new color and other characteristics, largely as part of a Government effort to stem a black market in alien certification.

Asbestos at Blast Site Asbestos was found at a Manhattan apartment building damaged in a steam-pipe blast Saturday, and residents were evacuated.

LEAD: A BUOYANT Sir James Goldsmith voiced confidence yesterday that his problems with American insurance regulators were close to being resolved. He seemed to hint that it was those problems that had prevented him from putting up any cash in his bid to take over B.A.T. Industries.

LEAD: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola asserted today that the country's two-month-old cease-fire is in jeopardy because the United States and South Africa continue to arm guerrilla forces.

LEAD: Companies Eastman Kodak said it would eliminate 4,500 jobs, about 3 percent of its work force, and sell some businesses. The company also said it would cut management salaries by up to 40 percent. The announcement came three weeks after Kodak reported a sharp drop in second-quarter earnings.

LEAD: Early one morning last week, several hundred Roman Catholic priests gathered in a Manhattan movie theater to preview ''Romero,'' a film about the life of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador, who was assassinated in 1980 by a gunman believed to have been a member of a right-wing death squad.

LEAD: WITH the exception of Ernest & Julio Gallo and a few other giants, the American wine industry has never done much advertising. Most wineries cannot afford it, and others say word of mouth remains the best way to promote prestigious products.

LEAD: It seemed like a good idea when the Lincoln Center Out of Doors summer arts festival announced it would present a two-part program on the relationship of American jazz and dance. The program was to open with ''Scat Dancing,'' developed by Larry Ridley and C. Scobey Stroman for the American Dance Festival in 1981 and 1982.

LEAD: - A South Orange Village police officer was shot tonight while chasing two burglary suspects, village officials and witnesses said. The officer, whose name was not released, was taken into surgery at University Hospital in Newark, the Village President, Roger Ross, said. Residents of Holland Road, where the shooting occurred, said an officer was chasing two men suspected of robbing a home when one turned and fired, striking the officer.

LEAD: ROBERT WOOLLEY craves beautiful things, and as director of the decorative arts division of Sotheby's, he has access to them. His eight-room apartment on Fifth Avenue at 96th Street is crammed with antique china, architectural drawings, maps, furniture, wooden walking sticks and more. But some of his favorite objets d'art came not from auction houses but from pet stores.

LEAD: The Grumman Corporation said it would close Tachonics, a division based in Plainsboro, N.J., that makes gallium arsenide computer chips. Tachonics, which had 47 employees and has been unprofitable since its start in 1985, is the third gallium arsenide company in a year to be shut down. Gallium arsenide is a material that can be used to make chips that are faster than those made with silicon.

LEAD: Dallas Green's dismissal as Yankee manager took place six days ago, but there is apparently some lingering anger over remarks he is reported to have made in its aftermath. Lou Piniella and Billy Martin, former Yankee managers, issued statements yesterday criticizing Green, and George Steinbrenner, the team owner, said he was severing future ties with the former manager.
LEAD: MODERN FARM, a mail-order catalogue, has just the thing for keeping track of cow-milking schedules or breeding records. The folding Barn Desk, below, can also be used in the kitchen or garage.
LEAD: Rick Dempsey's leadoff homer in the 22d inning gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 1-0 victory over the Montreal Expos tonight in the second-longest shutout in major league history.

LEAD: The Hilton Hotel Corporation sweetened its relationship with McCann-Erickson yesterday to the tune of $5 million. The company awarded the account for its Flamingo Hilton hotels in Nevada to the Los Angeles office of McCann, which has been its agency of record since 1967. McCann will create advertising for three hotels in Nevada: the Flamingo-Hilton Reno, the Flamingo Hilton-Laughlin and the giant Flamingo Hilton on the Las Vegas strip.

LEAD: The children of Herman and Frances McMillan have told officials their father buried their two dead brothers in a playground a short walk from their apartment in the Bronx, not in an embankment on the Major Deegan Expressway, as Mr. McMillan said after his arrest on Monday.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said its Chicago assembly plant would end production of 1989-model Taurus and Sable cars on Sept. 1, a week earlier than planned, because orders from its dealers had dropped. The company said the 2,500 employees there would return to work on Sept. 11, the first day of production of the 1990 models.

LEAD: Doing the Fugs The Fugs, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). The Fugs, the once-notorious, now-venerated East Village band led by the poet Ed Sanders, still makes seriously zany mischief. The group's show tonight is likely to include excerpts from Mr. Sanders' anti-Pentagon opera, ''Starpeace,'' anarchistic broadsides by Tuli Kupferberg, and a medley of the group's smutty underground hits from its earliest days in the mid-1960's.

LEAD: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins' quarterback, will be sidelined for 8 to 10 weeks after surgery today, the team announced yesterday.

LEAD: The Mets begin a nine-game West Coast trip tonight in San Diego. They will play three games against the Padres, three at Los Angeles and three at San Francisco.

LEAD: It would be easy to wrap ''The Little Thief'' in nostalgia, to treasure it as the last legacy of Francois Truffaut. Before his death in 1984, Truffaut had written, with Claude de Givray, a brief scenario for the story of Janine, a neglected, spirited, imaginative adolescent of the 1950's. He had invented the girl more than 20 years before as Antoine Doinel's companion in ''The 400 Blows,'' but had cut the character from that film and carried her image to the end of his life.

LEAD: Although the Dow Jones industrial average reached a high yesterday, Wall Street remains a far more subdued place than it was at the 1987 peak. LEAD: Don Mattingly showered and dressed, but the frustration did not wash away. He struck out three times last night, and the Yankees lost again. When the night was done, their new manager even suggested that some players were pressing.

LEAD: ''I'm not one of those women's libbers.'' The sentence sounds like a joke now, a laugh-getter out of ''All in the Family.'' But not so long ago it was a sentiment shared by millions. Many men felt they had nothing to gain from feminism - and many women felt they had everything to lose. To the latter, the women's movement that began in the 1960's was more a threat than a promise.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to forbid musicians and others from using amplifiers on New York City subway platforms, saying the excessive noise they produce can ''interfere with transit operations'' - not to mention drive some people crazy.
LEAD: A man described by police as a drug dealer has admitted killing Huey P. Newton, the co-founder of the Black Panthers, the police said tonight.

LEAD: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that he would reject a Federal judge's request that he join a dispute in Ohio on the terms of a proposed $78 million pollution settlement between the department and neighbors of the nuclear weapons plant in the town of Fernald.

LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration says it has no plans to ask the Defense Department to delay one of its space shuttle missions so that the rescue of an errant satellite can take place in November rather than December.

LEAD: The rate of death from breast cancer in the United States is increasing and it is highest in the Northern states, Federal health officials say.

LEAD: After a wide search using troops and helicopters, soldiers found an Israeli jeweler alive and healthy today at the bottom of a 20-foot well in a West Bank village, a day after he was kidnapped by masked Palestinians, the army said.
LEAD: Physicians have long prescribed allopurinol for people who suffer from gout. Now three entomologists think it may be a formidable weapon against cockroaches.

LEAD: The New York City police yesterday searched intensively for an 18-year-old white youth who they believe may have shot to death 16-year-old Yusef Hawkins in a racial attack Wednesday night in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

LEAD: The judge in the trial of Leona Helmsley and two co-defendants told jurors yesterday that in trying to reach a verdict they should not be swayed by emotions or any personal feelings they might have about the defendants' backgrounds and life styles.

LEAD: A class action suit has been filed against the Anchor Glass Container Corporation over its rejection of a $280 million takeover proposal from Vitro S.A. The shareholder suit, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, seeks to block Anchor Glass from taking any defensive action to thwart the Vitro tender offer.
LEAD: ''Wow! What a way to leave the solar system!'' - Dr. Laurence Soderblom, geologist on the Voyager team. [ 1:6. ]

LEAD: John Nelson has resigned as the music director of the Caramoor Music Festival, the management announced yesterday. He left to ''pursue other interests,'' said Susan Spier, a spokeswoman for the festival. A decision as to a replacement has not yet been made.

LEAD: Late selling sent the prices of Treasury securities tumbling yesterday. The sales, which dealers said came in two waves, quickly erased the modest gains posted early in the session, which were attributed largely to European demand.

LEAD: For all car travel, even short trips to and from the local grocery or pool, the safest way to transport young children is in a safety seat in the rear of the car. Small children, usually up to the age of 4, are required by law in every state to ride in approved seats designed for children, and the seats must be secured by safety belts.
LEAD: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins' quarterback, was listed in good condition yesterday after undergoing surgery to repair a herniated disk, the team announced.

LEAD: A guide dog would have seen the danger and prevented Tony Candela from walking into a bent traffic sign Thursday morning, an accident that left a nasty gash in his forehead. His cane provides surveillance only of the lower altitudes.

LEAD: Top officers of the Chicago Board of Trade did not benefit from the exchange's decision last month to order an emergency liquidation of positions in the soybean market, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said in a preliminary report today.

LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company announced plans to double the production capacity for its artificial sweetener products, which are marketed in more than 70 countries.

LEAD: Speeding away from its fourth and last planetary encounter, Voyager 2 today left jubilant scientists agog as they viewed new photographs showing in dazzling clarity Neptune and especially its largest moon, Triton, where frozen lakes and ridges bespeak a past of slow-flowing icy volcanism never before seen in the solar system.

LEAD: After nearly a decade of poor spawning years, the Chesapeake Bay's striped bass have produced a host of offspring.

LEAD: PEOPLE usually go to Pagan just to admire and photograph the dead city's glorious temples and pagodas. Said to number as many as 5,000, they date from the 11th to the 13th centuries. Pagan, stretched out across the plain on the east bank of the Irrawaddy River, 350 miles north of Yangon, formerly Rangoon, is one of the most spectacular archeological sites in the world.

LEAD: The biennial theater of the World festival, recently on view in Hamburg, is one of several heavily subsidized, extremely selective European festivals aimed at the audience of connoisseurs that has been created by the easy availability of first-rate European theater. It visits a different West German city on each occasion - Frankfurt four years ago, Stuttgart two years ago, Essen next.

LEAD: AFTER the Aug. 13 performance of ''They're Playing Our Song'' at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor, the eight-member cast quit the show. Three day later, a new company took over in the Marvin Hamlisch-Neil Simon musical, which is scheduled to run through Sept. 17. What sets the two casts apart is that the first consisted of members of Actors' Equity, the union of professional actors and stage managers; the new cast does not.
LEAD: Beirut was quiet except for occasional gunfire today as a Soviet envoy pursued efforts for a cease-fire.

LEAD: Morris Seldin's letter ''Cheap Power is Misleading'' (Aug. 6) is itself misleading and misinformed. His statements that ''publicly owned utility plants pay no taxes'' and that the taxes on the residents of Rockville Centre ''have to be increased to make up for the loss'' are simply wrong.

LEAD: As his long white prayer robe hung limply in the late summer heat, Mohammed Mezgualdi stepped carefully over the chunks of concrete, broken timbers and shattered roof tiles. ''Here was where I used to teach the children,'' the Muslim cleric said, pointing to a room that looked as if it had been ravaged by war.

LEAD: Ending the slight suspense early, Jeannie Longo of France jumped away in the third of six laps and cruised to a solitary and easy victory today in the world championship road race for female bicycle riders.

LEAD: Although we talk about the Roaring Twenties and the explosive 60's, who can say what a decade really means, and when an era actually begins and ends? We have been living in the 1980's for almost 10 years, yet they show no signs of ending. Then there is the problem of how to judge a decade - especially one that is still happening.

LEAD: WHEN they ponder their good fortune to be living and working here and now, planetary scientists sometimes speak of this as the golden age in the exploration of the solar system. Planets once no more than points of light have finally been visited by spacecraft and photographed in striking detail. For the first time, they have emerged as distinct and varied worlds.

LEAD: THE heat of curry seems to wake summer appetites. Spicy seasonings are often characteristic in regions with hot climates, and curry - or the spices like pepper, cumin, turmeric, ginger and others that make up the blend - is no exception.
LEAD: With a variety of issues on the agenda but none urgent, members of the International Olympic Committee opened their 95th congress today with six days of meetings to follow.

LEAD: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew. Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off. We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks.

LEAD: American officials say that Hojatolislam Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a fundamentalist Shiite cleric fighting for a place in Iran's new Government, has been a leading figure in Iran's support for terrorist actions against Western countries over the last decade.

LEAD: ALONG Center Road three miles out of Vermont's capital, Richard Atkinson's dairy farm unfolds across a hill, where streams rush cold and clear and gnarled sugar maples are just starting to turn the colors of autumn. Twice a day, the tall farmer leads his 40 Jersey cows down the hill to be milked in a bright yellow barn.

LEAD: IT is a jungle down there. Beneath the 23 square miles of Manhattan are 11 million miles of telephone wire, 19,000 miles of electrical cable, 6,000 miles of water mains, 4,000 miles of gas lines, 100 miles of cable television wiring and 105 miles of steam pipes. And that is not all that is stretched over, under and around subway tunnels, sewage lines and passages barely big enough to crawl through.

LEAD: OPHELIA AND THE GREAT IDEA. By Deborah Levy. (Viking, $16.95.) In the title story of this collection by the young British playwright Deborah Levy, one character glosses the eponymous ''great idea'': ''To invent a time and place of your own.'' To this end, Ms. Levy has discarded the traditional props of plot and unified setting.

LEAD: ''WHEN are you coming home this summer?'' asked my mother. ''Home'' is Lansing, Mich., and it has not really been my home for nearly 25 (Is that possible?) years. No matter. Most adults approach these journeys home with a mixture of anticipation and boredom - anticipation (at least on my part) of seeing much-loved relatives, boredom at the prospect of being stuck in a place frozen in memory as an incubator of youthful dreams rather than a living community.

LEAD: In ''Those Tailgate Terrorists'' (Opinion page, July 2), Terence M. Ripmaster spun a tale of terror largely the result of the supposed driving habits of young drivers in sports cars. While I agree with him on the emotional effect that such automotive encounters can produce, I cannot let stand his assertion that these ''terrorists'' are largely in the under-21 set.

LEAD: ITALY is a country of arches. Walking through nearly any Italian city or town, the eye glides across the scenery not in straight lines but in gentle arcs, weaving patterns of dramatic shadows in the abundant sunlight and slowing the eye down to Italy's leisurely pace.
LEAD: A NEW era begins at the Neuberger Museum tomorrow when Dominique Nahas assumes his post as director of the 15-year-old institution here, on the campus of the State University of New York.

LEAD: The current market rally may prompt more investors to call their stockbrokers for advice. Unfortunately, most brokers pay serious attention to only a handful of clients, and chances are you are not one of them - even if you have $50,000 or more in securities. Further, if you don't know how to work with a broker, even paying a steady flow of commissions won't necessarily win the broker's constant attention.

LEAD: As a golfer, Eddie (the Eagle) Edwards turns out to be at least as good as he is as a ski jumper.

LEAD: Even with the new openness, the Soviet Union is not the sort of place where you can jump in a car and drive off into the sunset. You need to plan a car trip well ahead of time, and to stick to the itinerary you have agreed to. All this is worth a trip with no parking meters or toll booths, some beautiful countryside, intriguing places and a sense of unmapped adventure.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.
LEAD: The jury in the Helmsley tax-fraud trial began deliberating yesterday.
LEAD: JUST as it's beginning to take off, the New Jersey Theater Jubilee may be coming to a halt.

LEAD: IT was the largest of all the tomatoes that survived the foraging raids of the deer on my garden this summer. I found it almost hidden from view among the drooping branches of a withered tomato plant. It was huge, this beefsteak tomato, ripe, red and luscious. The kind that drips down your chin when you take a bite.
LEAD: The Evangelical Lutheran Church of America has decided to make sure dissenting voices are heard when the new denomination makes a pronouncement on a social issue.
LEAD: To the Editor: The Practical Traveler column about Trek Preparation (July 30) summarized realistically the appropriate preparation for such trips.

His first hit, ''Wild Thing,'' is the second-best-selling single in the history of popular music, after the charity record ''We Are the World.'' With two million singles sold, as well as five million copies of his debut album, Tone
LEAD: A new coat can bring a wardrobe into focus. Though the weather is still warm, many women are already eyeing the new, chic shearlings.

LEAD: Federal officials have been meeting with city officials, representatives of the N.A.A.C.P. and others to resolve a dispute over whether the police used excessive force against black students after a dance that ended in looting on the city's main street.

LEAD: When Adella Gray was dismissed as the academic adviser to the University of Arkansas football team shortly after Ken Hatfield took over as coach in 1985, Gray, who had held the position for three years, was convinced she was the victim of sex discrimination.

LEAD: No one had ever heard of AIDS when Mayor Edward I. Koch took office in 1978, although the deadly virus was already silently spreading through New York City. Today, the scourge of AIDS poses a citywide health-care crisis and has emerged as a sharply disputed issue in the mayoral campaign.

LEAD: MY family and I touched an Angel last summer. For years I had been fascinated with the Fresh Air Fund's concept of taking children from the city and exposing them to the country and to different values and customs. Now, for the first time, we were able to participate in the experience of welcoming a city child into our home.

LEAD: It defies logical explanation, but there's something irresistible about pictures that are long and skinny. They're commonly called panoramas, since they include a wide sweep of scenery. Photographers have been making them almost from the moment that photography entered the world 150 years ago.
LEAD: Benjamin F. Rogers, a medical publisher, died of cancer Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and lived in Huntington, L.I.

LEAD: Someone is killing off all the writers on the Puerto Rican island paradise of Vieques in MAY'S NEWFANGLED MIRTH (Bantam, Paper, $3.50). The first victim is a Pulitzer Prize-winning American poet. An alcoholic author of pornographic trash is the next scribbler silenced. Shortly after Detective Balthazar Marten, the ''unnervingly competent'' hero of four earlier procedurals in this wonderful series, arrives from San Juan to investigate, a travel writer disappears.

LEAD: Tipping the Guide Question: How does one tip adventure travel guides? - J. M., Stowe, Vt. Answer: Tipping on such trips is never mandatory but almost always appreciated if participants feel a guide has done a good job. The best approach is before you leave to to ask the tour company for guidelines on tipping.

LEAD: JAPAN: In the Land of the Brokenhearted. By Michael Shapiro. (Holt, $19.95.) Perhaps no country makes a foreigner feel more conscious of his foreignness than Japan. For foreigners who seek fulfillment by submerging themselves in another culture, it represents the ultimate challenge. As Michael Shapiro shows in his insightful book, ''Japan,'' it is a challenge they can never entirely meet.

LEAD: Terrace Cookout Question: I have seen newspaper articles recently about people cooking outdoors on apartment terraces and on balconies and in back yards. I thought terrace cooking was illegal. Is it? . . . B. K., Manhattan Answer: Yes. According to a spokesman for the New York City Fire Department, fire rules prohibit the use of grills of any kind inside houses, apartments or garages or on any apartment balcony, terrace or roof.

LEAD: To the Editor: I'm sure you know how dangerous it is on the highways when it rains. Most of the hazard is created by trucks, which frequently go beyond the speed limit and throw a heavy spray onto passenger cars. This is particularly troublesome when the trucks are large and their wheels high. In a heavy storm, and at night, there can be long moments when visibility for drivers of smaller cars is almost nil.

LEAD: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew. Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off. We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks.

LEAD: Keith Hernandez, the symbol of the Mets' summer of pain, conceded today that this had been a year of trial both for him and his teammates and admitted that he was concerned about his future. But he said, ''I know I can play, and I'd like to finish my career in New York.''

LEAD: Dan Yaron, a 70-year-old Israeli whose parents died in Nazi concentration camps, has translated Hitler's ''Mein Kampf'' into Hebrew for Israeli youth. But in so doing he has touched feelings that run so deep here that he cannot find anyone who is willing to publish it.
LEAD: For This Week: Continue planting, harvesting and ordering bulbs, perennials and shrubs for fall planting, which will go on as long as the good weather holds. Pruning

LEAD: The wedding of Juliette Laddon Robbins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Robbins of Troy, N.Y., to Edward Bingham Bland, a son of Mrs. Richard H. Downes of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the late James Edward Bland, took place yesterday at the Braintree Hill (Vt.) Meeting House. The Rev. Richard H. Downes, an Episcopal priest and the stepfather of the bridegroom, officiated.
LEAD: Nancy Lynne Baker and Dr. Peter T. Clement were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Ithaca, N.Y., by the Rev. David Shew.
LEAD: Steinbrenner has extinguished the spark from Don Mattingly's eyes and created an environment that caused Yogi Berra to refuse to enter Yankee Stadium.

LEAD: IN a section of the State Police Forensics Laboratory, an investigator cautiously removes fingerprints from a series of bombs. In another room, a photographer takes pictures of a telephone receiver that has been dusted for fingerprints. In one of the other 14 divisions, three scientists examine tiny bits of glass and hair, while nearby in the arson room, fire debris is analyzed.

LEAD: Ruth Folz, a daughter of Lea Seluque Folz of Rio de Janeiro, and Joseph Cox Ballantyne, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Merrill Ballantyne of Ithaca, N.Y., were married yesterday at the temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Manti, Utah. Wilbur Wallace Cox, the bridegroom's grandfather and past president of the Manti temple, officiated.

LEAD: I started collecting journalism novels six years ago, just for fun at first, or maybe because I was flattered that fiction writers would find my chosen career so alluring, so full of possibilities. But what had begun as little more than a vague attraction soon took hold of me, tightened its grip and turned this meandering, benign pursuit into an obsession.

LEAD: Whether it serves as an aid to education is debatable. But for the class of '93, now heading for the campus, a stereo system counts among the required scholarly paraphernalia, like a library card or a tennis racquet.

LEAD: ''There is something going on in the South Bronx that is not all crack, burned-out buildings and poverty,'' Karen Washington said the other day as she looked out over a blooming garden she helped cultivate in what was once a rubble-strewn lot. ''We are doing something with nature and giving it back to the community.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The irony would probably be too much for Willie Randolph to tolerate. In his 13 seasons with the Yankees, Randolph played second base next to 31 different players at shortstop, from Aguayo and Alomar to Zeber and Zuvella. Bucky Dent served the longest of the horde (nearly six seasons), but after he departed in August 1982, 18 of those 31 players served as

LEAD: It was shortly past midnight the other night when a mortar shell ripped through the roof of Felismina Castilho's adobe hut. Shrapnel from the explosion tore a hole in her right thigh. Her parents, sleeping in a room next door, were killed.

LEAD: California's South Coast Air Quality Management District may be calling for a car-pooling requirement in southern California. But whatever progress might be made in reducing the number of cars will be offset by the numbers of new tenants in the many high-rise buildings under construction. The City of Los Angeles and the Community Redevelopment Agency have approved this new construction without regard to the effect it will have on air quality in the downtown area.

LEAD: JULIA HEALY comes well recommended by John Perreault, who, formerly director of Snug Harbor's Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, remains the eminence grise of the Staten Island scene. Indeed, in his introduction to the artist's show at the Museum of the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, he frankly applauds her painting.

LEAD: Even in a record industry newly energized by the CD revolution, the emergence of the Italian Nuova Era label as a potent force, particularly in the field of complete operas, counts as an extraordinary phenomenon. While the company's rapid growth from modest beginnings in 1985 to its substantial catalogue today may stem from having the right manufacturing and distributing facilities at the right time, its success owes just as much to a combination of marketing skill, imagination and dedication.

LEAD: Walter Klien has played in America for 20 years without exactly becoming a central figure in our concert life. He is not a showy interpreter, for one thing, and for another he sticks in the memory as a library-style recording artist (the complete piano music of Brahms, of Mozart, of Schubert. . . .

LEAD: FIFTY FEET ABOVE dirt and talus, I plaster myself to a vertical wall of rock. I lift my way against the unfamiliar demands of gravity, calling on joints and muscles that suddenly seem inflexible and weak. My novice's eye can hardly make out the slender juts of stone above me that must serve as holds for hand and foot - and it requires a great leap of faith to believe in them.

LEAD: ONCE, years ago, I was on a bus tour out of San Francisco that stopped for a halfhour in Carmel. In that brief exposure to the resort's main shopping street, I was bombarded with beauty: Venetian glass, Scottish cashmere, Chinese jade, French porcelain . . . everything in unrelentingly exquisite taste.

LEAD: The Khmer empire ruled southeast Asia for centuries, but in the last two hundred years the Khmer homeland, Cambodia, has been torn apart by its former vassals. In the 1960's Cambodia tried to strike a balance between the forces of Vietnam and the United States by playing her China card.
