The change has been brought about in part by legislation last year giving the military a role in controlling drug traffic and in part by a change in attitude in the leadership at the

LEAD: The white corn is in; the zucchini are flourishing. The question was how to combine them and turn them into a dish that, for a change, did not require tomatoes, a dish that would make a meal with little effort and a minimum of pots.

LEAD: Of course not. We Brooklyn Dodger fans haven't had this much fun since the '55 World Series. We thoroughly enjoy watching those proud Yankee followers squirming and sweating over their team's misadventures. WILLIAM J. ASH Westhampton, L.I.

LEAD: REUNION: A Memoir, by Tom Hayden. (Collier/Macmillan, $12.95.) The Chicago Seven defendant who married Jane Fonda tells about a time long ago when children of the affluent briefly found common cause with Black Panthers and thought they could start a revolution. Last year our reviewer, Paul Berman, said this autobiography is ''evocative, wordy, sometimes inconsistent.

LEAD: Q. Last summer, we installed a brick patio, but after a couple of months the patio developed mildew. Each time we washed this mildew off with a solution of one part bleach and three parts water; however, during the winter, the bricks turned a kind of whitish color, which would not wash off. We don't know whether this loss of color is because of the bleach we used, or because of efflorescence of the bricks.

LEAD: It was at the United States Open in 1971 that Chris Evert burst onto the tennis scene, reaching the semifinals as a 16-year-old, and it will be after this year's Open that she will close out serious competition as a 34-year-old. ''No more 'maybes,' '' Ms. Evert wrote in Sports Illustrated. She has won more matches and more tournaments than any other player, male or female, including the United States Open six times, Wimbledon three times, the Australian Open twice and the French Open a record seven times.

LEAD: No. He should be forced to obey the Constitution and emancipate them. ASHLEY SIMMONS New York

LEAD: WHEN more than 700 Greenburgh residents gathered at a public hearing in February last year to comment on a housing project for the homeless that was to be built on six wooded acres in their town, they had little information to rely on but knew they were against it.

LEAD: AMBITIOUS plans for expanding the Town Center mall and building a new Lord & Taylor mall outside the central business district, plus moderating office vacancies and a major refinancing of the city's oldest office tower, are lifting the clouds that have hung over Stamford's commercial real estate for more than a year.

LEAD: WHEN I was a young married woman, family holidays were pretty near-perfect, but until recently I never thought of analyzing the reason. My spouse and I simply drove upstate to one of our parents' houses, where we joined other jolly relatives for days of carefree fun and legendary meals.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is bracing for what it fears could be a new diplomatic crisis over whether to grant the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, a visa to attend a forthcoming session of the United Nations this fall.

LEAD: THE concert lineup for fall is becoming known, and it will include a special nonsubscription concert by the Hartford Symphony to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the first manned moon landing.

LEAD: Less than two weeks after President Bush signed the monumental bailout bill for the savings and loan industry, Federal regulators are suggesting that the money provided by taxpayers and the industry might not be enough.

LEAD: HANNAH. By Paul-Loup Sulitzer. Translated by Christine Donougher. (Poseidon, $18.95.) Since Paul-Loup Sulitzer has already published novels entitled ''Cash,'' ''Money,'' ''Fortune'' and ''The Green King,'' it seems safe to say that he's not uncomfortable airing his personal preoccupation with wealth.
LEAD: For almost as long as he can remember, the St. Louis Cardinal pitcher Joe Magrane has had one baseball dream.

LEAD: Catherine McFarland Sandler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Sadler of Columbia, S.C., and Capt. Thomas Cornelius McFadden Jr., U.S.A.F., Medical Corps, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McFadden of Basking Ridge, N.J., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Trinity Cathedral in Columbia.

Raimondi Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Raimondi of Lewiston, N.Y., were married there yesterday at the Niagra University Chapel. The Rev. John Maher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Raimondi, 25 years old, is a nurse at Syosset (L.I.) General Hospital.

LEAD: Upper-class English culture is securely rooted in the nanny. If you lunch in a Pall Mall club, you will find the menu degenerating, as it reaches the sweet course, into nursery food - bread and butter pudding, jam roll and custard, suety lumps covered with treacle - and you can almost hear nanny's voice ordering you to eat it all up.

LEAD: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass., Elizabeth Brooks Emmons, a daughter of Diane Neal Emmons of Manchester, Mass., and Robert Wales Emmons Jr. of Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to Terrence Michael Dunn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Dunn of Mountain Lakes, N.J. The Rev.

LEAD: Paraguay asked Brazil on Friday to extradite Gustavo Stroessner, son of the deposed Paraguayan dictator Alfredo Stroessner, to face charges of extortion and other crimes. An official at the Paraguayan Embassy said his country formally petitioned Brazil to turn over the 46-year-old former air force colonel, who is assumed to be living in Brasilia.

LEAD: Top Soviet and American scientists, environmentalists, policymakers, industry leaders and artists today urged President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to form an ''environmental security alliance'' to reverse what they fear could be a catastrophic warming of the planet.
LEAD: Darrell Blow hooked a four-inch-long crayfish with a worm he had dug from the banks of the pond. In Central Park.

LEAD: WITH more than $50 million in public and private funds committed thus far, city planners in this Michigan city have outlined a 25-year development plan for land adjacent to the downtown business district along the Saginaw River near its mouth on Lake Huron.

LEAD: Joanne Amy Wise, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerold Wise of Newton, Mass., and Franconia, N.H., and Carlo Resta, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Remo Resta of Rome and San Felice Circeo, Italy, were married yesterday. Justice of the Peace Edward English of Newton performed the ceremony at the Newton home of the bride's parents.

LEAD: It is just 100 years since the death of Gerard Manley Hopkins, S.J., and about 60 years since I first read him. Those were the days when to read ''Ulysses'' was to break the law. Modernism was dangerous, and one of the marks of modernism was strangeness of language. Hopkins, like James Joyce, had bizarre compound words like ''beadbonny'' and ''fallowboot-fellow''; he seemed to be dragging the Germanic roots of English out of freshly dug earth.
LEAD: Of all the changes made by Mikhail Gorbachev in the name of glasnost, the most important may be his steps toward truth in history. Important, and unsettling in their consequences.

LEAD: Alycia Maria Peloso, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. X. Peloso of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael John Crane, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Crane of Woodhaven, Queens. Msgr. William T. White performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Holy Family.

LEAD: Two leading Democratic strategists said today that members of Representative Barney Frank's own party are likely to ask for a formal House investigation in the aftermath of his admission of an 18-month association with a male prostitute.

LEAD: ''Danzas de la Tierra,'' presented on Friday at the McGinn/Cazale Theater, was a thoroughly enjoyable evening of flamenco, tap and Near Eastern dance, scheduled, sadly, for only one performance. It would be nice to see it as a fixture in this ideally small theater, particularly during the summer doldrums.
LEAD: These days, a loyal guest of a hotel gets more than a bed and a bath. Such ''regulars'' receive everything from scarves and Tiffany stationery to all-expenses-paid vacations.

LEAD: THE demand for organically grown vegetables coupled with a desire to help local farmers has prompted some consumers to try a new approach to produce shopping. They are in effect buying a subscription to the crops. A result is a guaranteed supply of fresh vegetables during the growing season and an assured income for growers.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A young man from a poor Hispanic neighborhood who went to Harvard University was sentenced Friday to 10 years in prison for six armed robberies during school breaks.

LEAD: The Rolling Stones announce that they're back with the two triumphal chords that start ''Sad Sad Sad'' and open the album ''Steel Wheels'' (Columbia 45333; all three formats). Those two syncopated chords, like a rock ''Amen,'' are the ones that kicked ''Jumping Jack Flash,'' ''Honky Tonk Women'' and ''Start Me Up'' into gear; they're a Stones trademark, and Keith Richards's guitar makes them sound brash, slick, edgy, poised, offhand, jubilant and nasty, all at once.

LEAD: Salomon Vallecilo, a 34-year-old factory worker and labor leader, left his house in a working-class neighborhood here on July 4 to take a 6 A.M. bus to work. He passed a nightclub on his left and, on his right, an assassin, who was reading a newspaper in the shade of a small almond tree.

LEAD: TROPHY FOR EAGLES. By Walter J. Boyne. (Crown, $19.95.) Walter J. Boyne, the author of 10 books on aviation, has written an 11th book on aviation, thickly disguised as a novel. It concerns airplanes and people, real and imaginary, of the period 1927-37, a glorious era for aviation but for Western humanity a slog through the sloughs of depression and totalitarianism, emerging in war.
LEAD: The head of the Soviet K.G.B. met with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki today and said the new Polish leader was ''a solid man'' who will succeed in solving the nation's problems.

LEAD: New Jersey's expensive automobile insurance system, a target of motorists' anger since it was established in 1983, has also become a fertile ground for fraud investigations by Federal and state agencies.

LEAD: Nathan Susskind, a New Jersey lawyer and philanthropist, died of cancer Friday at Bayonne (N.J.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Bayonne.

LEAD: Delegates to the Veterans of Foreign Wars 90th annual convention elected Walter Hogan on Friday as their commander-in-chief. Mr. Hogan, a Greenfield, Wis., resident who served in the Korean War as an Army infantry squad leader, replaced Larry W. Rivers as head of the 2.1 million-member veterans' organization.

LEAD: It could have been almost any day this summer because the rain fell in such quantity it was like being sloshed with buckets of water. But actually it was just a short time ago, and Benedicte de Vleeschauwer was at a cocktail party at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park looking elegant and cocktail-partyish, a slender stalk in a turquoise, burgundy and white silk kimono balanced on a pair of black and white patent pumps.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: AIDS in the Mayor's Race When Mayor Edward I. Koch took office in 1978, no one had heard of AIDS.

LEAD: Tulsa, a young, sophisticated city on the edge of the prairie, revels in its heritage, the Indian, the cowboy, but predominantly in oil, which propelled it from cow town to ''oil capital of the world.'' Today, that boastful sobriquet is more nostalgia than fact. The oil business is both depressed and headquartered elsewhere.

LEAD: In its strongest response yet to the growing calls for independence in the Baltic republics, the Communist Party today condemned nationalist movements in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and declared that the agitation had caused alarm and hysteria and raised the prospect of ''civil conflict.''
LEAD: ON Long Island, a $35 candlelit dinner for two with live music, dancing, four courses, a glass of wine and coffee served at a cloth and flower-bedecked table sounds like dream dust.

LEAD: Of the 67 players on the Giants' roster, seven are running backs. All seven will probably survive when the roster is cut to 60 on Tuesday. One or two will go when the final cut to 47 is made the following Monday.

LEAD: Enough is enough! The joke could have been funny, but those telling it never knew its origin. While the recounting of the building of the New Jersey Turnpike (''About New Jersey,'' July 30) brought some interesting historical facts to light, once more the turnpike has been erroneously credited as the inspiration for the talk-show hosts and comedians' question ''What exit?

LEAD: The Times obituary announcing the death of John Hirsch says Hirsch was best known as artistic director of Canada's Stratford Festival. At least for the nonprofit professional theater community in the United States, the real story is quite different.

LEAD: At the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I., Barbara Kirkland Pond was married yesterday to Tylor Field 3d. The Rev. Beverly Edwards, an United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Daniel Warren, an Episcopal priest.
LEAD: A resounding yes! But before he has a chance to resign as principal owner of the Yankees, I would like to tender my resignation as a Yankee fan. CHRIS LOSCALZO Larchmont, N.Y.
LEAD: NONPROFIT groups that in the mid 1980's were overwhelmed by the price of Manhattan office space are finding relative bargains today as landlords struggle to fill vacant floors.
LEAD: Cynthia Steffe is moving briskly through the ranks of women's sportswear designers. When she graduated from the Parsons School of Design in 1981 she was named the school's Designer of the Year.

LEAD: Dana Joi Silfen and Michael Alan Blum were married last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Lawrence Colton. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Silfen of Baldwin, L.I., graduated from the University of Maryland and is employed by CBS Records in New York. Her father is a lawyer in New York.

LEAD: LONG isolated on an urban renewal wasteland of 150 vacant blocks, the seaside synagogue of Congregation Derech Emunoh has just barely survived. Slated for demolition, gradually decaying and its landmark designation overturned by the city, its congregation now is so small that services often cannot be held.

LEAD: Project Orbis, a program that uses an airplane equipped as a teaching hospital to train eye surgeons in developing countries, has reached an agreement with China to establish a permanent relationship.

The 23-year-old bride, a graduate of Syracuse University, is a creative merchandising coordinator in New York for the Amcena Corporation, a retail concern.

LEAD: Sigrid Arlene Mendel and Peter James Usen were married last evening at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia by Rabbi Elliot J. Holin.

LEAD: Many people who love music feel it is not only vulgar but pointless to pry into the lives of the great composers. Who cares if Wagner was a deadbeat, that Mozart used foul language, that Beethoven tried to sell scores to different publishers simultaneously, that Chopin loved a woman who dressed like a man and smoked cigars?
LEAD: After suffering unmanageably high occupancy rates for two years, New York City's hospitals are becoming less overcrowded, according to State Health Department data.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recognize that the July 16 article on the Grampian area of Scotland, ''Castle Country Along the River Dee,'' didn't pretend to be comprehensive, but for readers who intend to use it as a guide for touring, may I put in a good word for Crathes Castle? Crathes is a short drive east of Banchory Lodge Hotel.

LEAD: Modern athletics seem to have gotten in the way of ancient instruments this week, at least in the case of Stanley Ritchie - a practitioner of the baroque violin who missed Thursday evening's Mostly Mozart chamber music concert at Avery Fisher Hall because of a frisbee injury.

LEAD: Flush with a surge in demand for its luxury automobiles, Jaguar Cars Inc. is building a new North American headquarters in the 20-acre Ramapo Ridge corporate park in Mahwah, N.J. The $25 million construction project, due to be completed next spring, will consolidate the British motor company's current corporate operations in Leonia and Teaneck, N.J., into one building of 200,000 square feet, more than double the current space.

LEAD: Two archeologists have recently joined in the quest for the elusive homeland of the Indo-Europeans, speakers of the ancient mother tongue of English and half the other languages of the globe. Their arguments are fascinating but their conclusions discordant. One, J. P. Mallory, places the ancient homeland firmly in the southern steppes of Russia, between the Black Sea and the Caspian.

LEAD: F OUR PEOPLE GAZE at a steeple. A minister sees a religious monument. A mechanical engineer sees a balance of forces and materials. A psychoanalyst sees a Freudian symbol. The person who has to climb 70 steps to clean the belfry sees something else. The same object, but each observer has a different take, depending on his or her deformation professionelle.

LEAD: AccordinG to a recent Department of Labor study, the number of black Americans in the work force increased from approximately 8 million in 1965, to 12.4 million in 1985; and the number of Hispanic workers nearly doubled between 1975 and 1985, to 7.7 million from 4.2 million. million. Moreover, it is estimated that during the coming decade minorities will constitute one-third of all new entrants into the labor force.

LEAD: Control of Hawaiian Airlines would be acquired by a group that includes Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner whose deal for Eastern Airlines collapsed earlier this year, under an agreement set with HAL Inc., which owns the financially troubled airline. The group is headed by J. Thomas Talbot, former chairman of Jet America, a California-based airline.
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.
LEAD: IT took only hours for the killing of a black teen-ager in Brooklyn last week to turn into a political issue, not least for the six men running for mayor of New York City.

LEAD: Alison Jane Bailes and Christopher Bowditch Huntington were married yesterday in St. James, L.I., at the home of the bridegroom's grandmother Mrs. Prescott Huntington. The Rev. Francis C. Huntington, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

LEAD: A tree nine feet in diameter, believed to be the world's tallest Ponderosa pine, has been cut down in a central Idaho forest, producing a 112-foot log. The pine, which died three years ago, was more than 500 years old. Sections of the trunk, with historical dates marked on its growth rings, will go to parks in Boise, Donnelly and Pocatello, Idaho, and a botanical garden in Dortmund, West Germany.

LEAD: My friend Marty is something of an inventor. He has come up with a lock that makes casement windows burglar proof, and he is working on a pop-up barrier to keep bags and packages from flying off the passenger seat of his car.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a ''What's Doing'' article in the Travel section on Aug. 6 about Edinburgh carried an erroneous restaurant listing. The restaurant, Handsel's, closed last December. The exchange rate was also misstated; it is $1.60 to the pound. And the birthplace of James VI of Scotland, later James I, was misidentified; it was Holyrood House.

LEAD: In 1982, when futures markets came up with the idea of stock index contracts, the securities industry said it was a silly idea that would not work. Later, when it did work, the industry said it was the work of the devil and ought to be banned. Later, when most academicians lauded these contracts as indispensable risk-management tools, the securities exchanges decided that maybe it was a good idea after all.

M. Forster's novel ''Maurice.'' INSIDE LONDON: Discovering London's Period Interiors (Prentice-Hall, $29.95) is one result of his search.

LEAD: IT is a familiar scenario: John Jones, businessman, walks confidently to the sun deck of a leading Westchester hotel and announces his arrival. Instead of being handed a key, he receives an indifferent glance from the desk clerk, who informs him curtly that the hotel is completely full and, what's more, there is no record of a reservation for a John Jones.

LEAD: IN the final days of a political campaign, television is like a monstrous maw gobbling up campaign money as fast as it can be raised. The Democratic and Republican mayoral primary campaigns in New York City that will end in two weeks are no exception, even under the restraints of the city's new campaign finance law, which is supposed to keep big money and fat cats out of municipal campaigns.

LEAD: KURT VONNEGUT is ready to talk about how much fun he had writing his new play, ''Make Up Your Mind,'' which will have a staged reading at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton tomorrow, and about how funny it is.

LEAD: The Bush Administration, which came into office with prison furloughs as one of the new President's major emotional campaign issues, is now moving to restrict furloughs in the Federal prison system.
LEAD: Like so much of the Jets' team around him, Roger Vick is an unknown quantity with the season two weekends away.
LEAD: Roger Clemens settled down after a shaky start and won his 13th game as the Red Sox beat the Detroit Tigers this afternoon, 5-2, for Boston's fifth successive victory.

LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company announced a major restructuring aimed at paring costs following a weak second quarter. The company will cut 4,500 jobs this year and will sell some of its business units. There will also be a wage and salary freeze for 1990. Kodak's poor showing comes after its $5.1 billion purchase of Sterling Drug Inc.

LEAD: QUITE THE OTHER WAY. By Kaylie Jones. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Although we've got used to second-generation actors equaling or surpassing the accomplishments of their parents, the same hasn't happened with second-generation novelists. Nonetheless there are a few, like Martin Amis and Susan Cheever, who are making names for themselves - and added to their small number ought to be Kaylie Jones, the daughter of James Jones, whose second novel, ''Quite the Other Way,'' is a look at the particulars and peculiarities of glasnost.

LEAD: Edward O'Brien, a Federal drug agent arrested on cocaine trafficking charges here last week, pleaded not guilty Friday and a United States magistrate said she would decide Monday whether he should be freed on bail.

LEAD: ''Theater is an engagement between the actor and the audience,'' says Pauline Collins. ''Film is a different sort of medium. It's not immediate, but in some ways it's more involving. I think you can lose yourself more easily in a film than in the theater.''

LEAD: When the New York Philharmonic was first broadcast live over radio station WJZ, Newark, in 1922, it was heralded as an event of enormous significance. An article in Popular Radio (October 1922) reported: ''For the first time in history the music of one of the greatest of orchestras, the New York Philharmonic, of 85 pieces, was transmitted by special wire from the City College Stadium in New York to a distant broadcasting station and sent out by radio to probably the biggest number of auditors that have ever listened in on a musical program.

LEAD: ''This movie is about contrasts,'' says the director Susan Seidelman, and indeed it's hard to imagine a more contrasting pair of stars. One is tall and sleek; the other is, well, fat. One is refined; the other, outrageous. One trained at Yale; the other, in biker bars. One does accents; the other, wisecracks.

LEAD: The outcome of the Shoreham controversy is a foregone conclusion. Despite the apparently never-ending controversy, there is really no question about the ultimate outcome. The old adage that ''money talks'' holds true in this case. And the people of Long Island have ''voted'' with their pocketbooks.

LEAD: ''I lied because I needed to support myself. I was a young girl and there was no one to support me.'' Lisa Ann Jones, former trading assistant, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

LEAD: Social gallantry still rules in Newport, R.I. When the Preservation Society realized that its fund-raising dinner and ball would conflict with a debutante party, the society gave its party at the Breakers on Friday, Aug. 18, instead of that Saturday. The opulent rooms were filled with trees of purple petunias and other flowers from the Breakers greenhouse.
LEAD: THINGS could not be going any better for Ruth Brown these days.

LEAD: THE adventurous, the rich and the hardy have long come to Kenya for safaris, dreaming of the 1930's grand tradition of the Prince of Wales and his favorite white hunter, Bror Blixen. More recently, movies like ''Out of Africa'' and ''White Mischief'' helped Kenya's standing as an exotic destination that was also accessible.

LEAD: FIREFIGHTERS in Fairfield have a new piece of protective equipment that they bring to fires. It is a roll of plastic to cover rugs when responding to minor fires, so they do not muddy the carpet on rainy days. It is the first innovation to come out of a fire department program that offers fire victims a chance to evaluate firefighting techniques.

LEAD: Fred Waitzkin's poignant remarks about his homeless friend convey a sense of hopelessness in dealing with the homeless who suffer from chronic mental illness (''When All the Stars Are Gone,'' July 16). Homelessness, in this case, seems to have followed the onset and gradual worsening of mental illness.
LEAD: The thing baseball fans seemed to forget all along was that this was really harder on Pete Rose than it was on the fans themselves.

LEAD: Voyager 2 is heading for the stars after transmitting to Earth a vast treasure of scientific information about the distant planets of our solar system. Simultaneously, another space probe is on its way to Venus to learn why a planet so near and similar in size to Earth suffers 900 degree temperatures underneath its veil of sulfur rain.

LEAD: South Africa's Acting President, F. W. de Klerk, declared today that the Government would not allow the current wave of protests to widen into the kind of violence that shook the nation from 1984 to 1986.

LEAD: President Bush has responded swiftly and wisely to Colombia's cry for help in its war against the drug cartels. His decision to dispatch helicopters, arms and other equipment to Bogota meets an urgent need. It could also mark the start of a sound, and essential, foreign policy on drugs.
LEAD: Jackie Mason tells a story about a man who finds his wife in bed with another man. ''It's not what you think,'' she says to her husband. ''He's just teaching me to dance.''

LEAD: ''ELDER OF THE JEWS'': Jakob Edelstein of Theresienstadt. By Ruth Bondy. (Grove, $26.95.) History rarely forgives those who fall, eyes closed, into its traps. Ruth Bondy makes this point in ''Elder of the Jews'' with the story of the commissioner of the International Red Cross during World War II, a man who emerged from a stroll through the Theresienstadt concentration camp convinced the Jews there had reached safe haven.

In Genoa, her son Gianni makes his frittata on top of the stove, inverting the omelet onto a plate after the eggs have set and sliding it back into the skillet to complete the cooking.

LEAD: AS Elizabeth Mills Brown searches through the cities and towns of Connecticut, she knows just what she wants. ''I want everything of distinction,'' she says. Mrs. Brown's task is to find the state's best architecture.

LEAD: In the Government's insider-trading investigation of Wall Street, the first person convicted by a jury was Lisa Ann Jones, a runaway at age 14 who become a $117,000-a-year trading assistant for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. at age 26. Last week, a Federal judge sentenced her to 18 months in prison and imposed $50,000 in fines, not for securities law violations but for perjury and obstruction.

Women I've known more than 20 years, women I've known only a short time, women I have never met - dozens of women who have responded to a woman's catastrophic inability to care for her own family.

Actually, the lyricist's schedule called for her to work on only two shows that day; but she worried some about the other two.

LEAD: Purely ornamental as they may seem now, decorative antique boxes hold the key to the social customs of an older culture. Stored within their intricate interior fittings was the paraphernalia that served both men and women in the tasks and pleasures of daily life - particularly as they traveled abroad.

LEAD: Too few people gave much thought to training when personal computers arrived in offices. ''Here it is,'' a technician said, patting the contraption that replaced the typewriter. ''Call if you need help. Good luck.'' But today no company can afford to be casual about training, for computers and software are tools used for competitive advantage.

LEAD: When the Soviet authorities jailed the leaders of the most prominent Armenian nationalist group last winter, they hoped to quell and discredit the growing movement that these men were directing.

LEAD: FIRST came postmodernism, which stems from the idea that there can no longer be anything newer in the arts than what has already been created. Now a State Department official, Francis Fukuyama, has caused a stir among intellectuals with his thesis that the period of ''post-history'' has arrived. With the decline of fascism and Communism, he argues, Western liberal democracy has triumphed and mankind has reached its highest wisdom.

LEAD: AZT is the only drug approved for use against AIDS. It's now known that AZT also postpones the onset of AIDS in people infected with the virus. Yet there's a massive obstacle to wider use of this life-saving drug - its extraordinary cost. At $8,000 a year for users, AZT is said to be the most expensive prescription drug in history.

Since President Bush signed legislation two-and-a-half weeks ago to create the Resolution Trust Corporation, its oversight board has stepped in several times to alter regulators' plans.

In time, Americans began accepting strangers' signatures not just on their jeans but their shoes, purses, cosmetics and furnishings. Signed, labeled or otherwise trademarked, almost everything now seems to be a designer item.

LEAD: Greg LeMond did it again. Continuing his remarkable comeback from a hunting accident that left him near death about two and a half years ago, LeMond surged in a sprint today to win the professionals' world championship in the bicycle road race.

LEAD: Nathan Susskind, a New Jersey lawyer and philanthropist, died of cancer Friday at Bayonne (N.J.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Bayonne.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation office here has dropped out of the investigation of Pete Rose, satisfied that the former Cincinnati Reds manager wasn't involved in a cocaine-trafficking ring.

LEAD: Police departments in the country's largest cities employed only slightly more policemen in 1987 than a decade earlier, but at the same time the rate of violent crimes jumped by 43 percent, the Justice Department said today.

LEAD: Egypt and Jordan indirectly criticized Syria over the weekend for its role in Lebanon's conflict, highlighting differences between the Syrians and neighbors usually described as moderates in the Arab world.
LEAD: Israel deported five Palestinians accused of leading the Arab uprising in the West Bank today.

LEAD: Racial tensions from the killing of a black youth on Wednesday flared again in Bensonhurst yesterday as 60 to 70 marchers clashed with about 250 white residents who screamed obscenities and racial slurs.

LEAD: Explosive volcanoes fueled by liquid nitrogen or possibly methane may well account for the rugged terrain around the south pole of Triton, Neptune's largest moon, scientists reported today after further analyzing photographs from the Voyager 2 spacecraft.

LEAD: More than 2,000 mourners came to pay their respects to Huey P. Newton today, waiting in a long line to file past the open coffin containing the body of the slain co-founder of the Black Panther Party.

LEAD: Risa Rabinowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rabinowitz of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Goldberg, a son of Norma Goldberg of Philadelphia and the late Sidney Goldberg. Rabbi Sheldon Thall and Cantor David Abikzer officiated at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. The bride, a magna cum laude graduate of Boston University, is the eastern sales manager in New York for Elle magazine.
LEAD: President Bush stepped up to bat with a score to settle.

Stover of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Synagogue in New York. Mr. and Mrs. Stover, who are 23 years old and graduates of Georgetown University, are the owners of Hold It!, a manufacturer of women's accessories in New York.
LEAD: The expected loss of a million teachers from the nation's classrooms in the next five years has prompted Washington and New York City to revive a useful idea from the 1960's: the Teacher Corps.

LEAD: An article on Tuesday about the reaction of Poles and Polish-Americans in the United States to the political events in Poland misidentified a Brooklyn church. It is St. Stanislaus Kostka Church in Greenpoint.

LEAD: A fisherman won a $7,700 settlement from the Exxon Corporation and the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company after filing a complaint in small-claims court that he lost wages because of the nation's largest oil spill.

LEAD: In one of their shabbiest performances of the season, the Mets took a 13-7 thrashing from the San Diego Padres this afternoon and were swept out of town three and a half games out of first place and fading fast. And, for an extra shot of bad news, they probably lost Bob Ojeda for a couple of weeks with sprained ligaments in the left knee.

LEAD: Rick Prelinger is a pack rat extraordinaire. The archivist has collected more than 20,000 industrial, public service and educational films - most of which had languished forgotten in vaults for decades. Now, to ease the access of producers to this and other collections, Mr. Prelinger has published a guide to every significant storehouse of film and videotape footage in North America.
LEAD: A privately owned rocket fired a payload into orbit yesterday for the first time in the history of the space age.

LEAD: It is a story that seems too good to be true: how an industrial city that came to symbolize the ugliest violence of the civil rights era in the South was transformed into a harmonious, economically diverse city under enlightened black leadership.
LEAD: The fixed-income securities market is bracing for a week of volatile price moves in what is normally its slowest period of the year.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Getting the right people in the right jobs is always a priority for a new President, but for a variety of reasons, the task has been especially difficult for President Bush.

LEAD: Melinda Ruth Stolley and Craig Jonathan Snider were married yesterday in an interfaith ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Thomas L. Stiers, a Congregational minister, and Cantor Raymond Smalover.

LEAD: ''This is the beginning of a whole new era in space for America. We're now aggressively entering the world competition to launch satellites.'' -Stephanie Lee-Miller, director of the FederalTransportation Department's commercial space office. [ A1:6. ]
LEAD: * J. Walter Thompson/New York will create a campaign for the Council of Independent Colleges, an association of small liberal arts colleges based in Washington.

LEAD: On the eve of the final round of talks aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia, Prince Norodom Sihanouk resigned as president of one of the main political factions seeking to oust the Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia, his aides said today.

LEAD: Irving Stone, a prolific author whose exhaustively researched and often immense biographical novels included ''Lust for Life,'' based on the story of van Gogh, died of heart failure on Saturday night at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 86 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

LEAD: * Bob Cox has resigned as executive creative director of Hal Riney & Partners/New York.
LEAD: Robert G. Martin, a 42-year-old educator with a history of rescuing troubled institutions, will arrive here next month to take command of the Haskell Indian Junior College.

LEAD: From the Federal Register of Friday, Aug. 11, concerning termination of a Department of Housing and Urban Development program known as Title X. The program was designed to provide Government insurance for affordable development projects, but rules were bent to serve luxury and resort projects. Loan defaults ended up costing taxpayers $90 million.

LEAD: Yankees and Mets Q. When Walt Terrell joined the Yankees from San Diego last month, he also joined a list of major leaguers who have been with both New York teams, the Yankees and the Mets. How many pitchers are in that group? A. Terrell is the 18th pitcher among the 39 players to have donned both New York uniforms in a regular season, meaning that more than 45 percent of those with Met-Yankee backgrounds have been pitchers.
LEAD: For Michael Fish, the British Broadcasting Corporation's veteran weatherman, who has a weather-obsessed nation waiting on his every word, it has been a disappointing summer.
LEAD: Nine Colombian bank offices were bombed, and the nation's Justice Minister reportedly resigned after receiving death threats. Page A10.

LEAD: Citing dwindling financial support for the account, Chiat/Day/Mojo announced yesterday that it had parted ways with the Ricoh Corporation, a manufacturer of copiers, after handling the company's advertising for two years. The account, which includes broadcast, print and outdoor advertising, is worth $6 million.

LEAD: Nine bank offices, seven of them Government-owned, were dynamited today, presumably by drug traffickers, as indications grew that the Minister of Justice was resigning in the face of death threats.

LEAD: Erica A. Grody, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin H. Grody of New York, was married yesterday to David J. Levens, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Levens of Massapequa, L.I., at Beth El Temple in West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Stanley Kessler officiated. Mr. and Mrs. Levens, both 28 years old, are the senior audio engineer and production associate, respectively, for the ''Today'' show on NBC-TV in New York.
LEAD: ''It's so exciting when the product and the concept come together,'' says John Sullivan, a candy manufacturer. ''And with Boogers, we've hooked into something culturally significant.''

LEAD: The filbert harvest in Oregon and Washington is estimated at 13,500 tons, down 18 percent from 1988 and the smallest output since 1984. An Agriculture Department report said severe cold in early February interfered with pollination. The Oregon crop of filberts, or hazelnuts, was forecast at 13,300 tons, compared with 16,300 tons in 1988.

LEAD: Forgotten in remote mountain churches, Argentina's colonial art has barely survived centuries of neglect. Canvases flap free of their frames. Images of Roman Catholic saints are dim with grime and soot and scorched with candle burns.

LEAD: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Tuesday misidentified the president and chief operating officer of General Motors and the banking company that appointed him to its board. He is Robert C. Stempel; the company is the NBD Bancorp.

LEAD: David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, has called for increasing spending on services and benefits for poor children and troubled families as a way of helping people and saving money.

LEAD: Beth Ann Solomon, 23 years old, and Steven Barry Glazer, 28, were married yesterday by Cantor Raymond Smolover at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. Mrs. Glazer is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Solomon of Harrison, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Florence Glazer of Yonkers, and Bill Glazer of Newport Beach, Calif.

LEAD: Virginia Taggart quit her job earlier this month as a secretary, sold her four-bedroom house in Anaheim and moved to rural Washington State after living here for 50 years. Life here, once wonderful, had become just too difficult, she said, with ''gridlocked'' traffic and smog. She will miss little about the Los Angeles area ''except my daughter and grandchildren.

LEAD: Fifteen years after Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn was exiled, a Soviet magazine has begun publishing portions of ''The Gulag Archipelago.'' Page A7.

LEAD: The commodity trading firm Capcom Financial Services Ltd. has been expelled from the Chicago Board of Trade in response to its indictment on charges involving a multimillion-dollar scheme to launder drug profits, the Board of Trade said Thursday. London-based Capcom, which had been a member since 1985, agreed to the expulsion and to never reapply for membership.
LEAD: The six-year treasure hunt for a golden horse is finally over, and the only winner is a Philadelphia-based charity, the Big Brothers/ Big Sisters of America.

LEAD: Let somebody experiment with crack, and chances are good that his dealer has gained a steady customer. Let that person experiment with cigarettes, and chances are even better that the tobacco industry has one.

LEAD: Walter A. Drexel, who was named chairman of the Singer Company on Friday, is a former railroad and oil executive who is coming out of retirement to try to help calm the troubled waters at the military contractor.

LEAD: In the last few days, the normally adverse August social mood has been relieved by comment, press and private, on two rather spectacular social events. One was the million-dollar party sponsored by Saul Steinberg for his 50th birthday by his fiscally attentive wife, Gayfryd.

Seligman, an editor in the public information department at the United Nations in New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Mark, an associate editor of New York Jewish Week, a newspaper. Rabbi Avraham Weiss, assisted by Rabbi Marvin J. Spiegelman, performed the ceremony at the Washington Hotel in Belle Harbor, Queens.

LEAD: The Angolan guerrilla leader, Jonas Savimbi, said today that he was prepared to restore the cease-fire that has broken down in his country 's civil war amid confusion over what was agreed to in a June accord.

LEAD: Nearly every child who ever saw a circus has harbored the fantasy of running away to join one. And here in the wooded groves of Mendocino County, 200 miles north of San Francisco, a camp combines that fantasy with another vision: building a peaceful, harmonious world.

LEAD: The Soviet Union may be signaling to the U.S. a willingness to engage in a complete, mutual halt in production of the essential elements of modern nuclear weapons: plutonium, enriched uranium and tritium.
LEAD: During a recent visit by the House Armed Services Committee to Sevastopol, a Soviet admiral disclosed significant details about a new aircraft carrier being built near there.
LEAD: A state appeals court has overturned the murder convictions of three men in a case of violence against homosexuals that stirred this city five years ago.
LEAD: A new gym bag that fits into standard-size lockers is designed to provide easy access to gear.
LEAD: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. promoted Bernard J. Hamilton to executive vice president and director of strategic business systems.
LEAD: In the club of Latin America's largest debtors, Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela are looking with envy on the debt relief plan won recently by Mexico.

LEAD: A recent newspaper cartoon here showed a group of South American presidents -from Brazil, Peru, Venezuela and Argentina - struggling not to drown in a sea of economic woes, while one man stood on the shore, undecided about jumping in.

LEAD: CHRIS EVERT, whose 19th United States Open will be her last, panicked for only a moment upon waking up last Wednesday morning in Toronto and learning that her plan to ease into retirement following her favorite tournament had been trumpeted worldwide while she slept.

LEAD: A little-noticed section of the House budget reconciliation bill, if passed, could lead to profound changes in the way the nation's $1 trillion in pension assets are invested. The legislation would give 30 million employees control over one of the nation's largest pools of capital.
LEAD: The Spanish Government has awarded three 10-year commercial television licenses, marking the beginning of the end of a state monopoly over television broadcasting.

LEAD: Israeli Air Force fighters bombed and significantly damaged a headquarters of the Party of God in southern Lebanon this evening, killing 2 people and wounding at least 10 others, the army and the police in Lebanon said.

LEAD: The games are beginning to run together now, each day and each defeat weighing more heavily on the Yankees than the one before. There is a growing impatience in the stands, a growing loss of heart on the field and a sense that the new manager, just 10 days into his first term, is already working on borrowed time.

LEAD: With its announcement on Friday of plans to acquire the First Pennsylvania Corporation of Philadelphia, the oldest bank in the country and one of the largest before it fell on hard times in the late 1970's, Meridian Bancorp hopes to bolster its market share in Philadelphia and become one of the state's largest banks.

LEAD: Lorin Maazel made his New York conducting debut 50 years ago this month. Since Mr. Maazel is by no means one of the older conductors in the international upper echelon today, that may be found surprising -but not nearly as surprising as his initial appearance at the 1939 New York World's Fair must have been.
LEAD: Orders for American-made machine tools dropped by 20.7 percent in July from the June level, as a slowdown in the automobile industry continued to hurt manufacturers of factory machinery.

LEAD: Angel Cordero Jr., after being suspended 10 days for careless riding and fined $1,000 for an outburst against a Saratoga Race Track official, denounced the New York track stewards today as incompetent to judge race-riding because ''they have never even ridden a pony.''

LEAD: A newly restored version of Sergei Eisenstein's 1938 film classic, ''Alexander Nevsky,'' is delighting audiences on a world tour that its producer hopes will carry the film triumphantly back to the Soviet Union.

LEAD: You would never know it to look at the stub end of West 61st Street, a public cul-de-sac off Amsterdam Avenue, but within its modest roadbed lie the seeds of 21 extra stories for a proposed apartment tower.

LEAD: One of Broadway's most venerable organizations is to be saluted in an exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. ''The American Theater Wing: 50 Years of Education Through Theater,'' celebrates the golden anniversary of the organization that founded the Tony Awards and that provides a variety of theater-related community services.

LEAD: Leaders of nationalist movements in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania said today that the Soviet Communist Party's scathing denunciation of their actions would not deter them from pursuing their goal of independent statehood and would not provoke them to mass demonstrations.

LEAD: Richard Ravitch is a serious candidate for mayor of New York City in the way that all candidates ought to be serious - in the substance of the positions he takes and the policies he proposes. Unfortunately for him, it's an American political cliche that the only truly ''serious'' candidate is one who looks like a winner.
LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of new issues during this pre-Labor Day holiday week is confined to an auction of three- and six-month bills today.

LEAD: David Frost came out of the right rough at the second playoff hole, then chipped from the fringe and sank a 3-foot putt for par today to beat Ben Crenshaw and win the N.E.C. World Series of Golf.

LEAD: Two decades ago, a British scientist named James Lovelock put forth an imaginative and poetic view of how the Earth functions. The planet's living organisms, he said, act together to regulate the global environment: Life interacts chemically and physically with the air, the waters and the rocks to maintain optimum conditions for itself.

LEAD: When Andrew Reed is asked how old he is, he proudly holds up three fingers, one, then another and another, unfolding them with all the care that three years of living deserve. On this day, each finger was a different color, blue, red and purple.
LEAD: Jerome Walton's mistake helped his team, the Chicago Cubs, score four first-inning runs today. And the Cubs went on to beat the Houston Astros, 6-1.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation made progress on two labor fronts today, actions that should help increase both its share of the domestic vehicle market and its overall profitability.

LEAD: Militant tribal people fighting to set up a separate country in the northeastern state of Assam called off a one-year agitation campaign today after the state government agreed to end its crackdown against militants.

LEAD: Joseph Alsop, the syndicated Washington columnist whose robust opinions appeared in newspapers around the country for five decades, died yesterday morning in his house in the Georgetown section of Washington. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Fourteen weeks after the death of Representative Claude Pepper, the two candidates for his Congressional seat concluded their campaigns today amid the same air of bitter ethnic division that has dominated the race.

The memorial was inspired by the life of Charles Mittel, who escaped from Auschwitz.

LEAD: The cost of a first-class postage stamp will probably rise, to between 28 and 32 cents, early in 1991, Postmaster General Anthony Frank said today. That means two more Christmases at the current 25-cent rate for first-class letters, Mr. Frank said on NBC-TV's ''Today'' show. Mr. Frank had previously said the Postal Service would apply for a rate increase next year, to take effect in 1991, but had not specified the amount.

LEAD: An article on Aug. 8 about the effect of Medicaid cutbacks on Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford misstated the percentage of its patients enrolled in Medicaid, the Federal health insurance for the poor. LEAD: Rowena Wyant, the first woman to be named a vice president of Dun & Bradstreet, died Aug. 23 at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital of injuries received in an auto accident a few days earlier. She was 72 years old and lived in Centerport, L.I.

LEAD: In a widely expected upward revision, the Commerce Department reported today that the economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, considerably higher than the 1.7 percent rate estimated last month.

LEAD: Harry Carson, the former All-Pro linebacker for the Giants, will be a reporter this season for Madison Square Garden Network's ''Giants Journal.'' The show, a weekly half-hour program, features a discussion with Coach Bill Parcells, interviews with players and game highlights. Carson, who made the Pro Bowl eight times in his 13-year-career, will also contribute to the network's ''MSG Sports Desk'' on Sunday evenings during the football season.
LEAD: A denunciation of the Rumanian Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, smuggled out of Bucharest by a former Rumanian official, is causing a stir at a meeting of human rights specialists here.

LEAD: Security for Gov. Bob Martinez has been tightened amid threats of political violence by Colombian drug lords, the Governor has confirmed. ''There has been a general warning, a general concern of high-profile public officials on the subject of drugs,'' Mr. Martinez told reporters Monday.

LEAD: Should we tax pension funds? If a tax could be designed to counter the funds' bias toward short-term investment, it should be strongly considered.

LEAD: An Italian satellite launched to collect data on the stars has failed to reach orbit, an official here said today, and the authorities are prepared to ask the European Space Agency for funds for a second satellite.

LEAD: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that he would prefer what he called ''the law of the jungle'' to the nation's labor laws, which he said were tilted toward business.

LEAD: The Kellogg Company is expected to become the second manufacturer to introduce a cereal containing psyllium, an ingredient that led to a dispute this summer over advertising claims made for a General Mills cereal. LEAD: With a Government crackdown continuing, leaders of two of Colombia's largest cocaine rings have offered to get out of the drug trade in return for an amnesty and truce in Colombia's war on drugs.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors have backed off some of their accusations in an insider-trading case against a former director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who leaked secret information on interest rates to a brokerage.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev personally worked on and approved a Communist Party statement vehemently attacking nationalist activities in the Baltic republics, an official Soviet spokesman said today.

The judge, U.S. District Judge Wallace Tashima, said the defendants knew of his March order barring the blockades in several cities but went ahead with the protests.

LEAD: PROSCIUTTO from Parma, Italy, prized for its sweet flavor and silken texture, will finally be sold again in the United States after an absence of 22 years.

LEAD: Three employees at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan say that for more than a year some hospital employees, under pressure from supervisors, have been altering the background information of hundreds of patients so that they will qualify for Medicaid coverage.

LEAD: Egyptian rights campaigners accused the authorities today of beating and torturing a group of 52 journalists, lawyers, students and workers detained after a strike at the country's biggest steel plant.
LEAD: Lattie F. Coor will leave here in December as president of the University of Vermont to become president of Arizona State University, in Tempe.
LEAD: An editor of TV Guide said yesterday that diet or no diet, Oprah Winfrey's head does not belong on Ann-Margret's body.

LEAD: In a red brick house on the grounds of a community health center here, Massachusetts is experimenting with a way to break a cycle of crime and drug use before it is passed on to a new generation.
LEAD: The accountant for Pete Rose's former housemate implicated the former Cincinnati Reds manager today in an alleged tax-fraud scheme involving a race-track parimutuel ticket.

LEAD: In planning to merge and form the world's second-biggest bank, Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank have an eye on both the new world of deregulation at home and competition abroad.

LEAD: The University of California at Berkeley has agreed to recognize the Association of Graduate Student Employees and meet with the group in ''good faith,'' averting a strike by the 3,000 members who serve as teaching and research assistants on the campus.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency concluded today that a nearby coal-fired power plant causes up to 70 percent of the air pollution over the Grand Canyon. The agency said it expected a final decision by February on how to curb emissions from the plant, the Navajo Generating Station in Page, Ariz.
LEAD: Cliff Stearns moved here from Massachusetts in 1977 and was elected to Congress 11 years later. But he says he never had to worry about the dreaded charge of carpetbagging.
LEAD: Edith Park Martin, an authority on contemporary needlework, died Saturday at Northern Westchester County Hospital after a brief illness. She was 72 years old and lived in Katonah, N.Y.
LEAD: An article in Science Times yesterday about perils facing left-handed people misstated the affiliation of Dr. Diane Halpern. She is at California State University at San Bernardino.

LEAD: John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, says Citibank will offer loans to Mexico as part of the debt restructuring and reduction plan agreed to last month.

LEAD: From the walls of mosques and bazaars throughout this old frontier city, posters showing Afghan guerrillas with turbans stare out at passers-by. By night, supporters of a rival guerrilla faction rip and disfigure the posters, but thousands remain in view.

LEAD: A monthlong international conference aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia appears to have collapsed, with officials predicting today that there will be large-scale fighting between the warring Cambodian factions before serious negotations can resume.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Illinois yesterday priced a $70 million bond issue through competitive bidding. It was awarded to an underwriting group led by First Chicago Capital Markets Inc.

LEAD: The sultry air shimmers as syncopated bodies glide past. A woman in pink carrying a dripping ice cream cone, two scoops. An emaciated, mustachioed man with a million-dollar smile and a ponderous plastic bag of empty cans, a bargain-basement Burt Reynolds if there ever was one. Old women speaking Russian, teen-agers ambling through an endless summer, cotton-candy dreaming, hot dogs with the works.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it plans to lay off 600 assembly line workers in November at its Arlington plant, a union official said. The G.M. plant builds the Chevrolet Caprice, the Cadillac Brougham and Chevrolet, Buick and Oldsmobile station wagons.

LEAD: A ''SOFT LANDING'' appears to be at hand. Although the statistics bounce around a bit, the American economy is clearly growing more sluggishly than it was last year, much to the relief of the Federal Reserve and many economists. Now, the question is whether a slowly growing economy is really a blessing.

LEAD: Members of Congress are loath to accept criticism, especially from those they thought they had helped. Small wonder, then, that some appear ready to wash their hands of the problems of the elderly.

LEAD: For politicians seeking support, crime plays. Each of the six major party candidates for mayor of New York City has made crime prevention and punishment the cornerstone of his campaign, although some of their siren songs may be more apt to capture votes than criminals.
LEAD: Stocks fell broadly yesterday, weighed down by profit taking, a moderate decline in interest rates and a spurt of mid-afternoon program trading.

LEAD: ''LOSE weight safely and quickly without cutting calories - or even counting them.'' That is the promise of ''The T-Factor Diet'' by Martin Katahn (W. W. Norton, $18.95), a best-selling diet book. Dr. Katahn, a psychologist, maintains that as long as you reduce the fat in your diet to about 20 percent of total calories, you can eat as much food as you want and still lose weight.

LEAD: Gerald J. Weber, a retired United States District Court judge who was the chief Federal judge in western Pennsylvania from 1976 to 1982, died of cancer on Monday. He was 75 years old and lived in Erie.

LEAD: ''I wanted the fun of having empty walls for once,'' Billy Wilder joked. So the 83-year-old director has arranged to sell 94 paintings and sculptures from his personal collection at an auction at Christie's in New York in November.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it supports the Dallas-based Harken Energy Corporation's proposed merger with the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation. Last week, Harken offered to pay Tesoro shareholders $11.75 a share in cash, or about $190 million.

LEAD: As Voyager 2 approached Neptune, scientists had six key questions they hoped to answer about the huge, gaseous planet at the farthest reaches of the solar system. With satisfaction, they said today that they had found answers to all of them.

LEAD: The Dallas Times Herald was granted a temporary restraining order on Monday that forbids its rival, The Dallas Morning News, from publishing syndicated cartoons and columns, including the Far Side and Dear Abby, that now appear in The Times Herald.

LEAD: Four years ago, when a group of public school teachers from isolated rural districts and small towns came together here to reminisce about their experience at the Bread Loaf School of English, one of them said: ''I was able to find my own voice. I now own myself.''

LEAD: The dispute over the islands that Britain calls the Falklands and Argentina calls the Malvinas has been encased in permafrost since the two countries warred in 1982 in the frigid South Atlantic. So it's welcome news that they are putting aside rival claims to begin talks on normalizing relations.
LEAD: The Jet careers of two young players, Bobby Riley, a receiver, and Vince Amoia, a running back, came to an end today when they were suspended for testing positive for steroid use.

LEAD: Scores of youths roamed the main business district here for about four hours Monday night and early today, hurling rocks and bottles at cars and storefronts in the tense aftermath of the fatal shooting of a black man by a white police officer on Sunday.

LEAD: In a legal skirmish that pits one founder of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the world's largest leveraged buyout firm, against the other two, Jerome Kohlberg Jr. filed suit yesterday against Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts, accusing them of enriching themselves at his expense.

LEAD: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn yesterday questioned the decision of some clergymen to conduct protest marches last weekend in Bensonhurst, where a black youth had earlier been shot to death after being chased by a white gang.

LEAD: Five years after he signed a contract that revolutionized the salary scale in professional cycling, Greg LeMond is ready to repeat the feat. ''It's a very good contract,'' he said with a soft laugh about the reported $1.5 million-a-year offer. ''More than I ever expected.''

LEAD: Bruce Gould, co-editor with his wife, Beatrice Blackmar Gould, of the Ladies' Home Journal from 1935 until 1962, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Hopewell, N.J. He was 91 years old. Mr. Gould was on the editorial staff of the Saturday Evening Post in 1935 when he and his wife were made co-editors of the Journal.

LEAD: Barely three weeks after taking office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is to leave for the United States this week to offer assurances that Japan's recent political turmoil has not undermined its dependability or willingness to negotiate thorny trade and security disputes.

LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission took steps today to make it more difficult for futures traders to conceal fraudulent transactions. The Justice Department has brought indictments against 46 traders and brokers in Chicago, accusing them of such practices.

LEAD: Among the Colombian drug-trafficking suspects being sought for extradition to the United States are these 12 men, described by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh as the ''dozen most wanted.'' PABLO EMILIO ESCOBAR GAVIRIA ''The Godfather'' Age: 39 Considered the leader of the Medellin cartel.

LEAD: A Palestinian identified by relatives as a leader of the uprising in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip was killed today in a clash with soldiers, witnesses said.

LEAD: In the face of slow sales and a keenly competitive market for the most powerful computer work stations, Ardent Computer Inc. and Stellar Computer Inc., will announce merger plans today, company executives said.

LEAD: Fernanda Wanamaker Munn Kellogg, a philanthropist interested in wildlife, conservation and other concerns, died of heart failure Sunday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 69 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: An article on Saturday about the killing of a black youth by a gang of whites in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn misstated the address of one suspect, Charles Stressler. It is 2042 66th Street, not No. 2142.

LEAD: Feliks Topolski, a Polish-born artist and writer who painted battle scenes and portraits of British royalty for the Government, died Thursday. He was 82 years old and had heart trouble and diabetes.

LEAD: ''Anything Goes,'' a revival of the 1934 musical with music and lyrics by Cole Porter, will end its run at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center, following the Sunday matinee performance. Directed by Jerry Zaks, the show will have run for 44 previews and 804 regular performances.
LEAD: Scholars and universities around the world are setting up archives to collect pamphlets, posters and other items created during the democracy movement in China last spring.
LEAD: The Phoenix Cardinals placed Neil Lomax on the injured-reserve list yesterday, making the two-time Pro Bowl quarterback ineligible to play with the team this season.

LEAD: The jury in Leona Helmsley's tax-fraud and extortion trial deliberated for its fourth day without reaching a verdict yesterday, spending the nine hours apparently discussing the most serious charge against her, conspiracy to extort kickbacks from hotel suppliers.

LEAD: Investigators frustrated by a bold theft from a mine of more than a ton of silver shaped like chocolate kisses are hoping the thieves brag, and they are watching smelters capable of melting it down.

LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran won a major triumph and cemented his political authority today when Parliament approved his entire list for the first new Cabinet since the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
LEAD: Algeria has blocked the admission of Israel to an international conference negotiating a ban on the making and possession of chemical arms, diplomats said today.

LEAD: For years, Colombians walked quickly past the forbidding walls and unblinking electric eyes guarding estates of the nation's cocaine cartels. But with the police raids of the last 10 days, the gates have swung open.

LEAD: Bruce Kennedy, the 51-year-old chairman and chief executive of Alaska Airlines, believes it is the manifest destiny of his company and Alaskans who have ties of kinship and history to the Soviet Union to establish an air link across the Bering Strait.
LEAD: Mayor Edward Koch of New York has always had a troubling propensity for sending the wrong message. He did that again Monday, in the wake of the racial murder in Bensonhurst.

LEAD: Tribal militants detonated a bomb in a bus in northeast India today, killing at least 12 passengers a day after tribal leaders agreed to suspend a campaign of separatist violence, news reports said.
LEAD: By next Monday, when all National Football League teams must be down to the regular-season limit of 47 players, Ottis Anderson will know if he will still be a Giant.

LEAD: Most technological change occurs first in small niches and, more often than is widely recognized, it starts with a creative look at yesterday's innovations in light of new predicaments.

LEAD: An unusual sex discrimination suit that began in 1987 is working its way through the courts in California. LEAD: WHEN the first of our friends decided to leave Los Angeles and go back to the land - specifically Oregon - some 15 years ago, we who loved them secretly laughed. LEAD: Investigators looking into the Alaska oil spill and parties to litigation arising from it have started an inspection of the Exxon Valdez, now in dry dock for a nine-month repair job estimated to cost $25 million.

LEAD: Business failures fell by 14.5 percent in the first half of 1989, the biggest drop in more than 10 years, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation says in a report that suggests the economy is not tumbling into recession.

LEAD: Pandick Inc., one of the companies hurt by a downturn in financial printing, has named James P. Alexis, a seasoned industry executive, as president and chief executive.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, far higher than the 1.7 percent rate estimated last month, the Commerce Department reported. LEAD: VINE-RIPENED tomatoes, bursting with flavor and succulence, are at their peak around about now, but many gardeners have more fresh tomatoes than they know what to do with.

LEAD: WHEN I was a child and my family had a house on the Jersey Shore, summer was a time of long days at the beach, secret hiding places and fireflies we would catch in a jar. LEAD: The Defense Nuclear Agency has announced it was no longer considering a ranch near this border city as a site for underground explosive tests but was looking at another site in the area.
LEAD: Elliott Horne, a jazz writer and press agent, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City. He was 67 years old and lived in New York City.

LEAD: Shares of the AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, continued to move up amid speculation that there may be a bid for the company. LEAD: A lack of money is hampering local governments in dealing with child care and other problems involving children and teen-agers, the National League of Cities said Monday in appealing for long-term Federal assistance.

LEAD: In its strongest effort to counter attacks on airlines, the Government yesterday ordered American carriers to install a new type of bomb detector to check luggage at major airports in this country and overseas.

LEAD: Bowing to intense public criticism, the planners of the Times Square redevelopment project yesterday presented entirely new designs for four office towers, including one with a 27-story built-in sign.

LEAD: Faced with the unfathomable evil of the Holocaust, the French town of Le Chambon-sur-Lignon responded with deep and mysterious goodness. From 1940 to 1944, the 5,000 people of Le Chambon - a community of profoundly religious Protestants - sheltered 5,000 Jews. Individual farmers and pension owners took in refugees; a Swiss-run school received Jewish children from French internment camps; a safe house sheltered Jews heading for the Swiss border.

LEAD: Although psychological depression is suspected of reducing the body's immunological defenses, researchers now say it does not appear to increase the risk of cancer.
LEAD: The number of American children living with stepparents has risen sharply as women have children before marriage and parents change spouses, the Census Bureau reported today.

LEAD: If America's fascination with automobiles can be termed a love affair, then what started last night in Auburn, Ind., is an orgy of national proportion. Something like 150,000 people are expected to drop in.

LEAD: Herman Badillo, a prominent figure in New York City's Hispanic community who once described Mayor Edward I. Koch as a ''petty racialist who fans the flames of racism,'' yesterday endorsed the Mayor's re-election bid.

LEAD: For Billings S. Fuess, the copywriter who created the line, ''Hershey's, the great American chocolate bar,'' Ogilvy & Mather's Fifth Avenue office was home for 23 years. But last month, Mr. Fuess left the agency to start his own advertising shop in Summit, N.J. Mr. Fuess is currently working on the second edition of a best-selling book, ''How to Advertise,'' with his co-authors, Kenneth Roman, chairman of the Ogilvy Group, and Jane Maas, president of Earle Palmer Brown/New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After months of noisy debate, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted last week to ban amplified and other loud music from subway platforms, while allowing it to continue in the mezzanine areas of stations. The compromise isn't music to everyone's ears - but that's the beauty of it.

LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., stung by new allegations that he has used drugs, denied tonight that he had ever done so and charged that the allegations resulted from ''blatant'' disclosures to reporters by Federal officials who wanted ''to get headlines and to assassinate my character.''

LEAD: An article yesterday about the guilty plea entered by Salim B. Lewis and his investment firm, S. B. Lewis & Company, on criminal charges of securities violations reversed the roles played by two lawyers in the case. Gandolfo V. DiBlazi represents S. B. Lewis & Company; Stanley Arkin represents Mr.
LEAD: Blythe in the Village

LEAD: Banners and lights of red, white and green - the colors of the Italian flag -hang along 18th Avenue in Bensonhurst for the Feast of Santa Rosalia. Normally the neighborhood's biggest event of the year, the feast is overshadowed now by the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black youth who had ventured into the neighborhood to look at a used car and was surrounded by a crowd of white youths and gunned down.

LEAD: A new bomb detector that the Government has ordered airlines to install at large airports cannot reliably spot the type of bomb that caused the crash of a jetliner over Scotland in December, critics say.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Helen Johnson, a lawyer and former trustee of the Experiment for International Living, a student exchange group, died of colon cancer Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 68 years old.

LEAD: The Labor Day weekend in Westchester County will be celebrated with a good measure of leisure, both outdoors and in. There will be a song-filled salute to the work ethic in America, nature walks in search of butterflies - even a horse show and a chess tournament open to novices and experts alike. CONCERT IN SOMERS.In a tribute to laborers everywhere, Muscoot Farm Park in Somers will present a musical revue on Monday called ''Songs of the Working Class,'' led by Jeffrey Main, a guitarist.

LEAD: International A3-11 Latvian nationalists will demand that Moscow grant their region ''special status'' within the Soviet Union, said leaders of Latvia's largest political movement. Page A1
LEAD: Joe Collins, a first baseman for 10 years with the New York Yankees, died today at his home here. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: The Allstate Insurance Company announced that it would offer a 10 percent discount on three leading auto-policy coverages for drivers of cars equipped with anti-lock brakes. The only other United States insurance company offering an anti-lock brake discount is U.S.A.A. of San Antonio, which insures military personnel and their dependents.

LEAD: Some regulators in the Treasury and the Office of Thrift Supervision are warning that they have found a provision in the savings and loan bailout law that could force institutions to build up large cash reserves faster than it was believed the law required.

LEAD: The International Olympic Committee passed three resolutions today restricting the eligibility of athletes in Olympic Games. Two of the measures further isolate South Africa from international competition; the third places limits on the soccer tournament.

LEAD: Robert Schakne, a writer and correspondent for CBS News for 33 years before he retired in 1988, died of cancer yesterday at Sibley Hospital in Washington. He was 63 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: Hungarian and West German officials have worked out a plan that will let up to 20,000 East Germans leave for the West over the next few days, West German Government and opposition officials disclosed today.

LEAD: A light-skinned black woman has won her battle to stop the illusion that she was white, even though her parents listed her as white on her birth certificate in an attempt to help her overcome racial bias.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Consolidated Edison ''misled the city and residents of Gramercy Park'' about the danger of asbestos contamination from a powerful steam-pipe explosion and criminal charges may be warranted, Mayor Edward I. Koch said last night.
LEAD: Fordham will play a game against a major college opponent for the first time in 35 years tomorrow as the Rams begin their association with the Colonial League and Division I-AA.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * BancOklahoma Corp., Tulsa, Okla., a bank holding company, named Stanley A. Lybarger president and chief operating officer of the parent company and its principal subsidiary, Bank of Oklahoma.

LEAD: In his decade of competition at the United States Open, Ivan Lendl has acquired much more than his three singles titles. Over the 10 years and through the countless interviews, he has gained a sense of both perspective and humor, honed a sharp wit and crafted an altogether engaging smile.

LEAD: The Swedish auto maker Saab-Scania A.B., facing mounting losses, today refused to confirm or deny a news report that the Ford Motor Company was negotiating to buy an interest in its ailing passenger car division. LEAD: Kevin Mack, the Cleveland Browns' running back, was suspended for four games by the National Football League yesterday for violating the league's substance-abuse policy.

LEAD: THE really exciting thing about the American economy at this point is that there is no excitement. Despite everything - the near-record seven-year longevity of the expansion, the anxieties about recession and inflation, the mounting national debt, which has been exacerbated by the bailout of savings and loans, the relatively high level of interest rates and the high cost of the dollar in international markets - the United

LEAD: Darryl Strawberry has finally broken his silence after refusing to speak to reporters for the last month. He admitted today that he was ''very disappointed the way I've been playing all season'' and promised a new effort to help spark the Mets.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SEW WHAT,'' a workshop that teaches children ages 5 to 11 and their families how to make belt pouches, bean bags or pillows, 1 to 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in Central Park, at Belvedere Castle by Turtle Pond and the Delacorte Theater, south of the Great Lawn at 79th Street. Free.
